name: Christophe HANSEN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you, Commissioner, for being here. It is also a great honour for me to be able to speak of this place, because it is now almost a beaten year that we have worked out a compromise with the Council. Mr Eickhout and Mrs Müller were also present, which was a night shift with the Finnish Presidency. However, it was important that we finally managed to get this modernisation of the Drinking Water Directive, which had been on the hump for twenty years. However, we have also taken various things on board, such as the first European citizens' initiative, which has collected the necessary – over a million – signatures. For example, we have included a new Article 13 describing access to water, and this is intended, in particular, to help our most vulnerable groups of society without permanent residence to gain access to water. That is why we have called on the Member States to finally make drinking water sources available in public places and in public buildings, in order to give these social groups a chance. However, we have also increased transparency. We want information on price scale, but also on the quality of water, to be more accessible to the consumer, because trust in drinking water will also lead to less plastic being used, more drinking water to be used, and that benefits us in many respects. However, we have also addressed the challenges, requirements and recommendations of the World Health Organisation and have adapted various limit values. For example, in the case of lead, we now have stricter limit values. But we have also gone further in order to finally put our close eye on new substances such as endocrine disruptors, in particular bisphenol A, but also microplastics, which were not yet provided for in the old directive.  In addition, in times of climate change, we are of course also talking about the consequences of climate change: about drought. That is why it was irresponsible for us to leave out various things. The Council would have preferred to do this when it comes, for example, to the loss of the lines. Many of our pipeline systems in Europe are very, very old and have a leak rate that can be up to 70% in different Member States. That is why it was very important that we also tackle this problem. I mentioned the trust in drinking water. Why is it important that people know how high quality our water is? When people drink water from the tap, they must be aware that drinking water that is bottled will require up to a thousand times more energy to transport this water. In other words, we are also reducing the amount of plastic waste generated by bottles. We actually laid a foundation stone for the Green Deal before the Green Deal was even on the table. I think that is something where we, as a Parliament, have also played our part in strengthening our ambitions. In this sense, I would like to thank all the colleagues who have worked on this. Today, however, we also have a resolution and a question for oral reply to the Commission, in general on water policy. We have just talked about stricter measures and stricter criteria for drinking water. That is why it is also important that we do not rely too much on cleaning processes and other cleaning methods. We need better protection of our water sources. That is why it was and is important that the Water Framework Directive is properly implemented by the Member States. There is the problem: we have the evaluation from the Commission, we have taken note of it. It is stated that this set of rules of our European water regulation is actually fit for purpose, but that implementation in the Member States is often either underfunded or simply far too far from reality to have our waters in good ecological, good chemical condition by 2027 – that is the aim. We must also note that more than half of our surface waters are still in poor condition. Freshwater stocks have fallen by 83% since 1970 – here again the link to the Green Deal, we definitely need to get on with it. European wetlands are natural carbon stores, and these too have fallen by 50% since 1970. In our resolution, we called on the Member States, and also the various sectors involved – agriculture, energy or even industry – to get involved. We have therefore set out the 'polluter pays' principle more firmly anchored. I would also like to thank my colleagues who have worked constructively with us. We have forged 34 compromises out of the 359 amendments, which have been supported across all political groups. We naturally have minor differences between colleagues in how we interpret this. However, I think there is a great deal of agreement here in Parliament, and I would therefore like to thank all the colleagues involved.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: Author. – Mr President, the Water Directive is, to date, the main instrument of the European Union's water policy establishing a Community governance framework for integrated water management, the slowdown in the deterioration of its quality and the reduction of chemical pollution.  Currently, less than half of the EU's water bodies are classified as "in good condition" and only one of the 4 freshwater indicators has made progress over the past 10 to 15 years. The European Parliament therefore considers that the implementation of this Directive must be improved and accelerated. There have been, and are, a number of constraints when implementing water legislation due to inadequate funding and insufficient integration of environmental objectives into different sectoral policies. In this context, it is essential to focus on the application of water legislation by the different Member States. We have not achieved the objectives we have set ourselves for 2015 and we must work together quickly to achieve the objectives by 2027, which are these: the protection of all forms of surface and groundwater, inland and transition, the restoration of existing ecosystems in and around the water bodies, the reduction of pollution of water bodies and the guarantee of the sustainable use of water by all.  The control of the adequacy of water legislation has made considerable differences in application between Member States, in particular in relation to controlled pollutants and the limits set out in the Groundwater Directive.  So how does the Commission intend to achieve a more harmonious application? The integration of the objectives of the Directive needs to be improved in the different sectors, in particular agriculture, energy and transport, and these must be aligned with the strategies of biodiversity, the circular economy, zero pollution and the Common Agricultural Policy. What additional measures will the Commission take to protect water in the agricultural sector? Speaking now of chemical pollution, how does the Commission intend to solve the problems in the field of chemicals and pollutants that raise new concerns, namely how are drugs and microplastics? How will these substances be regulated? The next Multiannual Financial Framework should allocate resources for water conservation. Ambitious actions and projects need to be promoted to contribute to the objectives of the Directive that have not yet been achieved. What measures will be taken in this area?  We need to assign responsibilities to those who cause environmental damage, thereby encouraging non-pollution, changing social behaviour and becoming more aware of the importance of this scarce resource. When will the user-pays and polluter pays principles be fully implemented? So far, exemptions from the Directive have been used in an unjustified manner. The provision of more data, greater transparency and information on water management, aided by coordinated work between local, regional, national and European authorities, will contribute to greater and better river basin management. So how does the Commission intend to reduce the use of exemptions from the water directive in the 3rd cycle of river basin management plans? Effective and immediate responses to the challenges facing the water sector are therefore urgently urgently in line with its direct impact on human health, energy production, agriculture, food security, among many others. Specific funds and programmes are needed to enable the objectives advocated by this Directive to be operationalised. Finally, it is essential to focus on raising awareness of the importance of this resource, because we have no doubt, if no action is taken we will not achieve the proposed objectives for 2027. I would remind you that the mismanagement of this scarce resource will have serious long-term consequences for all of us and for our environment.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Good morning, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you for the invitation. Nice to be back here, I feel very honored. And the fact that I am able to speak again in the European Parliament in what is expected to take place here last week fills me with particular joy. Ladies and gentlemen of the European Parliament, the issue of water has been a topic of concern to us in the European Union for over 20 years – a highly controversial, highly sensitive issue. But we certainly agree – no matter where we are politically and what institution we represent – that clean, healthy water is the most important basis for a good life and that it must be our common goal that we work to ensure that all people in the European Union and, of course, globally have free access to clean water. This year, the European Parliament and the Council adopted two very important acts on water, and I would like to remind you of this once again. And this also makes it clear that we are also trying to live up to our responsibilities. Firstly, the regulation on water re-use in May 2020 and then, more recently, the recasting of the Drinking Water Directive in December 2020. Yes, we are still a long way from our common goal of being clean rivers, clean lakes – everywhere. The Council warmly welcomes the Commission's report on the aptitude test of EU water legislation and its main conclusions. Water legislation so far has, by and large, served its purpose. However, honourable Members, there is, of course, still a great deal of room for improvement, and I would just like to comment very briefly on the most important points: these are the right investments. This is concrete implementation in the Member States and in the regions, but also at local level. This is the inclusion of water in other policy areas: transport, agriculture – agriculture alone is responsible for 33% of water consumption, and a significant burden on our water is also caused by the agricultural sector. In this respect, it is important that we look at these different sectors and also ask what responsibility each sector has for the objective of making the waters cleaner. And then, of course, there is also the issue of chemical pollution, and we are facing completely new tests. But it is also about the administrative agreement and, not least, about digitisation. The Commission has put forward important proposals here, and I look forward to the fact that we will be able to debate this very intensively in the Council as well. The Environment Council held an initial exchange of views on the report on 5 March this year, and I would also like to assure you once again that all Member States are determined to adopt the Commission's recommendations in the preparation of their next river basin management plans and their flood risk management plans. Please take us at our word, honourable Members. As far as further measures to combat chemical pollution are concerned, the recasting of the Drinking Water Directive establishes a system of watch lists for the monitoring of emerging substances. And you know that a lot of things have changed dramatically; We didn't have to talk about that 20 years ago. These are the so-called endocrine disruptors, i.e. hormone load. It is a question of the burden of medicines. Or microplastics are a big issue, not only for rivers and lakes, but especially for the seas. And we are also called upon to find quick answers to these completely new tests, to the new burdens. The Council also looks forward to the publication of the Commission's proposals for updating the lists of chemical pollutants affecting surface waters and groundwater. We are also looking forward to an intensive exchange. Finally, once again, ladies and gentlemen, the Council is seriously committed to a sustainable water management policy that takes account of our common environmental objectives and contributes to the objective of a pollutant-free environment set out in the European Green Agreement. And we must live up to this responsibility together.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission very much appreciates the European Parliament’s support and interest in water policies. Let me thank you for your work on this file and for the strong support for the important resolution which you will adopt following today’s debate. The European Union has every reason to be proud of its water acquis. It has halted water deterioration, brought unprecedented governance to transboundary water management and laid the foundations to deliver on the human right to water.  Nevertheless, four major crises threaten our waters: the climate crisis, the biodiversity crisis, the pollution crisis, the resources crisis, and, on top of that, we now have the COVID crisis as well. Business as usual is not an option. I can assure this House of the Commission’s commitment to supporting Member States in their efforts to step up implementation of the water directives. When we received their legislation in a comprehensive fitness check, we found it broadly fit for purpose with some room for improvement.  At this stage, we see no need to revise the Water Framework Directive beyond updating the lists of surface and groundwater pollutants to align them with science. The year 2027 is the final deadline to achieve good status for surface and groundwaters. The next river basin management plans, covering the 2021—2027 period, will be critical in this respect.  The Commission is working closely with the Member States through the common implementation strategy, peer—to—peer assistance, the LIFE programme and various research projects. You ask for effective compliance. As the guardian of the Treaties, the Commission will continue to act with determination to enforce the directives. We have announced a set of EU pilots based on the country—specific gaps identified in the fitness check and in the second river basin management plans, and we will not hesitate to use the infringement procedure, should this prove necessary. Under the Green Deal, we have presented a revision of the Aarhus mechanism to improve access to justice. We need enforcement to work better at national level too. Policy coherence is key. We cannot fight pollution with one hand and do harm with the other.  This brings me to the importance of the Green Deal and the integrated and coordinated solutions it offers for crises that are complex and interlinked. Water is a recurring theme in the Green Deal initiatives. The circular economy action plan features water efficiency and reuse. The biodiversity strategy includes the restoration of rivers and wetlands. The farm to fork strategy covers nutrients, pesticides and eco—schemes, and forthcoming initiatives like the climate adaptation strategy and the zero pollution action plan reserve a special place for water. I’d like, therefore, to ask the honourable Members to make sure that this coordinated approach is maintained here in Parliament as well when processing the different elements of the Green Deal.  You have repeatedly called for more harmonised criteria on pollution thresholds, more action on pollutants of emerging concern and better information. We therefore very much welcome the formal adoption of the recast of the Drinking Water Directive this week. This revamped piece of EU water law on which we managed to find an agreement in trilogues almost exactly one year ago was a precursor of the European Green Deal. Now it is making a concrete contribution to climate change, the circular economy, zero pollution for a toxic—free environment, and thus to biodiversity as well.  Next year, the Commission will present the zero pollution action plan, the first integrated EU framework to holistically tackle and inform policymakers and the general public on pollution of air, water and soil.  We are already at work on many of its components. We are updating the legislation on environmental quality standards for both surface and groundwaters and revising both the Industrial Emissions Directive and the Urban Waste Water Treatment Directive in continuous coordination with the scientific community and stakeholders. Our aim is to become collectively better equipped in tackling pollution at source and its key pathways. In doing so, we will factor in the lessons learned from the COVID—19 crisis to make better use of water surveillance with a view to becoming better prepared and more resilient. To finish, a word on financing. Member States’ efforts to draft the third river basin management plans coincide with the imminent adoption of the reinforced multiannual financial framework and the Next Generation EU instrument. The OECD estimates the European Union’s needs for water supply and sanitation at around EUR 289 billion for the next 10 years. We have to become fairer and better apply the laws so that the burden to pay is put on all water users and those who pollute it at its source. To conclude, it will be important to be generous with our rivers. If we restore them to health, they are sure to return the favour.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: ppe group. Madam President! All the water found on the planet is only 2.5% drinking water, of which only 0.007 percent can be drunk. The rest needs to be cleaned thoroughly, and even better than is done in many places today. Even in the European Union, where some countries must stop pouring water out of their ears when they try to explain why they have not yet implemented the laws and regulations to ensure clean water for Europeans. Many of my colleagues will say that. Because it has to be said that it is insanely important, but there is also other things. Namely, the contribution of water to CO2 reduction through energy efficiency improvements in the water sector. These are actually pretty crazy numbers. Listen, the EU water sector seizes two to three percent of our total electricity consumption. It may not say much, but it is. In fact, it equates to as much power as an electric car needs to travel in a straight line 38 million times around the globe or make two million return journeys to the Moon. You see it for you. The potential of energy efficiency improvements in the water sector is, a blow to the bag, 25 percent. That's the equivalent of saving 9.5 million trips around the world for that little electric car. Or just under 20 million tonnes of CO2. Energy efficiency in the electricity consumption of the water sector is not a drop in the ocean. I hope that we will remember this going forward in the green transition, including of our water sector.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the right to safe water and sanitation is a human right. Still 1 million people in Europe have no access to water and 8 million have no sanitation today. This is cause for grave concern and must be a wake-up call for all decision-makers across Europe. We as politicians have a responsibility to ensure that all people in Europe have access to safe and healthy water to drink, and we must also make sure that the EU’s water legislation contains sufficient environmental standards. Later today, we will finally adopt the final agreement on the Drinking Water Directive after many years of revision. It is a welcome modernisation of this important legislation. We are improving access to water for all, in particular for vulnerable groups in our society, and the new rules also mean that we will use better parameters for assessing the quality of drinking water, with tougher thresholds for a number of chemicals as well as the watch-list for pollutants such as microplastics and pharmaceuticals. We are ensuring that tap water across Europe is safe to drink and taking a welcome step towards realising the human right to water in Europe. EU water legislation needs to be foolproof and protect the health of people and the environment. The Water Framework Directive is especially important in this regard and I welcome the fact that we will vote on this resolution later this week. It is very worrying that Member States are not adhering to the framework directive and are not implementing the rules the way they should. Unless there is a big improvement here, the Union will not reach its the objectives under the framework directive by the deadline of 2027. Half of the water bodies in EU have still not attained good status, and good chemical status has been achieved only for about a third of the surface waters. The solution to this is not to dilute the directive, of course. Europe should not lower its environmental ambitions, especially in the light of the Green Deal and the important role that clean water bodies with healthy ecosystems play for nature, our society and the climate. What we need here is better solutions for improving this implementation.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Renew Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has done so. We have the saying "Good thing wants to have a while". Unfortunately, since the conclusion of the trialogues due to the Corona crisis, it has taken us longer to adopt the new Drinking Water Directive.  In fact, there is a lot of good to be said about them. The Commission's proposal came in response to the first successful citizens' initiative. The directive is therefore a hobby of European citizen participation. In future, the directive will not only improve consumer information. The updating of health-related limit values, the creation of an observation list for emerging pollutants, the ambitious rules for old lead pipes and harmonised regulation of drinking water contact materials will also improve consumer health protection. All this creates confidence in the high quality of drinking water in Europe.  With the implementation of the risk-based approach, we will be able to combat contamination at source in the future. Here, Parliament has been able to ensure that prevention must come before containment. This is a major step forward in the protection of our waters and our natural drinking water resources. Personally, I am particularly concerned about the many small municipal water suppliers and cooperatives that have to work with the directive in practice. I am therefore pleased that, in the negotiations with the Council and the Commission, we have been able to resolve many detailed problems in order to ensure that the day-to-day business of water suppliers is implemented. I would like to take this opportunity to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur, Christophe Hansen, and to our shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation.

name: Simona BALDASSARRE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my satisfaction with the results we have achieved with the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on this directive.  Water is a fundamental good for human life and its safety is an essential prerequisite for having the best of it. Politics, institutions and society need to engage in constructive dialogue, and the 2012 Right2Water initiative is a virtuous example from the bottom up that the European Union has embraced. If this Parliament shows that it is open to everyone's contribution, it not only makes a qualitative leap forward, but finally understands that opposition, with their ideas, also plays a fundamental role in democratic dialectics.  Let us go into it specifically: the checklist of endocrine disruptors, pharmaceuticals and microplastics, as provided for in the directive, is a fundamental step forward and a valuable tool. Today, unfortunately, in many Italian and European areas, drinking water is subject to a huge series of pollutants, and one case in all, the Veneto region where PFAS contamination has been one of the most serious health and environmental emergencies ever faced for years. Furthermore, reaching a compromise on a significant list of pollutants is a regulatory intervention, where, in fact, in some cases there were no rules.  Finally, an important fact is that The Member States will be free to intervene in their territories with more stringent restrictions if they deem it necessary. In conclusion, this directive is a first step in safer consumption and more conscious use of water.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Today is really a good day for consumers in Europe and also a good day for the environment. The new EU Drinking Water Directive will bring crucial improvements for clean, healthy and also better drinking water. First of all, we owe it to the citizens who have signed the European citizens' initiative 'Right to water' 1.8 million times. And it was this citizens' initiative that carried us all to the hunt. That is why the European Commission has presented a new Drinking Water Directive. That is why the European Parliament has strengthened the proposals. That is why the Council of Member States ultimately approved at least part of the proposals. It is simply a correct and important sign that hormone-altering substances will be controlled and limited in the future, and that bisphenol A, which is also suspected of causing serious damage to children in particular, is now getting a European limit value. Likewise, that drug residues are regulated and microplastics. That we are now on an easier path to identify new hazardous substances via an observation list and to regulate them throughout Europe. In doing so, we have succeeded in continuing a success story, because the old EU Drinking Water Directive has already strengthened confidence in drinking water as a good food stuff throughout Europe. But now we are going a step further, because, on the initiative of the European Parliament, public drinking water dispensers are now being set up throughout Europe. And with that, instead of buying plastic bottles somewhere and having to buy water in the way that polluting packaging first, people can fill up their own bottles, and some harmful effervescence with a lot of added sugar may also be avoided. Incidentally, the European Parliament has worked hard here – including Mrs Heidi Hautala, who is leading this – to ensure that thousands of plastic bottles have been abolished in Parliament itself and replaced with drinking water dispensers. That has been years of work in the Bureau of this Parliament, but now the time has come: in the European Parliament, once Corona is over again, you can see what we want everywhere on the streets. Finally, I have one more point: we have another element of European water law, the EU Water Framework Directive. In fact, since 2015, it should have been implemented that all water systems are in good natural condition. I ask Michael Roth for the EU Presidency: when will you ensure that this finally becomes a reality on our rivers and waters? I look forward to an answer today, Mr Roth.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Improving the quality and protection of water resources is a key issue for all the inhabitants of the Old Continent. Water scarcity problems are also increasingly affecting us Europeans.  Eu water policy should encourage Member States to implement better water management practices, in particular as regards water pricing policies. Information policy should raise public awareness of saving water with appropriate tools and encouraging the drinking of water-suitable tap water, the consumption of which will reduce the consumption of water in plastic, environmentally harmful bottles.  At the same time, we need to consider whether ambitious water directives mobilising Member States to take action to improve water quality in Europe should not be modified and more adapted to the changing climate and emerging new pollutants.  Ladies and gentlemen, water is called the source of life. Without it, we are not able to survive the week. Let us take care of its cleanliness and protect its resources for us and future generations.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. "Madam President, only fools confuse value with price," Antonio Machado said. Last week we dawned with the news that water is starting to trade in Wall Street futures markets. They have already put a price on it: price to speculate on a fundamental right, as Peter Arrojo, rapporteur of the United Nations, denounced.  Today we welcome the progress of this Directive and its work on water quality, which will improve the lives of many Europeans. But we fell short of protecting its value as a common good, far from the citizen initiative, brought to this Parliament and supported by more than 1 800 000 people, which guaranteed access to this human right, recognised as such by the United Nations.  Water is everyone's and is a public good, closely linked to all our lives, environments and livelihoods, and an essential component for public health.  In view of current climate change prospects, available flows will continue to shrink. In the face of corruption problems and privatization pressures, our water policy must be implemented from a strict commitment to integrated, participatory and sustainable public management of rivers, lakes, wetlands and aquifers as well as water and sanitation services.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the directive is a real guide to further commercialisation of water and your universal access password has no impact on the people. The basis of the strategy of the European Union and governments concerns not only the acquisition of state-owned enterprises by private individuals, but also the operation of state or municipal water companies on private-economic criteria, whether or not they are privately owned.  We say this clearly: your principle is to recover the cost of water services together with the social consequences of recovery, as you say; in a nutshell: 'water goods and the people paying for the broken'. This is evidenced by both thousands of water supply interruptions per week to working-class households in Athens alone in the midst of a pandemic.  We demand: no thought of further privatisation of EYDAP and EYATH, no increase in tariffs, no interruption of water to the people's households. Only with a socialised economy where land, water resources, networks and infrastructure are social property and not a commodity can adequate and cheap water supply and environmental protection be achieved.

name: Michal WIEZIK
text: – Mr President, there are more than 1 million barriers in the EU that literally bite our rivers and streams, prevent fish from stretching to spawning grounds and wintering grounds, change water flow, prevent rivers from feeding their agúvia. Migrant fish species have literally collapsed in Europe. Since 1970, the decline in their populations has been at an appalling 93 percent. Stretching salmon, strips and sturgeons basically do not exist. After the dinosaurs survived, they were destroyed by our concrete. Today, more than 21 000 hydroelectric power plants operate in the EU and we are still planning to build more than 8000 more. In Slovakia, the Supreme Court recently halted the construction of a small hydroelectric power plant in Žiar nad Hronom. The Court ad on the grounds that the interest in protecting and maintaining a healthy environment clearly takes precedence over the interest in building a small hydroelectric power plant. We should understand that the protection and maintenance of living rivers should be given the highest priority throughout the European Union and our water policies. I am therefore pleased and hopefully pursuing the objective enshrined in the biodiversity strategy of having 25 kilometres of free-flowing rivers by 2030. This objective is being missed if, at the same time, we subsidise the construction of thousands more barriers. We cannot have both, and it is pointless, to liberate the strapped rivers while at the same time attracting those that have remained free until now. We urgently need to improve the implementation of the Water Framework Directive, because water is not just about drinking and electricity. Water is all about life in the first place.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, scientific data show that water resources, also due to climate change, are increasingly becoming a scarce resource, putting human well-being, biodiversity and ecosystems at risk. In order to counter this trend, it is first necessary to implement policies at European level in order to increase their efficient use, while ensuring access for all to drinking water. The drinking water directive, which we are finally adopting today thanks also to the action taken by European citizens, has this dual objective: awareness-raising campaigns, the fight against water waste on national territories, the installation of taps or water fountains in public spaces are among the main measures that, thanks to the work of the European Parliament, we have managed to include in this directive. It is an important step forward but, as highlighted in the Green Deal, we need to go further, to put in place a global strategy that aims not only at the efficient use of water resources, but also at the objective of water quality and therefore zero pollution for water, but also for air and soil.  Attention to water resources, which is a source of life, is crucial. On the one hand, we must achieve the good ecological status of European river basins and the full implementation of the Water Framework Directive in order to preserve and restore biodiversity in lakes, rivers, wetlands and estuaries and prevent and limit flood damage, on the other hand, the new measures will have to address the negative effects of urban run-off and new or particularly harmful sources of pollution. , such as microplastics and pharmaceutical residues. The revision of the other important directive on water resources, namely the directive on urban waste water, will also be a fundamental step in defining the parameters of new pollutants and in strengthening circularity and nutrient recovery measures, in line with what has already been done with the regulation on the reuse of water.  Water is a precious, essential asset, a pillar for human well-being, biodiversity and our economy. Climate change will present us with ever-increasing challenges that we will have to be able to anticipate, as we are doing today in Europe.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, because of climate change, water is increasingly lacking in humans, plants, animals. Recent summers we have seen rivers increasingly dry and earth become arid, barren, dry. Water disappears from the soils of Oltenia and Dobrogea, regions of my country.  In several European countries we bring summer water by tank so that people have strict needs. There is no European green infrastructure, no European blue natural infrastructure. The European Commission is clear, we are not yet where we want it through the Water Directive. We have too many exceptions and too little investment, too much pollution and too little responsibility. Yes, hydropower may be green, but it is no longer when it endangers people and nature.  European rivers are choked by microhydropower plants that produce little energy. Because of them, the whites are destroyed in the name of obtaining the so-called "green energy". Let us be careful that the inflation of microhydropower plants, of building on rivers in protected areas, does not cost more than the current they produce. This means that the authorities do not have the dual role of verification, management, but also of revenue collection from activities that damage the chemical state of the water.  I very much want my country to be a leader in the fight against climate change, to see in the European Green Pact a great opportunity, as it is. But then, in the water basins, we need to see more than just a source of funding. Water is life itself. A truth that is evident in nature, but that seems to be forgotten by people.

name: Aurelia BEIGNEUX
text: Madam President, as we defend access to water in the Third World all day long, let me remind you that our own people are finding it increasingly difficult to access it. Already 11% of Europeans do not have sufficient access to water. Your worldview and business model have dried up groundwater and wiped out many rivers. Your progressive liberalism has already done a great deal of harm to agriculture.  Today, it is the water resource that is under threat. In this area, the institutions that know best what to apply are the states, and it is the states that must have the final say.  Propose a clear and logical text, without liberal ulterior motives, without pseudo-humanist ulterior motives or even pseudo-ecologist. Let us defend the common sense of the Member States in the sustainable management of water. Let us highlight European mutual aid against fires and droughts. Let's promote innovation and research. In particular, let's promote artificial intelligence to help our respective countries make more cost-effective and, above all, greener decisions.  Despite these advances, too many points must be excluded from these texts. So what is this obsession with defending minorities all day long in all European texts? What is the connection or the relationship with access to water? At the same time, the most modest Europeans no longer have access to it in certain regions.  Let us denounce the entry into this text of any form of liberalisation of the water market. And finally, let us reject sanctions for countries that are not in compliance with the Water Framework Directive. The Commission has no legitimacy to impose fines on sovereign and free states.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Madam President, first of all thanks to rapporteur Christophe Hansen for doing a great job on the recast of the Drinking Water Directive. But I think we mainly have to thank our citizens who were at the core of the question of a European Citizens’ Initiative on the right to water, for universal access to water, and I think there we did make good steps despite, I have to say, the Council not really being willing to improve access to water for vulnerable and marginalised groups, because it all had to stay optional. I think it’s thanks to Parliament that we strengthened those provisions.  I think it’s also a good deal if you look at the improvements on, for example, endocrine disrupters, microplastics, and how we are, for the first time, dealing with a group approach on PFAs, so I think that is a good solution, but we also have to discuss the fitness check of the Water Framework Directive.  I think it’s very important that the Commission is stating also here that the Water Framework Directive is fit for purpose and that the Commission is not intending a review, and I think that is something that also this Parliament is asking for. However, still the conclusion is that half of our waters – and in some cases even less than half of our waters – are not in good condition and this means we need to improve on the implementation – and this is also a question for the Commission.  You said, Commissioner, that you will continue, but can you be more precise on what the Commission is going to do to increase the implementation, the pressure on Member States, to implement the Water Framework Directive? And also for the Council. We know very well that the financing is lacking very much and that for the implementation of the Water Framework Directive we need more finances, so how is the Council Presidency going to improve that discussion so that we can have that? Last point: the Member States are making too much use of the exemptions possible in the Water Framework Directive. There are guidelines for that. Is the Commission, together with the Council, intending to update those guideline documents in order to limit the possibility of exemptions, because that is very important as well?

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Water is the greatest treasure and resource of our planet, no doubt about it. Every day, more than 2 billion people worldwide in 43 countries fight for access to clean drinking water. There is a growing deficit. Rapid population growth, combined with climate change, leads to local water conflicts that can easily turn into regional wars in the future. The battle for the Euphrates between Turkey, Syria and Iraq, or the Nile between Sudan and Egypt are just examples of the regions closest to the European Union.  However, the problem of water resources affects not only Arab states or Africa, it is also our problem, the problem of the European Union. I am therefore pleased that the answer is this directive. My country is also struggling with a shortage of clean drinking water, droughts and supply shortages, and this costs us around PLN 2 billion. Today's debate on the revision of the Directive is therefore important, but with the new law there should be additional funding for infrastructure projects related to water and saving. About 66% of household water is used for purposes other than consumption and personal hygiene. That is why we need a revolutionary approach to water in Europe and new investments in its purification and retention. This great revolution can start with each of us.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Colleagues! The fact that water is vital to all of us is quite obvious – it is vital for us humans, for animals, for the plants, for the ecosystem, for our entire environment. Clean drinking water is something that we all need to have access to in our everyday lives. That is why we believe that we must strengthen the right to water. The citizens' initiative, which got so many people behind it, and which demanded just that, shows that this is important for people across Europe, and it put so much pressure on the Commission and the Council and on us in Parliament.  There should be public water fountains, of course with free water. But we all know it's not enough. The right to water must be strengthened in other ways as well, and in that respect we must continue to work together. Water must also be better protected. In this area, we are making some progress. If water contains too many hazardous chemicals, microplastics and other things that have been raised in this debate, it is clear that it ultimately also affects our entire habitat. The water affects us, both directly and indirectly, and in every chain. We have heard here ourselves how we actually need to reform agriculture in order to make it more effective for the protection of water.  The EU Framework Directive is an important step in protecting water. It is therefore important that it is not opened up for audit. Instead, we must ensure that it is properly implemented in all Member States. Of course, resources are needed, and we in the European Parliament will be watching the fact that both the Council and the Commission and the Member States are doing more.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, water is the source of life. For decades, it has been promoted that water in plastic bottles is healthier than that of tap water. However, what citizens do not know, which is that most of the water in these plastic bottles is filled in the city's water supply. Be so responsible to yourself. See the instruction on each water bottle and if the water source is not indicated it is water from the city water supply. Water from the city water supply is extremely acceptable and healthy in most cities, but what pollutes our water in the water supply? It's micro plastic, it's a food that, then, is grown in a genetically modified way, it's antibiotics that our food fills up with. We have to stop with that and we'll have healthy water.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, access to water is a vital right. That is why the legislation we are debating today, if implemented accurately, improves the lives of all of us. Intensive testing for lead mainly derived from piping, endocrine disruptors, microplastics, all those that degrade quality and increase health risk is not only necessary, it is now harmonised with high standards throughout Europe. After all, science warns: Environmental Research has announced that microplastics are detected in apples and carrots, and Nature Sustainability has announced that microplastics are found even in cereals above ground.  Accessibility to drinking water is ensured by high-quality infrastructure, which is why European investments in water are needed. In my city, Thessaloniki, the local company EYATH has reduced the loss from pipes to 30% and continues with projects financed by the Union, and the aim is to involve the private sector. Ladies and gentlemen, 1.8 million European citizens have called for new water legislation to feel safe, to upgrade the environment. We have today responded to this legislative challenge. It is now time for the Member States, water management companies and local authorities to act immediately, using the Commission's help and knowing that water quality cannot be discounted.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Madam President Hautala, Commissioner, Mr Michael for the Presidency of the Council, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work. The revision of the Drinking Water Directive is a success. However, it is a success of the first European citizens' initiative,Right2Water. Thank you again to the citizens who initiated this initiative. They have shown that Europeans can influence European politics even outside the elections. In future, the directive now stipulates that all people in the European Union must have access to clean drinking water. And this is above all a success of the citizens' initiative – so thank you for that! At this point, I would like to express my disappointment to the Council that the concern to provide access to drinking water was not taken seriously at first, but was only taken into account in terms of quality criteria. I think that was a disregard for the Right2Water initiative. But it is not just about quality, it is also about access, because water is a human right. That is why I am pleased that, within the framework of the directive, we have now succeeded in improving access. We are getting public drinking fountains throughout Europe and the Member States are obliged to take all necessary measures to give disadvantaged groups better access to water. And the fact that this is still desperately needed shows that 23 million people do not have access to a public water connection in the European Union – that is a mandate for all of us, and we as a Parliament will look very closely at this. But with the amendment, we are also ensuring that drinking water is safe in Europe and, above all, remains safe. We place even higher demands on quality. European drinking water now complies with all WHO standards, and in the case of lead we halve the value – that is absolutely important and right. It is also important that we look in particular at microplastics and drug residues in drinking water – absolute caution is required here. And a final sentence: At some point, drinking water treatment is no longer possible, at some point it reaches its limits. That is why we must ensure that the water remains clean.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Phosphate is a food for life. Without phosphate, we're going to die. Our potato plants, fruit and vegetable crops need phosphate, as well as fodder for our livestock. However, the world's supply of phosphate is in danger of running out. It is estimated that phosphate will be available for 80 to 200 years. A large part of the phosphate we use leaks away through our faeces to the sewer and eventually disappears into the sea. This is crazy, of course. We need to close this cycle. We can recover 25% of the phosphate we need from human excrement and from our sewage, but this is not yet allowed in accordance with European laws and regulations. Can the Commission indicate when it will allow the re-use of phosphate from sewage?

name: Marco DREOSTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we are debating European water legislation today. Some twenty years after the Water Framework Directive, we can say that this legislation is still relevant, but its implementation certainly needs to be improved and speeded up, further integrating the objectives of the directive into sectoral policies, particularly in the areas of agriculture, transport and energy. Water is an essential asset for citizens and it is not acceptable that more than half of the European Union's bodies of water are still in poor condition and that the targets have not yet been achieved, mainly due to inadequate funding and particularly slow implementation. Firstly, further action is needed in the field of chemicals and pollutants, in order to improve the quality of water bodies and to reduce risks to human, animal and environmental health. Effective action must be taken against pollutants and there is growing concern about PFAS, microplastics and endocrine disrupters and pharmaceuticals, among other things, from control measures at source. Greater attention should also be paid to the risk of releasing nutrients, chemical fertilizers, pesticides, antibiotics and other pollutants used in agriculture in drainage basins and rivers.  Water pollution is also a serious threat to biodiversity, given the strong negative impact on flora and fauna as well. Finally, I believe that greater transparency on water quality is absolutely useful in guaranteeing European citizens this fundamental right.

name: Benoît BITEAU
text: Madam President, the European Union, in adopting the European Framework Directive in 2000, has had great foresight for this central challenge of the 21st century. The first citizens' initiative on this subject illustrates the conscience of citizens on this issue. Finally, the European Framework Directive affirms that water, a vital resource, belongs to our common heritage, and therefore requires the notion of sharing, respect for the good state of water bodies, an end to derogations and the coherence of public policies. We must be intransigent and demand, for example, the "polluter pays" principle. Water management is actually a problem with the climate challenge. So we need to tackle climate change head-on. The recently passed climate law must be able to help us improve quantitative water management. The Green Pact, the Biodiversity Strategy, the 'Farm to the Range' strategy, which aim for 50% reduction in pesticides, 20% reduction in synthetic fertilisers, 25% of organically grown agricultural land by 2030, should help us to better quality management of the water resource. Agriculture, which mobilizes more than 50% of the freshwater resource, is both a victim of climate change, guilty of climate change, but also a solution to climate change, if accompanied in new directions. Public policies, rather than working hard to address the consequences of agricultural practices culpable by the degradation of water bodies both qualitatively and quantitatively, must, in line with the Green Pact, with contemporary challenges, prefer to address the causes, the roots of the problem by accompanying the transition to agriculture that respects water resources, with a goal of zero pollution. Recovery plan and CAP are not at the rendezvous of these challenges, these issues, these objectives. They are not yet fully validated, so there is still time to achieve these coherences in our public policies. We must have the audacity and the courage to do so.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Water is life. Water is a citizen's right. Water is the responsibility of the State for its citizens in a Member State, but water is also health. We have experienced this and we repeat it in the era of the pandemic, when we constantly say that it is necessary to wash our hands.  Yes, it's all important. It is also important to have an initiative of citizens who make us discuss the directive once again. Only that citizens' initiative and reflection on the old directive do not see what is needed, that is, revision. The revision related, firstly, to the Green Deal, to climate law, to the multiannual financial framework. Because we can say to citizens: Yes, we want water for you, yes, we want availability for you, yes, we want sewerage networks and sanitation for you. But we must be responsible, and we should show that there are resources for this. Because these are huge investments, and we cannot, by the way, lead not only to energy poverty, but to water poverty.  Such concepts already appear in some Member States. All investments make water more expensive in a way that is unacceptable to society. This is our responsibility. We must bear this in mind, we must impose our reflections on the Green Deal, and all that has happened over the last few months is m.in. in the regulation on water reuse.

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, today, thanks to the initiative of millions of European citizens and the work of rapporteur Christophe Hansen and the shadow rapporteurs, we in this Parliament guarantee by law to the citizens of the European Union the right to clean drinking water.  However, we must realize that at this point millions of European citizens do not have access to water at all or have threatened access to poor quality hazardous water. In my country, the city of Pernik has been in a severe water crisis for a year, which I have warned about as early as the end of 2019 this Parliament. The town of Shumen is in a constant shortage of quality drinking water, the third and fourth largest cities in Bulgaria Varna and Burgas are in constant threat of water regime and without quality, edible drinking water.  In Bulgaria alone, it is hundreds of thousands, nearly one million Bulgarian citizens in large cities and hundreds of thousands more in small settlements. Billions of European funds have so far been invested in water and sanitation projects, apparently against the backdrop of huge corruption and without sufficient effect. It is good what we are doing today, but we must also ensure control over it, including the intervention of the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: César LUENA
text: – Madam President, we finally have revised water quality regulations for human consumption, after twenty years, which updates water quality standards with the most up-to-date scientific data, improves consumer information and promotes tap water consumption. But let's not kid ourselves: he's got two big fouls, two big problems.  First, we have again missed the opportunity to recognize water as a universal right. Two million people, from citizens, have asked us to sign the right to water initiative, who asked us to legislate to recognize universal and equitable access to safe and affordable water for all. But it hasn't. It could not have been in this Parliament, by the Conservative groups, and it could not have been in the Council either. But I tell you that access to water should not be promoted, it should not be improved; access to water, as a universal right, must be ensured, guaranteed, recognized.  On the other hand, it is true that the initiative affects the accessibility of water, its safety, its acceptability, but not its affordable. And there is also water poverty, not just energy. Because resources can come, but if there's no money to deal with bills, we have the same problem.  With regard to the Resolution on the Implementation of Water Legislation, I am pleased to know that the gaps that still persisted have disappeared, and is therefore appropriate for the purposes it pursues, making it clear that its revision is not necessary. I'm glad. Now, water is a public good, this sector can no longer be industrialized. We cannot leave the field open to speculators with the rights to use and use water.

name: Martin HOJSÍK
text: – Madam President, they say that water is the oil of the future. Slovakia prides itself on being kuwaiti water, so to speak. Nevertheless, we treat her as if it did not matter. Not only in Slovakia, but across Europe. The Water Framework Directive is 20 years old these days and we have been waiting for 20 years for member states, including Slovakia, to apply it properly. On the one hand, we are talking about water protection, on the other, we are putting it at risk all too often. And yet it's not just about the water as such. We threaten many species of plants, animals and ourselves. Where's the problem? We underestimate the impacts of climate change. We imprison water in concrete, including in Natura 2000 areas. We make it a soup of microplastics full of dangerous chemicals, such as PFAS, which we often do not even measure. There's less of her, and there's less life in it. This sad state is not because we have bad laws. The Water Framework Directive is still up to date and does not need to be amended. Our governments are not really up to it. Precautionary, polluter pays are often ignored and replaced by exemptions for pollution.  I would therefore very much like europeans to be given under... (speaker exceeded time limit)

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Water is a very valuable commodity, and water will become the most valuable asset on earth in the next few years. We should therefore be very sensitive and very careful with this valuable asset. What surprises me, however, is that when we discuss in this House how we regulate access to water and all sorts of things with water in Europe, we must know that we have not been able to provide hot water in our own house for over four years. There has been no hot water here or in the house in Strasbourg for more than four years.  So perhaps we should not interfere in too many things, because access to drinking water is a national competence, and we know that things that can be better regulated at a lower level should also be regulated there. Water supplies throughout Europe are regulated differently, and that is a good thing in many areas. Therefore, we should not do things that are not the same and attack this precious asset very sensitively and with careful hands.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – Mr President, according to the European Environment Agency’s report published in 2018, agriculture is the main cause of groundwater’s failure to achieve a good chemical status in the EU, as it leads to diffuse pollution from nitrates and pesticides. Additionally, the European Nitrogen Assessment states that the total cost of nitrogen pollution in Europe – the majority of which can be linked to animal farming – ranges between EUR 70 million and EUR 320 million annually, yet so far there are no concrete plans how to tackle the issue of water pollution linked to the agriculture sector and in particular to animal farming. I would like to ask a question to the Commission. How is the Commission planning to address the problem of nitrogen emissions linked to animal farming, both in the future CAP and related national strategic plans and in the implementation of the From Farm to Fork Strategy?

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: – Mr President!  The right to water is a fundamental human right. Because without water, there is no life and no sustainable development of society. Therefore, concern for water resources is also an awareness of the importance of intergenerational cooperation and solidarity.  I am proud that four years ago, and symbolically at the same time as the ratification of the Paris Agreement, Slovenia brought the right to drinking water into its constitution. Water resources and access to them were primarily protected as a public good in the governance of the state. As such, they are not goods that can be usurped and marketed.  In view of this political experience, I welcome the Legislative Achievements of the Union. I encourage the Commission and the Member States to make additional efforts to achieve the objectives set out in the European Union legislative framework more consistently, faster and more carefully, including the funds foreseen in this heading in the next Multiannual Financial Framework.  Water resources are also becoming one of the central factors of ensuring international peace and security. Like many other places, we, like the European Union, can only lead by example and not by hypocrisy if we ask others for something that we do not implement on our own.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Member. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Thank you for a very interesting and inspiring debate. I wanted to assure you that not only the official text of the resolution, but also all the voices, comments and suggestions made during this debate, the Commission will undergo a thorough analysis in the course of its further work. This will be done above all by my colleague Commissioner Sinkevičius, who is directly responsible for water management and who, today, because of the need to attend the Council meeting, could not be present at the debate.  I would like to declare that the Commission is making and will make every effort to properly implement the directive that was mentioned today. A number of infringement proceedings are pending and further proceedings will be initiated if necessary. The list of derogations will also be maintained and updated.  I would like to express my satisfaction and thank the High House once again for being able to participate in this debate as Commissioner responsible for agriculture, because many of the voices were on agriculture. I confirm that proper water management in agriculture is of paramount importance and that improving the situation in agriculture is an important part of the whole package of measures aimed at improving water management. I would like to assure you that we are making every effort, in particular, to reform the common agricultural policy, its green architecture, the field-to-table strategy, the protection of biodiversity, but also the structural dialogue that we are already conducting with the Member States in relation to the recommendations in their strategic plans, to include the issue of improving water management and water protection.  This debate and your voices encourage us, and i personally, all the more so to pay even more attention to these issues. I declare that this will happen. I have high hopes for the introduction of green architecture into the common agricultural policy, and I hope that it will contribute to a significant improvement in water quality in the European Union. Once again, thank you for an interesting, really very inspiring debate and for the opportunity to present the Commission's position.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you very much for this debate, because it has also expressed the fact that the institutions of the European Union are pulling together, sometimes at different speeds and with different passions. We owe this to the citizens, also in the knowledge – as has become clear in all the speeches – that water, clean water, is a human right and that it must also be accessible to all people. Of course, as a representative of the Council, I must also stress once again that responsibility for water, for clean water, is a central national competence, and certainly also a regional competence in some Member States. But one thing is also clear: rivers, lakes do not stop at national borders. That is why the European Union's commitment, including in order to provide a secure framework, is of paramount importance, and MePs can always rely on cooperation and constructive cooperation with the Council. A few questions have been asked – and certainly also critical – in the direction of the Council. One of the big questions was: why has all this not been implemented in this way? And why did we rip up the schedules? Firstly, I am also grateful to the Commission, which, as guardian of the Treaties, must always ensure that what we, as the European Union, have jointly decided on, is then implemented in the Member States accordingly. I also have the impression that the Commission is fulfilling its responsibilities here. But why is it so difficult? It is, of course, also so difficult because we are dealing in part with huge investments, and the question of financing has also been raised. And I would like to highlight the outstanding importance of the municipalities. I myself was a local politician for twelve years. We have invested millions in a very small town in the middle of Germany to make the water cleaner through sewage treatment plants. Even then, there were very, very strict requirements from the European Union. There has been a constant debate at the local level about this: why is the directive supposedly being implemented more strictly in Germany than in other countries? And the Commission, and not least the ECJ, naturally play a central role here. But community engagement is very, very outstanding. And how can this be better financed? Of course, we also need a dialogue, also on the ground, about new sources of funding – public, but certainly also private, when it comes to the responsibility of the economy. However, I would also like to emphasise once again that we have successful funds at European level, in particular the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, but also the Cohesion Fund, which supports the Member States, but also the regions and local leaders, in ensuring that we are better able to meet the common objective. Finally, I would like to make a second point, because I also have the impression that we are pulling together. It is that we make the objective of ensuring clean water everywhere a task of all policy areas. I have already explained in my opening statement that 33 per cent of water consumption has something to do with agriculture, as the Commissioner has just emphasised. We also know that there are two important instruments, particularly through cross-compliance, but also through rural funding, that will help us achieve sustainable growth in agriculture. And when we talk about sustainability, clean water and access to water naturally play a very central role. And it is precisely during our Presidency that we have once again emphasised – also through initiatives – that it is necessary to reduce the environmental and climatic footprint of the current agricultural system, including the food system, in the European Union, because we are aware of the limits of stress, and we are aware of shared responsibility, especially for clean water. Thank you for this debate, and thank you for the opportunity to take part in this. And I hope that, in the coming years, we will perhaps be able to live up to our common goal even more quickly and more decisively, because that is also the responsibility we have towards our citizens in all the Member States of the European Union. European Union. And above all, as a encourager at the global level – as some Members have also impressively pointed out – we too must show – as a region of prosperity, social stability and economic success with a strong industrial sector and still strong agriculture – that clean water and access to clean water are an essential element of prosperity and security. , not only in Europe, but throughout the world.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. I would like to inform you that, with regard to Mr Hansen's report, no proposal to reject the Council's position and no amendments have been tabled in accordance with Articles 67 and 68. The proposed act is therefore deemed to have been adopted. The vote on the amendments to the motion for a resolution on the implementation of EU water legislation will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 16 December 2020. The final vote will take place on Thursday, 17 December 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The agreement on drinking water quality is an important achievement. In its new form, the directive concerns not only water safety, but also access to water – a trivial issue, especially in the context of climate change. It introduces concrete solutions to reconcile and combine the two objectives. Regulations on risk analysis, materials used, parameters of harmful substances take into account new realities and risks. The emphasis on providing tap water and admoniating access to water for disadvantaged groups should be appreciated.  However, when analysing the various solutions through the lens of the second document discussed today on the implementation of EU water legislation, one can ask whether, going in the right direction, we are not going too far: whether, by pushing ideologically correct solutions, we do not underestimate the realities and costs – both direct and long-term economic and social costs.  Ensuring access to safe drinking water is paramount, as is environmental concern. However, its implementation must take into account the needs of the economy, especially agriculture, which will bear the costs of excessively restrictive rules.  The question must therefore be asked, how will the various regulations affect the functioning of agriculture and industry?

name: Joanna KOPCIŃSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – According to a report by the European Environment Agency (issue 7/2018 entitled 'European waters – Assessment of status and pressures 2018'), only 40% of all surface water in Europe is in good condition or has adequate ecological potential, and only 38% is characterised by a sustainable chemical status. I welcome the intensive efforts of the EU Member States to improve water status and meet the high requirements of EU water legislation. However, it should be emphasised that the system of indicators for achieving environmental objectives proposed by the European Parliament should accurately reflect real progress in improving surface water quality and ensure a broader understanding of certain definitions taking into account the biodiversity and natural transformation of the ecosystem in line with the 'one-out all-out' principle and its key importance, which unfortunately does not reflect these developments. With regard to the provisions on perfluoorated unions, we should take a prudent approach in order not to exclude all compounds commonly used in many key industries.  I also believe that, in order to bridge water quality disparities in different areas, EU funds should be used appropriately not only for the implementation of new investments, but also for the maintenance of existing installations, in line with environmental objectives and for the sake of sustainable economic development financed in a tailor-made manner.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. " We are talking about a very important issue of the quality of water intended for human consumption, which affects every person. The proposed directive is another step by the EC, following the plastics directive, in order to achieve health safety and a safe environment. The revision of the Directive was not only caused by technological progress, but also by the first EU citizens' initiative, the 'Right to Water'. Access to safe water is a fundamental human right and is also one of the United Nations development goals. It is unacceptable that not everyone in Europe has access to good quality water. The EU must therefore promote the supply of free, good quality water in public places, perhaps even in every area. This is what the people of Europe want, and that is what they have expressed in their citizens' initiative. People's well-being must always be our priority, and safe drinking water is our main goal. Eu water is a high standard, but new pollutants, consumer protection and the need to keep up with environmental changes must be taken into account. It is therefore good that 18 new governance parameters have emerged in the Directive. Mandatory analysis and risk management are also important. We must also be vigilant about microplastics, which are becoming the greatest threat to the quality and safety of drinking water. Citizens must have full confidence in the quality of water. We should remember the need to protect drinking water sources and, therefore, to reduce pollution caused by industry and non-organic human behaviour.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: Writing. "We live in a world where we see water as an unlimited resource. However, this is not the case. That is why I consider today's debate on water legislation and the subsequent vote to be extremely important. The lack of drinking water is a constant problem on many continents, but also in Europe, with production areas drying up, water bases polluting and water supply dwindling, causing irreversible damage to our society. Furthermore, water-related problems are perhaps one of the greatest threats to economic and sustainable development. It is very important to recognise that water is essential for the citizens of the Union and, in the light of climate change and environmental degradation, water pollution management, reducing the narrowing of freshwater biodiversity and strengthening resilience to the effects of climate change are more relevant than ever, and access to drinking water of sufficient quality is of paramount importance in terms of reducing risks to the health of the population. The time has come, then, to see the source of our common future. Water is the source of our lives, let us treat it responsibly and with respect.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Elsi Katainen on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council with transitional provisions for support from the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EEER) and the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EChrA) in 2021, on the amendment of Regulations (EU) No 228/2013, (EU) No 229/2013 and (EU) No. 1308/2013 on the appropriations and their allocation in 2021 and on the amendment of Regulations (EU) No 1305/2013, (EU) No 1306/2013 and (EU) No 1307/2013 with regard to their resources and their applicability in 2021 (COM(2019)0581 – C9-0162/2019 - 2019/0254 (COD)) (A9-0101/2020). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches and no blue cards accepted in all the debates in this part-session. It also provides for interconnection from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are facing a crucial vote for farmers, agriculture and security of supply for the whole of Europe. We will be voting on legislation that will use about a third of EU funds in the next two years. We are also mobilising EUR 8 billion in recovery money, because the coronavirus is chastising the food chain right now and not next year. The outcome of the negotiations shows that Europeans value local food, security of supply and safe and high-quality food. I am proud that, in exceptional circumstances, we will be able to find a common solution in the content of the legislation, within the timeframe. We will continue for the next two years with the current rules of agricultural policy and ensure the continuity of national subsidies that are important to farmers. At the same time, we will ensure that more is done on climate and environmental issues. We are also responding to the shock caused by the coronavirus by facilitating state aid rules and the use of agricultural risk management mechanisms. The most important thing is that farmers will be assured of what is to come for the next two years, and the transitional period proposed by the Commission, which has proved to be too short for one year, will not take place. This will continue rural development programmes and ensure continuity for farmers. Now farmers and administration will have sufficient time to prepare and prepare for the changes brought about by the new programming period starting in 2023. The reform of the common agricultural policy will then enter into force, which will significantly revolutionise the rules and structures of the aid policy. I think it is important that the finalisation of the reform be carried out carefully, and now, within this transitional period, there is enough time for it. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the negotiators from all the groups for their excellent cooperation in this challenging work, where there have also been challenges along the year-long journey. Cooperation has been really smooth with everyone, and without a good team spirit we would not have achieved such a good result. I would also like to thank the recovery negotiator, Paolo De Castro, and his team for getting the recovery money linked to this legislation. Thanks are also due to the Croatian and German Council for its constructive cooperation and flexibility. I would also like to thank the Commission for its help in mediating the negotiations. Only together will we be able to bring the necessary stability and legal certainty to the agricultural sector. Ladies and gentlemen, this legislation will be a reality for every European in just over two weeks' time. By accepting the outcome of the negotiations, we will ensure that the subsidies that are important to European farmers continue within the agreed timeframe and that the operating environment in the entire agricultural sector is strengthened.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the co-legislators for their constructive attitude and effective cooperation during the legislative procedures concerning the CAP transitional regulation. I’m happy to see that we are now reaching the finishing line. Thank you very much to the rapporteur, Ms Katainen, to the shadow rapporteurs; thank you to the Council, to the German Presidency, for the very constructive dialogue and cooperation. The position which is about to be adopted today is key for providing certainty to farmers and other common agricultural policy beneficiaries in the years 2021 and 2022.
