I’m delighted to see that despite the difficulties caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, we were all able to combine two processes – the transitional rules and the integration of the additional allocations proposed under the European Union Recovery Instrument – into the rural development programmes. Today this plenary will vote on the merged outcome. It is a great achievement that the combination of two procedures did not hamper the quick adoption of the transitional regulation. The transitional regulation will include key elements that were brought forward by the European Parliament, such as the continuation of phasing out payments for areas with natural constraints which no longer qualify as such following the new elimination under Regulation (EU) No 1305/2013; the possibility for Member States to support more easily risk management measures; increasing technical assistance funding for certain smaller Member States in order to prepare for the new common agricultural policy and the continuation of the transitional national aid and the Finnish national aid. I’ve also pledged that the EU Recovery Instrument Funds to be distributed under the rural development programmes will mostly be used for measures that ensure a recovery beneficial for the environment and climate and to help our farming and rural communities to be more resilient and recover from the effects of the pandemic. Moreover, I am glad that all institutions managed to arrive at a satisfactory outcome on the funding of the support programmes for the outermost regions and the smaller Aegean islands. The text presented for the vote is a balanced text that will allow farmers and citizens and businesses in rural areas to continue in 2021 and 2022 to benefit from income support, from tools for market stability and from support for investments, cooperation measures beneficial to the environment, as well as from the other structural measures. This will be key for the recovery of the European economy and rural areas.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Two years of transition is, of course, not a good thing. It would have been better if we had succeeded in reforming the common agricultural policy and starting it with the reform in a few days' time. However, this is not the case, and I think that, in the present circumstances, this is a good regulation – a regulation that also gives farmers legal certainty, because they know that European Union funding will continue to be guaranteed in the coming years. However, I am particularly pleased that the EUR 7.5 billion from NextGenerationEU has been incorporated into this regulation. I think it is particularly important that this money can be used over the next two years and not from 2023, as originally planned by the Commission. That would have made little sense to use COVID money from 2023 onwards. That is why I believe that, overall, it is a good regulation – a regulation that we can also agree to – and I would like to thank all those involved in the work most warmly.

name: Álvaro AMARO
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the next two transitional years between the current and the future Common Agricultural Policy will be decisive in preparing the sector for what will be a common agricultural policy with more ambitious targets, with more ambitious environmental targets.  In this regulation which we are voting on today, it is fair to point out that important measures have been achieved, for example those relating to the wine sector and the olive oil sector. But we must also say that others have been able to reach. I am referring in particular to internal convergence and external convergence which, although interrupted during the transition, I believe are elementary justice for European farmers. I would also like to highlight the agreement on the Recovery Fund introduced in this regulation. This more investment-oriented support that enhances the resilience of the sector is crucial if it is to be more robust and better prepared for the ecological transition that will be required of it.  And with regard to POSEI, the agreement reached was, after all, positive.  I am sure to say that I expected more solidarity from the Council and the Commission with these fellow European citizens who, in the outermost regions of our Union, suffer extraordinary constraints. It is an issue for which I ask for the utmost commitment during the negotiations on the cap reform and which I will of course continue to follow up on. In conclusion, we are pleased to have ensured that this regulation has not become an anticipation of the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy, but a continuity system with the necessary adjustments. Farmers now know what they are counting on over the next two years and will be able to maintain their European funding without any cuts in payments. I would therefore like to greet all my colleagues and, of course, our rapporteur for the good work that has been done in the name of European agriculture.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, after weeks of waiting, the difficult agreement reached by the European Council last week finally gives us the opportunity to deliver on our commitments to our farmers, producers and rural areas. Not only legal certainty and the possibility of better planning one's business choices thanks to the two-year extension of the current agricultural policy, but also, and above all, an unprecedented injection of liquidity to deal with the devastating consequences of the pandemic. Thanks to the European Recovery Instrument, we are ready to release over EUR 8 billion for rural development as early as January 2021. A support package that must be made available as soon as possible by the Member States, so that it can really pave the way for economic recovery in the name of resilience, sustainability and digitalisation, and in line with the objectives outlined in the Green Deal. And it is thanks to the ambitious position supported by all the groups in the Committee on Agriculture in this Parliament that we have managed to prevent these funds from funding business as usual. For this reason, at least 55 % of the more than 8 billion will be allocated to young people, to small farmers, and above all to investments that promote the social and economic development of rural areas, pursuing essential objectives for an increasingly sustainable agriculture, such as the digitisation and modernisation of productive instruments, better safety conditions at work, short supply chains, renewable energies and the circular economy. However, in order for the recovery of the sector to effectively balance environmental, social and economic sustainability, at least 37 % of the funds will be allocated to measures with high environmental added value, such as organic farming, the reduction of agricultural greenhouse gas emissions, soil conservation, improved water management and animal welfare. Once again, the European Parliament has shown itself to be the driving force behind the legislative process, so let me thank the entire negotiating team, the shadow rapporteurs who have worked in recent weeks to reach an agreement on Next Generation EU for rural development. When the three institutions, Commissioner, decide to work side by side with the same objective, fundamental results can be achieved, especially for a sector that, even in the most difficult moments of the pandemic, has never backed down, continuing to guarantee the food that arrives every day on our tables.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Today we are discussing an important dossier: the transitional rules for agriculture. I would really like to thank all those who have worked hard to adopt this dossier at this time. I congratulate our Renew rapporteur for the good work she has done. We have followed the guiding principle: old rules – fresh money. And I think we really need that urgently. As we are currently in the negotiations on the common agricultural policy, we did not want to reintegrate an additional system. The aim for all of us was to ensure that our farmers get legal certainty on time for the next two years. Hopefully we will achieve that. I believe that the most important achievements are the extension of the duration to two years, the multiannual commitments on agricultural, environmental and bio-measures, national transitional aid and also the extension of COVID measures, to name but a few. I would like to say a few words about the operational programmes: in the fruit and vegetable sector, where the programmes are now open for five years, we can extend the programmes which have not yet reached the end of the period until 31 December 2022. The same applies to the beekeeping sector. I think that is a good signal. Despite adverse working conditions due to the COVID pandemic, solid results were achieved. I am also pleased that we can make the unused second pillar funds available for another year in the area of aid. In the time limit for the conclusion of the transitional arrangements, this will enable us, as the CAP negotiating team, to continue to work diligently and to make informed decisions. I believe that the national administrations also need this necessary time. Today we will be sending a clear signal to our farmers that they can rely on the European Union even in times of crisis.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, European agriculture is a wealth that we must preserve not only for economic reasons, but also for cultural reasons, because it has largely shaped our landscapes and our way of life. In this very trying time we are going through, it needs stability and security first and foremost. That is why I approve the regulation, which sets out transitional provisions for the Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. This regulation has the immense merit in my view to extend for two years the aid that farmers are entitled to rely on. I am delighted, along with my colleague Maxette Pirbakas, that the interests of our overseas farmers have been preserved. This two-year transitional period will also allow - second merit - to give States sufficient time to develop their national strategic plans, which I think is the most interesting innovation of the new CAP. I am more circumspect about the agricultural part of the stimulus package. I agree with many of its objectives, particularly those of promoting short circuits, financing the modernization of agricultural machinery and helping young farmers settle down. But I do not understand why at least 37% of the money should be earmarked for environmental actions. We should not have lost sight of the fact that the objective of the stimulus package was to promote economic recovery and not to ensure the protection of the environment, which is already the subject of the Green Pact. I regret, on the other hand, that the EUR 8 billion of this plan is not enough to compensate for the reduction in the CAP budget. Finally, I want to denounce the double play of the European Union which, on the one hand, helps European agriculture, but on the other, betrays it by negotiating free trade treaties of which it is the adjustment variable.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, last week the European Council reached an agreement for a new 2030 EU target for a net domestic reduction of at least 55% in greenhouse gas emissions. While it is not in line with the latest scientific knowledge and can hardly be seen as satisfying, it is still a challenge for the EU and a step towards climate neutrality. According to the communication on the From Farm to Fork Strategy, agriculture is responsible for more than 10% of the EU’s GHG emissions, and nearly 70% of those come from the animal sector. There’s no doubt that, with the CAP reform still under negotiation, a transitional regulation has to be put in place. However, we have to make sure that those two years are not wasted ones if it comes to the EU climate and environmental targets, including the ones regarding improvement of animal welfare. What is the Commission planning to do in order to use that transitional period as the time to prepare for higher ambitions in the next CAP?

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, this Transitional Regulation is an important achievement because, as we are in this pandemic, we have been able to give legal certainty to farmers so that they can continue to collect CAP aid during 2021 and 2022, until the entry into force of the new CAP in January 2023.  In the second part of the trilogs we have also achieved something very important, and it has been to incorporate the 8 billion of the Recovery Fund into the Transitional Regulation.  Finally, the transition will take two years. It is a pity that the European Commission insisted throughout the negotiation process that this transition period should only be one year, when it was obvious that the desirable minimum was two years. This may be anecdotal, but it denotes a very partial view of agricultural reality.  Finally, I would like to highlight the achievements for the wine, fruit and vegetables sector, which will enjoy greater flexibility in the single CMO, and – also and very importantly – the maintenance of funds for the outermost regions.  I would not like to end without thanking the rapporteur, Mrs Katainen, all her team and all those who have made it possible to bring this Transitional Regulation to fruition.

name: Petros KOKKALIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, it is time to vote on the crucial transitional regulation of the Common Agricultural Policy, in order to give farmers, small and medium-sized enterprises in the agri-food sector and rural areas of Europe the security and stability they need and deserve. Today we are ensuring the current support framework for the next two years, and indeed strengthened. We are incorporating the Resources of the Recovery Fund for 2021 and 2022 into the Rural Development Programmes to support the green and digital transition of the agri-food sector with an emphasis on young farmers. We continue to support farmers and small and medium-sized enterprises in the sector affected by the pandemic. We maintain an increased budget for the small Aegean islands and introduce necessary arrangements to support olive oil and table olives, fruit and vegetables and viticulture.  Above all, however, with today's vote we are giving the time for the effective preparation of the national strategic plans of the CFP after 2022, while demanding real open consultation with all, involving everyone on the road to the transition to 2030 and 2050.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have the opportunity and the obligation to stand by the most economically vulnerable to the climate crisis, who are no more than farmers. And that means: decent income, a new resilient and fair model of production and consumption, quality healthy and sustainable food for citizens, measures to reduce biodiversity and finally attractive, vibrant, thriving rural areas.

name: Dino GIARRUSSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is important to highlight today the European commitment to continue to help farmers in 2021 and 2022, giving them legal certainty.  Thanks to the transitional regulation, we will allow beneficiaries to have a gradual transition to the programmes outlined by the new CAP and ensure compliance with the Green Deal, i.e. transition to organic farming, phasing out pesticides and greater attention to the environment. The protection of farmers and the environment will be central, the Member States will have to spend 37 % of the additional funds on greening measures or on the protection of animal welfare and 55 % on measures for digital and social transformation. It will be possible to continue to use the crisis measures introduced with Covid for a further six months from the entry into force of the transitional regulation – an important aid. Finally, we welcome the agreement which will make it possible to include aid measures for the storage and sale of olive oil. It is necessary to improve and stabilize the functioning of the common market in olive oils and olives from which they are obtained. We hope that this will be a first step towards greater protection of quality European oils and a brake on wild and ill-regulated imports, which harm olive growers and consumers.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The continuation of the current regulations is right and good – true to the motto "Old rules - fresh money". At last, our farmers have legal and planning security for the next two years. The fact that the money from the Building Fund has been included in the transitional regulation and will be available as early as 2021 is also an important signal to European agriculture. In the Corona crisis, the sector ensured that we all have enough to eat on the table. The new figures from the World Food Organisation show that this is not self-evident, that we are slipping from a global health crisis into a food crisis.  Contrary to what some Members of this House wanted, farmers do not have to deal with new regulations for the next two years. Ensuring food supply and re-setting their operating structures can be at the heart of their work. I would like to thank all my fellow Members, in particular Mrs Katainen and Mr De Castro, for their great work in getting this transitional regulation through and for being able to enter into force in good time.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all on behalf of my group and on my behalf, I would like to thank Mrs Katainen and the entire negotiating group, in which I am on behalf of my group, and the technicians who have accompanied us. I sincerely believe that we have done a great job for the end result.  The political agreement reached after the trilogos provides European farmers and ranchers, during 2021 and 2022, with guarantees of implementation of the current CAP rules, and will therefore continue to receive the direct aid from the first pillar and will continue the rural development programmes of the second pillar, which are very important elements for the legal certainty of these aids.  There are a number of essential elements that we have pushed from the European Parliament to deal with this transitional period. And I sincerely believe that we have made improvements from Parliament.  Firstly, from the outing point of time, from Parliament, we understood that the time required for this transitoryness was two years — and not one, as the Commission said, to be able to close the reform debate and properly carry out the development of the new strategic plans, giving legal certainty to this compromise.  Secondly, we condition our final support on the adoption of the new Multiannual Financial Framework. That's why we're in the latter house. Because we did not want to approve the Transitional Regulation without the multiannual financial framework being approved and we did not want to accept, first of all, the proposal for measures in the Commission's budget.  New proposals have also been incorporated into this Regulation throughout the process, as a legal instrument: COVID measures to address the situation created by the pandemic, the extension of rural development aid, measures on wine planting rights, which OPFH can continue with their operational programmes without changing them if they are not necessary , or the funding part of the Next Generation programme for rural development, to which my colleague Paolo De Castro referred, to which I congratulate him.  There are also some issues that we have defended, such as the advancement of a measure of CAP reform, which is the self-regulation of the olive oil sector, and of course not admitting the cutting of the... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Jérémy DECERLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, many of us this morning welcome the very good work that has enabled the adoption of this transitional regulation, particularly in this Parliament. I am fully involved in it.  Some , and I am one of them - would have liked, at the beginning of this process, that we would have given ourselves a little more ambition by seeking from this transition phase to plant some milestones for the future CAP. The majority did not want it and we did so only marginally. Nevertheless, I welcome the solidity of the work carried out and the safety that this regulation will bring to farmers for the next two years, two years which will obviously be necessary to finish preparing the future CAP.  I also welcome the inclusion in this regulation of the agricultural version of the recovery plan, building on the current architecture, but with the support for the most relevant measures: support for young farmers, investments, without weakening on the CAP's environmental ambition.  Finally, I welcome the tenacity of the negotiators, who have helped to preserve a level of support that is essential to the POSEI programme, which was threatened by a weakening that would have severely penalised the outermost regions concerned.  The farmers, the legislators that we are, the Member States are now in a serene position to finish work on the next CAP. We will be able to take the time to properly defend the positions of this Parliament in a trilogue.

name: Maxette PIRBAKAS
text: Mr President, I wanted today to speak on the transition fund for the year 2021. I am pleased to see that our institution - the European Parliament - and all the European institutions have reached a compromise agreement to maintain THE POSEI, the programme of options specific to remoteness and insularity.  I also welcome this victory for ultramarine agriculture, for the thousands of direct and indirect jobs that depend on it, as well as for all the sectors that work with agriculture. Our French overseas departments of Guadeloupe, Martinique, Reunion, Guyana and Mayotte needed more than that.  Now, I would like to warn this House that the co-financing agreement to maintain the annual FIT for the next two years will have to be maintained after that. And we will have to do it together, ladies and gentlemen. Let us not forget that thousands of jobs, families and farmers in the five overseas departments depend on this vital aid to us, the islands. The co-financing of the POSEI budget between the Member States of the European Union and its supplementary budget must guarantee us this fund, which helps us to finance every agricultural sector such as sugar cane, banana, diversification, livestock, agri-processing.  Europe must support the outermost regions, which are insular and far from the European continent. Colleagues, I count on your much-needed support in two years' time on this issue. Otherwise, we will no longer be able to develop our agriculture in the five ultramarine departments.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to begin by expressing my satisfaction that Parliament, the Commission and the Council have managed to negotiate transitional arrangements for agricultural funds for two years. In this way, European farmers receive a longer period of stability and legal certainty, and will operate in well-known administrative and financial realities.  I am convinced that this two-year period will also make good use of the Member States by preparing robust strategic plans, consulted with their farmers, which will create the conditions for the development of European agriculture in the years to come. We owe It to European farmers to create these good conditions for development. After all, during a difficult period of pandemics, they have provided food security to nearly 500 million consumers and they want to continue to do so. I would also like to express my hope that, as part of the next multiannual budget, we will finally bring about the situation that rural infrastructure will be built from regional development funds and not from the second pillar of the CAP.  Finally, I would like to thank Commissioner Wojciechowski for the fact that, thanks to his personal involvement, the Reconstruction Fund has managed to raise an additional amount of almost EUR 8 billion for European agriculture and that this money will go to farmers in the next two years.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Before giving the floor to Mr Bompard, I would like to open the first round of voting today.  The dossiers on which we are now voting can be found on the agenda. The voting round is open from 11 a.m. to 12.15 p.m. The same voting procedure will apply as in the previous voting session. All votes are taken by roll call. I declare the first round of voting open. You can vote until 12.15 p.m. The results of the first round of voting will be announced at 2.45 p.m.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We are now continuing our debate on the report by Elsi Katainen (A9-0101/2020).

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Mr President, a few days ago, a scientific study published by the European Parliament showed that agricultural practices were incompatible with the objectives of the Green Pact for Europe. However, you are proposing, with this transitional regulation, to extend the same policy for two years without any change or new direction. EUR 111 billion, or one tenth of the EU budget, will be wasted again.  Worse still, the Common Agricultural Policy that will come into force in 2023 will exacerbate this trend. Scientific studies are multiplying to say it, but you remain deaf. Tens of thousands of citizens are mobilizing through the youth climate petition, but you remain deaf. How many ecological disasters, farmer suicides, farm closures or extinct species will it take for you to finally respond?  Be up to the climate emergency: remove these bad projects and take advantage of the two-year transition to pave the way for an agricultural and food policy that respects humans, the planet and animals.

name: Daniela RONDINELLI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, after months of negotiations, European farmers finally have the legal and financial certainty they need with this regulation in order to continue their business and invest in the green. In this way, farmers will be able to defend the European agricultural system and work now to achieve the ambitious environmental objectives that we have set ourselves with the Green New Deal.  I believe that there are three key aspects of this agreement: the imposition of clear environmental and social objectives, linked to the allocation of additional resources; the use of the crisis reserve fund, even during the transitional period, to buffer the economic and social effects of the pandemic and the special attention paid to the marketing of olive oil within the framework of the common organisation of the market, which will make it possible to better protect its production.  This agreement is a good route for the ongoing negotiations on the new CAP, the largest European production sector will be able to innovate and transform, but at the same time safeguarding the centrality of the active farmer and the continuous search for quality, wholesomeness and sustainability of production for the well-being of all European citizens.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the transitional regulation is a necessary legislative instrument to ensure the continuity of the CAP and, at the same time, to prevent major imbalances in the agricultural sector. Farmers need certainty for their investments, and this regulation provides them with the tools to make a smooth transition to the new common agricultural policy.  At the same time, the Regulation provides farmers with the necessary funding to deal with the current pandemic problems, thereby preserving their ability to produce quality and affordable food for consumers. An important aspect is to ensure flexibility between the two pillars, which allows Member States to transfer funds for direct payments with those for rural development.  Although the Commission did not initially include the continuation of transitional national aid in its proposal, we were able to add this form of support to the Regulation. There are eight Member States using this aid mechanism to help ensure the sustainability of farmers.  I note that SUPPORT through the ANT is provided by the Member States concerned and does not create additional burdens for the European Union budget. Moreover, it is a form of complementary aid, which does not have the capacity to distort the single market. On the other hand, it was absolutely necessary to introduce the ANT into this regulation in order to ensure continuity in the future CAP. In the absence of a horizon on achieving full external convergence, I believe that this support must be continued in the future common agricultural policy.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with today's vote we are remedying a number of problems that would certainly have resulted from the delay in approving the new CAP reform, and we have, I believe, reached an excellent agreement with the Council, and so we are able to bring stability to the activities of our farmers for the next two years. At the same time, we also approve eu next generation aid for rural development.  All this is a real breath of oxygen for our farmers and for the entire supply chain which, in these complicated and difficult months, have nevertheless been able to guarantee safe and healthy food on the tables of European citizens. The EUR 8 billion that we have been able to bring forward in part as early as next year – thanks to the work of this Parliament, I would like to stress – will be an important instrument for restarting the sector, including those with respect for the environment, because at least 37 % of the resources will have to be allocated to environmental measures and with an eye to young farmers with extraordinary measures dedicated to them.

name: Asger CHRISTENSEN
text: Madam President! Thank you to the Commissioner for being here. Thank you very much for getting the transition proposal through and ensuring stability for my colleagues throughout Europe. It's also about food safety. It's the best Christmas present we can give our farmers, this particular security. They have fought really hard during the pandemic to ensure good and healthy food. We have to thank them very much for that. I'm really looking forward to 2021. We need to work on a long-term strategy from farm to fork. This is a very ambitious strategy. It lays the trail for the green transformation of EU food production. I see the possibility of the agricultural sector. We are the sector that has been most affected by climate change, but we are also the sector that allows for the green transition. We must work to ensure that our farmers can store more CO2 in the soil. We must help our consumers to make the sustainable and climate-friendly choices when they are at the cooling counter. It is about our consumers having the right choice. Merry Christmas and Happy New Year to all my colleagues in the European Union.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, If agriculture and horticulture is in need of anything at the moment, it is stability and certainty, especially in these uncertain coronary times. The fact that we are now extending the current agricultural policy by two years is therefore a very good thing. On the positive side, the additional resources in the second pillar will be available as early as 2021 and 2022 and that we are paying extra attention to young farmers.  What's in front is a good package. I wholeheartedly agree with that. However, I would like to take it a little further today, because I note that the Commission, particularly in the first pillar, is currently missing some opportunities. I am referring to the various crisis instruments in market and price policy, which the Commission has hardly used in 2020 despite the major problems in the market. My question is therefore to the Commissioner: should we not start using the special market measures in the first pillar more actively, especially in view of the uncertainties surrounding Brexit and the corona problem? In this corona crisis, farmers are once again showing that we can count on them for our food production. They must also be able to count on us!

name: Juan Ignacio ZOIDO ÁLVAREZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the agri-food sector has been living in uncertainty since March because of the coronavirus — transport problems, temporary operators who could not cross the border, hospitality forced to close, national aid which did not reach, etc.- all coupled with the big questions it faced outside the pandemic, such as the impact of Brexit Trump's tariffs or increasingly restrictive environmental legislation.  That is why, today, this Parliament intends to bring certainty and confidence in the future with the adoption of the Transitional Regulation: by 2023, European farmers and ranchers will have their CAP funds secured with the same rules they had so far.  In addition, we accelerate the granting of the additional EUR 7.5 billion from the Recovery Fund for rural areas, because Europe cannot afford to leave anyone behind.  We also include a fundamental change with Article 167a, which will allow the regulation of the supply of olive oil in crisis situations – a historical demand of the sector in Spain, and in Andalusia in particular – and provides certainty in planting authorisations for the wine sector.  And finally, we managed to avoid the serious cut that some intended for the POSEI financial statement, a measure of justice to protect agriculture from outermost regions such as the Canary Islands.  In short, with this Regulation we bring a little calm in the middle of the storm, but we will continue to work to improve its future in the following years.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: – Mr President, after a year of multiple uncertainties and fears, the European Parliament's vote on the transitional regulation is exactly the breath of fresh air that the farmer needed. Because he now knows that, by 2023, when it is implemented in the new CAP reform, it will receive its subsidies, continue its investments and allow it to prepare for the green revolution in agriculture. This regulation is also revolutionary, bringing news such as doubling premiums for the installation of the young farmer, from 50 to 100 thousand euros, or supplementing the agricultural budget with money from the recovery and resilience fund, aid available as early as 1 January 2021 and financed 100% of European money.  In addition, the extension of the transitional national aid essential to some states, including Romania, was approved. I therefore thank my colleagues who have restored hope to our farmers through their work on these dossiers.

name: Atidzhe ALIEVA-VELI
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, I believe that transitional CAP legislation and the Recovery Plan will ensure a smooth transition for European farmers towards modern and environmentally friendly agriculture, while also helping to restore the individual subsectors from the consequences of the Kovid pandemic.  It is important to note that the two-year transition period proposed by the European Parliament brings predictability in terms of investments in agricultural holdings. Preserving the budget, preserving the structure and rules enable farmers to prepare for e-schemes, digitisation and innovation. The transition provides legal and regulatory certainty, stability and financial continuity, support for recovery in times of serious crisis and pressure on the food chain.

name: Krzysztof JURGIEL
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. A regulation on the transitional provisions of the common agricultural policy is necessary to ensure the continuation of this policy before the entry into force of the new common agricultural policy. Although Parliament's success is to extend the transitional period to two years and to include the reconstruction instrument in the legislative text, the regulation, in my opinion, sets an overly ambitious environmental target, as it provides that as much as 37% of the post-crisis reconstruction funding is to be earmarked for environmental purposes.  Furthermore, at the last stage of the trilogue negotiations, the German Presidency of the Council added to the text of that regulation a recital relating to the provisions on the general conditionality system for the protection of the Union budget. The reference to the conditionality system may in future link payments to Member States with their fulfilment of additional criteria which do not arise from existing law and are contrary to the Treaties. In the case of farmers, the European Union infringes the principle of non-discrimination on grounds of nationality.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, in this transitional regulation, the european Parliament's contribution has been essential to bring stability and legal certainty to our farmers in uncertain times. We have secured a two-year transition, which will allow us to finalise the negotiation of the future CAP with serenity and seriousness. But that is not all, because we have also secured the reform of a series of tools that will accompany our farmers to deal with the vagaries and crises that can hit them. I am thinking in particular of the revision of risk management tools and the introduction of an exemption from the state aid, savings and precautionary schemes. Finally, we secured the maintenance of the CISI budget, which was no small matter. As part of this regulation, we have also integrated the European agricultural recovery plan. That is almost eight billion euros over two years that will be available to revive the economic activity of our sectors and our rural territories. I am pleased to have been able to secure that more than half of the funds are focused on sustainable and digital investments and youth settlement. One regret, however, is that Parliament's will to reform the crisis reserve has once again been rejected by the Council and the Commission. In the event of a severe crisis in the next two years, the Council and the Commission will therefore bear a great deal of responsibility.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mrs Sander. Mr Jurgiel, we are making every effort to comply with the hygiene rules. The whole house is fighting to keep us open. I was dismayed to see – I mean, this is a polite expression, and I am very happy to do so – that you welcomed the Commissioner and his cabinet with a handshake. I hereby call you in all forms to order. I will suggest to the President that we will no longer give you the floor if the same happens again. We all have to make a little effort. Maybe it was thoughtlessness, then I apologise for it, then you get away with the call for order. But if it's intentional ... So, we have a Bureau meeting tomorrow evening, I will tell the President that we will not tolerate these practices here when the whole House is struggling, that we are maintaining Parliament's operation and keeping Parliament open.

name: Stéphane BIJOUX
text: Mr President, dear friends, one of our commitments here is to leave no one on the side of the road. To say so is good, but when we do, it is better, especially when it comes to defending and protecting the men and women who work in difficult conditions in our remote territories, in our overseas territories.  For the outermost regions, negotiations have been difficult. I want to tell you that we have sometimes doubted our common desire to respect the specifics of the UPRs. I want to warn you of the sense of abandonment that could devastate the hearts of our planters and herders.  Our farming world is courageous and we are proud of our local production. Of course, as usual, we heard earlier the speech of completely unjustified complacency of the extreme right. Everyone knows exactly who did what, and I want to thank the pro-European Members, our rapporteur and the French government, who have invested a lot in the POSEI issue.  A transitional solution has been found. There is still work to be done to consolidate this arrangement. Be sure that, from farm to fork, the green pact road also passes through the Overseas.

name: Marlene MORTLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. For us it is really only a formality today, for our farmers it is the main thing that they finally have planning security for their families and for their farms. Food will not fall from the sky in the future– except in crisis and war zones. It is precisely for this reason that, after the war, the EU committed itself to ensuring that our citizens are adequately supplied with local food. Agriculture is not the stupid docusoap "Bauer sucht Frau" (Bauer sucht Frau), which we know from Germany. Agriculture also does not mean working with ox and wood plough in the future. In the future, agriculture means producing in a resource-saving manner for more and more people, i.e. using state-of-the-art technology. So agriculture is not just a profession, it is a vocation. I would therefore like to thank all the Colleagues who have helped to ensure that we can adopt this two-year transitional period today. I would like to thank all the farmers who have so far ensured that we produce the safest, the best and most diverse foods in Europe. But we should not put our own political ego above our personal purchasing and consumption behaviour. In other words, the CAP of the future, but also the farm to fork strategy ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Mr President, I very much welcome this debate and particularly the issue around the transition regulation, which will give certainty to farmers in these very challenging times.  What we need to do now is to ensure that, over the next two years, while we’re going through this transitional arrangement, we use creativity and imagination to ensure that the next common agricultural policy (CAP) proposals give farmers the opportunity to farm in a way that is compatible with the environment and, equally, that they have a future in family farms across Europe. We have to look at some form of flexibility and a performance—related model. We can’t straitjacket our farmers across the entire continent to one system. So I would urge the Commission, the Parliament and the Council, in trilogue, to ensure that we have flexibility and creativity, that farmers will be allowed to farm for generations to come, and that we support young farmers transitioning into agriculture. We need to ensure that we have environmental ambitions that are compatible with farmers and farming compatible with environmental ambitions. So, Commissioner, I urge us to use this transition period to ensure that we set farming into the future compatible with the environment and ensuring that we have a strong agricultural base for years to come to support our family farms.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this very weekend I was asking a farmer on the island of La Palma: 'How are you?' And he said, "I want better." That's how we find ourselves here today, wanting better.  We have a transitional agreement that allows farmers and ranchers in the Canary Islands and other outermost regions to breathe with some tranquility. But they will only be able to do so for the next two years because, behind them, uncertainty continues.  Achieving this agreement has been the result of the great work of many, and today I must deeply thank President Von der Leyen, Commissioner Wojciechowski and the rapporteurs who have sought ways to ensure that the agricultural sector of the UPRs does not lose a single euro. However, it's not all won. From today, hard work will have to be re-worked so that, after the transitional period, the future of the agricultural sector of the UPRs is guaranteed.  PoseI's current allocation is EUR 268 million, just 0.1% of the CAP's overall budget. But its stable and long-term maintenance is vital, because the reduction of it would mean the disappearance of the primary sector and, with it, the disappearance of our landscape and also of our way of life. THERUP now needs Europe more than ever. By maintaining POSEI we will demonstrate that the outermost regions are really ultra-important for Europe. That's our challenge.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, as has been said many times before, this transitional provision for 2021 and 2022 is very important for our farmers. It guarantees them stable funding rules for the next two years, which are very similar to those they already know. We know that conditions are also changing very much for farmers, their climate is changing, the market situation is changing, they are being hit by the COVID-19 pandemic. Therefore, at least this certainty is very important to them and is such a gift for Christmas. Although I am not happy about the length of the transitional period, I will vote in favour of the transitional regulation for these reasons. However, I am sorry that we are postponing stronger environmental measures by two years, that we are postponing more support for young farmers, and that what we are witnessing will continue, namely that large agrocomplexes are drawing on funds that could be used by small and medium-sized enterprises, so that there is a lack of capping. I expect that the agreement in the trialogue will eventually bring about at least the amount of capping approved by the European Parliament. I therefore want the Member States to prepare their strategic plans well. Perhaps they will have time if the agreement is adopted in time. These strategic plans should also include the views of the general professional public in order to truly reform it.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, this two-year period of transition was much needed. It is true that there is, on the one hand, the pandemic that has created instability in all economic sectors, but also, on the other hand, a risk of no deal and all the risks associated with Brexit. This security and stability, brought about through this transition, is necessary for all of our farming friends. On the other hand, as you know, an agricultural business is not a business like any other. You don't press on-off, you don't change your production in 24 hours. It takes a little time. Time also, of course, to negotiate the new common agricultural policy, to do so with the actors, with the farmers at our side, to allow this just transition, to be able to also achieve important objectives related to sustainability and the green pact, and to enable them to have, over and over again, this primary function which is a nourishing function and which allows our rural territories to live , our villages, all of our territories. I am also pleased that, as part of the stimulus package, resources have been established. I have a regret - we can always have regrets - it is the overall budget which, in my opinion, was not enough, but it is a story that is unfortunately behind us. I hope that, as part of the recovery plan, which is also European, the various Member States will also table a whole series of proposals and projects that will indirectly or directly support our farming friends through these different plans. I ask you to pay attention to this, Commissioner, and also to ensure during these two years that the various treaties we will pass take into account imports and the impact on the agricultural world, in terms of product quality.

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: – Mr President, Dear Commissioner, first of all, I would like to congratulate rapporteur Elsie Katainen and the entire Negotiating Team of the European Parliament on the hard work on the Regulation on the transitional rules of the common agricultural policy.  Despite the extraordinary situation caused by Kovid, I congratulate you for showing steadfastness and protecting the interests of European farmers in the framework of the trialogies carried out. For today's plenary vote, we give the green light so that the transitional rules enter from 1 January 2021.  I am pleased that with a common effort we have been able to maintain transitional national aid during the transition period, as well as to continue supporting disadvantaged areas with natural constraints. These instruments are extremely important for countries such as Bulgaria, as they support the most vulnerable groups of farmers. An additional EUR 8 billion for rural development under the Recovery Plan has been very important in recent months. I am pleased that we have been able to protect these funds under the transitional regulation and they will be available to farmers in 2021 and 2022 to overcome the negative effects that the pandemic has had on their activities.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Member. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! When The Commission started president von der Leyen's commission more than a year ago, when I, as a candidate for commissioner, was standing before the High Chamber, we had one great uncertainty: It was not clear what to do with the multiannual financial framework, what about the budget for the common agricultural policy – which was, after all, presented in a heavily stripped-down version – we did not know what to do next with the reform of the common agricultural policy. , we did not know what about the transition period. And all this has been affected by the crisis, which has affected the entire EU economy and affected agriculture.  In this crisis, our farmers have provided us with food security, for which we must continue to thank them. It is a great, great achievement that food supplies have not been interrupted. Farmers have provided us with food security. We, as politicians, as political and legislative institutions of the European Union, must ensure economic security for our farmers – and we are a few steps further down this path. And I would like to thank you very warmly, because what we are finalising today – the transitional regulation – is part of a broader package of actions that we are taking together. The fact that today we can provide our farmers with precisely this clarity about the transition period is the result of very good cooperation with the Committee on Agriculture. I wanted to thank you. I thanked rapporteur Katainen, but I thank you for the coordinators I have met many times in our joint work: Mr Dorfmann, Mr De Castro, Mrs Müller, Mr Häusling, Mr David, Mr Kuźmiukov, Mr Flanagan. Such constant and constructive cooperation has contributed to this.  Today we have a much better budget, EUR 22 billion more than was planned two years ago. Today we are already clear about the future Multiannual Financial Framework. Today we know that there is a recovery plan, some of which has already been transferred to the Rural Development Fund. But I firmly believe that there will also be an approach, there will be greater synergy between politicians. And rural areas are not only expenditure from the common agricultural policy, but also increased expenditure from the reconstruction fund for various activities around agriculture, for the reconstruction of agricultural processing, for example, but also the Cohesion Fund, which should also be more dedicated to rural areas. We are a few steps ahead in all of these matters and I wanted to thank you again for that.  We are providing our farmers with much more certainty about their future, and I firmly believe that what is in the process at the moment, that is, the trilogue procedure and the final shape of the reform of the common agricultural policy, is a process that is on track. Once again, I thank the European Parliament for this very constructive cooperation in all these areas and for the fact that we can today, after this first year of the Commission's work, give our farmers more such good hope for the future at this very difficult time. Thank you for the kind words spoken in this debate to the Commission, Mrs von der Leyen, including my personal one. I am convinced that we are taking a very important step.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Dan-Ştefan MOTREANU
text: in writing. – The legal certainty for our farmers is essential and the support for farmers and agri-food producers, through direct payments, market measures and rural development, needs to continue without interruption during the smooth transition to the new CAP reform. On the same time, I regret that we did not achieve the full external convergence of direct payments for our farmers and that is why the continuation of transitional national aid is essential as will allow Member States to compensate partially the differences in payments. This year, the current coronavirus pandemic hardly hit our economies and our farmers and during summer, countries from the Eastern Europe have experienced a severe drought that had destroyed important agricultural harvest. The farmers and rural economies have to recover after the crisis and the funds from the European Recovery Instruments needs to be available immediately for our farmers through their integration into rural development programmes for the next two years. Moreover, the exceptional rural development measure adopted in the context of coronavirus crisis has allowed Member States to support the agricultural producers and as the current crisis continues, I welcome the extension of this exceptional crisis measure for additional six months.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Andrey Novakov and Constanze Krehl, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 as regards exceptional additional resources and implementing arrangements under the Investment for growth and jobs goal to provide assistance for fostering crisis repair in the context of the COVID—19 pandemic and preparing a green, digital and resilient recovery of the economy (REACT—EU) (COM(2020)0451 – C9-0149/2020 – 2020/0101(COD)) (A9-0150/2020).

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: deputy rapporteur. – Madam President, I take the floor on behalf of Mr Novakov, co-speaker of this report.  I wish we were not having this debate, because this would mean that we would not be living the nightmare we suffered because of COVID. What we are experiencing is a real humanitarian tragedy in the form of viruses that has already killed more than 476,000 Europeans; a pandemic that has resulted in the deaths of more than one and a half million human beings worldwide, as well as the contagion of more than 72 million people.  And, therefore, I would like to begin my speech by expressing my deepest condolences for the deceased, sending my most loving greeting to all family and friends and wishing for a prompt recovery for all the infected. I would also like to acknowledge the immense work of so many people who over the past few months have been and are on the front line of the fight against the pandemic: thank them all, thank you wholeheartedly for their immense dedication, sacrifice and professionalism. And precisely because of the immense work and talent of scientists and the investment of multinational pharmaceutical companies, supported by public institutions, today we can say that there is hope because we already have a vaccine.  Soon we will leave behind this terrible pandemic, but what follows is almost as tragic. Without a doubt, we are facing the greatest challenge we have faced since World War II. To the humanitarian and health tragedy are added the terrible social and economic consequences that we are already beginning to suffer: sinking of our gross domestic product, increase in debt and deficit, closure of business, destruction of employment, fall in consumption, uncertainty, since this nightmare is not yet over, but we remain immersed in it; macroeconomic data that already translates into the social needs and urgencies of many of our compatriots and their families.  In the face of all this tragedy, we must be proud of the European Union's reaction. I believe that the European Union and its institutions have risen to the challenge and have been able to provide a quick, effective, forceful and unanimous response since March and April, in which rapid initiatives were responded to to speed up Member States' access to the funds they needed to meet the needs of masks and health expenditure.  In this context, the Next Generation EU programme was born, an unprecedented economic recovery plan – we are talking about EUR 750 billion – and within this programme, next generation EU, is where we find the REACT-EU programme, which we are discussing today, a programme of EUR 47.5 billion.  Just as it was necessary to remember why this plan arises, it is just as essential to highlight for what. Public money recovery and injection plans are not good news in itself. Let us not forget that public money does not fall from heaven, comes out of debt, that we or future generations will have to pay, or it comes out of taxes, which we will undoubtedly have to pay. They are plans that must always be born in exceptional situations such as this one that we live in and with a series of concrete, measurable and evaluated objectives.  And, in my opinion, the plan we are presenting today is a very good agreement. We have reached a good agreement, as I said, that clearly identifies the investment areas, the objectives to be achieved, the sectors to be financed and the conditions to be met. Without a doubt, a good roadmap to achieve the real recovery of our economy.  What is REACT-EU? Grants and loans to small and medium-sized enterprises in crisis to support those who are to be the real protagonists of the recovery: the self-employed and entrepreneurs; employers, the only ones capable of creating jobs, that much-needed job; small businesses that create community, which maintain much of the employment, often sustained, at the moment, by family support.  The State will not be the one to revive the economy or to create jobs. The state has the opportunity to be able to help those who can do so, entrepreneurs. That is why we do not have to make the mistake of repeating the caduco interventionism of past times and, therefore, it is good that react-EU has approved aid to entrepreneurs and self-employed people.  In addition, this programme includes a clear commitment to something fundamental: training, digitisation, energy transition and support for our much-punished health systems, all of which are pillars of a recovery not only in the short term, but a recovery understood as building a european path of economic and social future.  This good agreement also includes much-needed retroactivity—as of February 1, 2020—so that Member States can use funding from the moment they began the pandemic. Having one more year to invest thanks to increased investment eligibility until the end of 2023 will enable the rationality of investment. There's no rush to spend the money. First, because we have not seen the end of the crisis and we still have to see many companies fall sadly and restructure. Therefore, we have to keep in mind that we are looking at the medium term. There is no rush to spend the money; you have to spend it well. And secondly, because it will be meditated and go where it can have a lever effect, one of the characteristics of cohesion financing.  The agility of the European Commission's two-week investment approval is very good news. We do not need the money to be in Brussels, but to be on the ground, in the regions, in the municipalities, where it is needed. We recognize, for this reason, the efforts of the institutions to shorten approval periods throughout the process.  Implementation will be carried out through the rules and structures of the existing cohesion policy; there will be no additional bureaucracy. And one hundred percent of the funds will be European funds; there will be no national funds.  In short, I would like to thank all the political groups of the Committee on Regional Development for the immense work they have done, for the effort we have made to get REACT-EU approved. It is a very good agreement for citizens, it is a good agreement for entrepreneurs and entrepreneurs and will undoubtedly help create jobs.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Madam President, in the name of Constanze Krehl, our rapporteur from the S&D Group, I address this plenary saying that 2020 was a year of drama and dramatic changes in Europe. We’ve suffered the drama of losing hundreds of thousands of Europeans. We mourn their loss and we extend our solidarity to their families.  But there were dramatic changes in the way we relate to each other, the way we work, the way we do business – all of this had to change this year. And a lot has also changed in politics and policy. Many of those who opposed further European integration started clamouring for more European common policies. Many of those who did not like cohesion policy started asking for the reinforcement of cohesion policy.  Fortunately, the European institutions were able to understand what was needed and what was expected from us. After some initial hesitation by some institutions, we put in place an extensive series of measures which protected the health of citizens, sustained the economies as much as possible, and protected employment and citizens’ wellbeing.  Within the multiple policy measures that were put in place to cope with the crisis it is important to underline that the first effective consequences on the ground were in cohesion policy. The Corona response investment initiatives, best known as CRII and CRII+ (Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative Plus), were launched in April and had immediate effects, frontloading EUR 37 billion of unallocated resources within the current MFF. The flexibility that CRII and CRII+ brought to the European funds allowed for essential investments at the initial stage of the pandemic, such as on medical equipment, including ventilators and personal protective equipment, the support to SMEs, to job maintenance and to the vulnerable groups.  Cohesion policy was at the forefront of the response to the crisis and once again it delivered. And let me stress this: one of the key characteristics of cohesion policy is that it indeed delivers. It delivers concrete results and European citizens deserve and are eager for those results. That is why the MMF agreement was also so important, and that is why the blackmail by two Member States was totally unacceptable, and in the end it didn’t pay. We overcame that blackmail and Europe can now go forward on a path where we can see hope, where we can see the vaccine is coming, the beginning of an end to the pandemic, the economic recovery, the creation of jobs, and finally a better Europe, a greener and fairer Europe.  The new MFF and the new cohesion policy are crucial for the recovery, but REACT-EU is the first instrument that is now ready, bridging the gap between the first emergency crisis response and the long-term recovery package. For every act the EU approved in time the negotiation teams worked hard and fast to reach an agreement, and as a result we can already vote now on REACT-EU.  With this initiative the European Union is offering a strong reaction to the consequences of COVID, which is what people in regions are expecting from us. But the negotiation teams have also worked well and we should support strongly the content of the agreement, an agreement where important Parliament demands were incorporated, bringing more flexibility and more fairness to REACT-EU.  The EUR 47.5 billion from the REACT-EU programme will allow for investment in the areas where Member States have higher needs, be it on health, on SMEs, on supporting the most deprived, the self-employed or the freelancers. Parliament managed to secure a higher pre-financing and guaranteed that the Commission quickly checks and approves the programmes so that the money can reach the real economy as fast as possible.  Parliament has also insisted on having projects funded retroactively from 1 February onwards, enabling regions all over Europe to fund their reactions to COVID which they started in spring or summer. It was also important for Parliament to have a stronger focus on border regions, which was made through a link with the Interreg programme, because border regions and their populations were particularly affected when the borders were temporarily closed.  Finally, I want to underline the importance of the strong ties Parliament was able to introduce with the European Social Fund, the Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived and the Youth Employment Initiative, strengthening the social dimension of REACT—EU, a fight in which the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) and the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) were side by side.  The social impact of the crisis must be a priority and the European Union has to do everything to make sure the response to the crisis leaves no one behind. The European Union is a political project aiming at economic and social convergence. We must always keep this in mind or European citizens will be alienated from the future of the Union. Initiatives like REACT-EU, policies like cohesion policy that deliver concrete results, that touch, protect and improve people’s lives, are the ones that do the most to strengthen the sense of belief in the future of the Union.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Rapporteur for opinion EMPL. Mr President, we must be honest about the crisis, and that is not easy. The measures that are needed are not fun. They leave no room for carelessness. They hurt. So we have to take the hits together. As good and as evil as it goes, we must prepare for the effects of the crisis. The React-EU emergency fund has been working at a breakneck pace in recent times. Now that this nasty virus is stagnating, this fund has been kicked out of the ground in order to alleviate the greatest need as quickly as possible. From this place, I would like to congratulate my colleagues Constanze Krehl and Andrey Novakov and Commissioner Ferreira for the hard work of getting this done here. React-EU creates the space to invest in sustainable employment, in new jobs. We're going to need it very much later.  In addition, it will be possible to finance a temporary part-time WW and so we can also keep jobs. Personally, I am proud that this does not come at the expense of the social potty. Fortunately, this remains at the same level, because we know that poverty will increase all over Europe. I also see it in my own Netherlands where the queues for the food banks are currently growing. We must therefore maintain the fight against poverty. We must not allow poverty reduction to become the child of this crisis.  For the whole of Europe, €47.5 billion is now in place to keep people working or to work. For the Netherlands, that's about 440 million, which is on the shelf. So I call on the aldermen from Dronten, from Lochem, from Utrecht or elsewhere in the whole country to call for action in The Hague, because the money is available, the needs are there. Let's get to work.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, dear rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, honourable Members, since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in Europe, the Commission has undertaken a comprehensive set of actions for a European response to the crisis. REACT-EU, which stands for Recovery Assistance for Cohesion and the Territories of Europe, is an important milestone in this process, and I am thankful to the rapporteurs and Members, in particular of the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL), for addressing the REACT-EU proposal with the same sense of urgency as its predecessor, the Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative, CRII and CRII+. Every day, CRII and CRII+ deliver emergency support to workers, to hospitals, to small businesses across the Union, reaching EUR 18 billion by December. To continue this type of support in only a few months since the Commission’s proposal on REACT-EU in May, the College leaders reached a political agreement once again in record time. This was the first initiative agreed to be powered by the Next Generation EU, and it is in fact the first programme negotiation to be completed among the MFF Next Generation package of proposals. This is testimony to the added value unanimously confirmed by the REGI Committee on 3 December. Thanks to the proactive approach of the rapporteurs and our joint effort, our message to the European citizens is clear and strong. We are leaving no one behind. We are in this together. We will come out of this crisis together. Together we can achieve a resilient and strong repair of our economy and society. The vote today is an opportunity to unlock EUR 47.5 billion for crisis response and repair in Europe. This additional exceptional amount will support Member States and regions most impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and its social consequences. It will also serve to prepare the green and the digital transitions for a resilient economy and society in the longer term. REACT—EU builds on the flexibility of the CRII package while bridging funding in the first crucial years of the recovery towards long-term cohesion investments in digitalisation and sustainability. Which key features of cohesion crisis response were retained? Some of the previous interventions already underlined its support to the health sector, workers, small businesses and young people in particular: liquidity thanks to generous pre-financing, flexibility and the possibility of 100% EU financing. Eligibility of expenditure as of 1 February 2020 is retained, and the measures continue to be embedded in the current cohesion programmes for facility. What is new? First of all, the scope of the initiative, which now covers basic infrastructures for public services and enables the first steps of the repair in line with digital and green goals. Also cross border territories, as was mentioned before. Let me close by highlighting two core principles of REACT-EU. First, reflecting the importance of tackling climate change, REACT-EU is expected to contribute 25% of its resources to climate objectives, and in fact, the Commission regrets that we could not get this information or this requirement in the legal text as an article. That’s why the Commission will issue a statement in that regard upon adoption of the act. Second, I’d like to stress that the involvement of regional and local actors, economic and social partners, and civil society is essential for our policy, including REACT-EU. I would like to thank again the rapporteurs, the Committee, and I’m looking forward to hearing today’s debate.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: Rapporteur for the BUDG Committee opinion. – Dear Vice-Presidents, in this pre-Christmas time of deep uncertainty for millions of families across Europe, after an extremely difficult year, the most vulnerable deserve concrete European solidarity. Recovery and cohesion assistance REACT-EU is therefore an indispensable part of the common European recovery.  Additional funding for employment measures, SMEs, job preservation support, but also for business working capital will be particularly important for less developed Member States in recovering as quickly as possible. The possibility of 100% European funding and financing of projects already implemented or planned will be additional assistance. For the most affected sectors such as tourism and culture, for the most affected generations, in economic terms these are young people, but also for the most affected areas, rural, less developed and demographically disadvantaged areas.

name: Tsvetelina PENKOVA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, react-EU funds must reach European citizens as quickly as possible. The Kovid-19 crisis has once again shown us that the answer and the way to rebuild Europe is not by denying Europe, but quite the opposite. Only if we work together can we overcome the consequences of the crisis.  That €47.5 billion is just the beginning. The funds are allocated retrospectively and aim to cover the costs of national states to combat the crisis that have arisen since February. We must continue to work together to respond more quickly and in such situations. National governments must be responsible for every euro spent and always seek to help those most affected first. A clear economic strategy is needed for the recovery of the European economy and for the green transition, which is an integral part of this future. This strategy must be at both European and national level so that we can all follow our common path together. European citizens require clear solutions for the future and it is our responsibility to give them.

name: Susana SOLÍS PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, today we can be very proud to be European. In the midst of COVID's second wave, with heartbreaking numbers of the deceased and infected across Europe and still unpredictable economic consequences, today we approve the first fund of the recovery package: the REACT-EU fund, with EUR 47.5 billion for the countries that need it most.  And if we often talk about the inefficiency of the European Union, the rigidity of its procedures and how far away it is from citizens, today we show the opposite: that the European Union has acted fast and that it has certainly been up to date, and that this is an example of European solidarity.  Because this is not going to be a fund to use. It will have unprecedented flexibility, the usual restrictions will not be imposed and will have a co-financing rate of one hundred percent, so that it is regional and local authorities that decide what this money can be used for until 2023.  Thanks to REACT-EU, small entrepreneurs, hospitality, small shops will be able to receive liquidity to cope with the serious losses they have had since the pandemic began since February 2020. But health expenditures — beds, PPE, respirators — can also be financed and, of course, support can be provided to all the unemployed in need.  It is a breath of oxygen for the most affected sectors. In countries like mine, such as Spain, where forecasts indicate that one in ten companies is going to have to close, that GDP is going to collapse by 12% and that there will be one million more people at risk of poverty, citizens, who are having such a hard time, need good news. And this is good news.  Europe has now done its homework and we have to make sure that these funds are used correctly, that they reach citizens as soon as possible and that not a single euro is wasted.  And I only have to thank you, dear police station, for your involvement, as well as the chairman of the Committee on Regional Development and all the rapporteurs, who have worked so closely, in this spirit of commitment, so that these funds reach citizens as soon as possible.

name: Francesca DONATO
text: On behalf of the ID Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased with the outcome of the negotiations on REACT-EU, but this instrument will not work for Italy, because to spend ten billion in a year you need spending capacity, therefore a capable government and that the current Italian Government is totally incapable of proving it: the 70 billion not spent on treasury, the highest number of deaths from Covid despite the lockdown , the exponential increase in the number of unemployed and the inability to bring home the 18 Sicilian fishermen who had been seized in Libya for three months, while the Turkish Government had General Haftar free his fishermen after just a week. If the European Union does not want to leave anyone behind, it cannot abandon the Italian citizens in the hands of buffoons, but it must ask Minister Di Maio, President Conte to resign and intervene directly to free the fishermen of Mazara, it is Sicily that asks you: bring them home!

name: Monika VANA
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to thank the two rapporteurs, their teams, the chairman of the Committee on Regional Development and all those involved in this REACT-EU dossier. The fact that we can vote on this dossier before the end of this year shows that the European Parliament, even under difficult working conditions, is able to work quickly on solutions for Europe's regions, for Europe's citizens, in order to provide targeted support for them in the crisis. With REACT-EU, we underline the important role of cohesion policy as a crisis instrument, but also the importance of the economic, social and, above all, territorial cohesion of the European Union.  REACT-EU is an important sign that we are not abandoning anyone, in a sign of solidarity with all regions and citizens. It is a flexible, temporary crisis instrument against the economic and social consequences of the pandemic and should be used by the Member States as flexibly and purposefully as possible, where the funds are most needed: up to 100% support from the EU– also retroactively.  It is important – and this is also the case in the negotiations – to set a concrete framework for efficient and high-quality funding, such as the emphasis on the social aspect of the crisis, the use of funds for youth unemployment and cross-border cooperation, or the establishment of a gender perspective and the strengthening of the partnership principle, that is, the involvement of regional and local administrations, the social partners and civil society. Of course, we Greens are also particularly concerned about strengthening climate protection and thus emphasising the so-called do no harm principle in climate protection, that is, the exclusion of climate-damaging investments in REACT-EU. As well as the time limit of the programme: REACT-EU is a short, targeted crisis assistance to The Member States, not a competition with the EU's regular cohesion policy with its high quality standards and strong sustainability objectives. A big downside from a green point of view, however, is the under-recommended target for climate spending of only 25% in this draft. I do not think that in 2020 we cannot talk about crisis management without taking into account the Green Deal against the climate crisis and enshering a stronger, more binding climate spending target.
