Overall, however, i would like to emphasise this, REACT-EU is an important instrument of European solidarity and in support of Europe's regions and citizens, in support of the Green Deal, digitisation in a socially just manner and gender-based development of the European Union.

name: Andżelika Anna MOŻDŻANOWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Today it is up to us whether we take the next step in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic. When we launched crii and CRII+ life-saving assistance in April, we showed that cohesion policy passed the test and ensured the health safety of our loved ones and families.  Now, after a few months of work, we have react-eu ready. This is €47.5 billion in additional cohesion policy funding for our countries, regions, health services, businesses and, above all, the people of Europe. The slowdown in investment and the functioning of economies across the European Union has caused a huge economic and social crisis. REACT-EU is an urgent response to counteract this and return to development and economic growth.  REACT-EU is the first mechanism under the European Instrument for Reconstruction. That is why trilogue negotiations were so crucial, resulting in even better opportunities for its use, i.e. the eligibility period for expenditure extended until the end of 2023 and the level of investment advances increased to 11%. React-EU does not oblige, but gives the opportunity to make flexible decisions in each country in order to maximise the effect of reconstruction. All this to ensure that support reaches where it is most needed. I am convinced that the EUR 37.5 billion for 2021 – more than EUR 1.5 billion for Polish – which we will mobilise from January, with a 100% level of investment funding, will effectively contribute to a rapid recovery from the covid-19 crisis.  My fellow Members, by adopting REACT-EU today, we support development and investment in solidarity, we are fighting to maintain every job, both economically and socially. All citizens of a united Europe are waiting for this help.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done For months, the regions waited for the European blockbuster of Corona crisis management. Now, finally, we have the REACT-EU programme. It is hope for health workers, for companies in the shutdown, for students who need to learn digitally, and for artists whose venues are still closed. I regret that the governments in the Council cut the funds even before the start of the negotiations. Large sums of money for the MFF and also for REACT-EU sound gigantic at first, but they are encapsuating the real cuts by the Member States. A joint debt was overdue, but it has scratches. We would have liked to have had more courage here. Binding to the EU budget now requires a bold own resources strategy, and I ask: where is the European financial transaction tax, where is the digital tax, where a wealth levy for those who accumulate billions? Last but not least, we now have a mechanism of the rule of law that hardly deserves the name and whose objectives have long since been pursued by the OLAF authority. The power struggle in the European Council must finally stop, because it is an engine of the crisis of confidence in democracy in the EU.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Covid-19 pandemic has caused a huge shock to the European and global economy. Many people have often been forced to stop or slow down their business almost overnight. This crisis has become a very important test for the European Union. A test of the extent to which it is able to support Europeans quickly and effectively at such a difficult time for them.  I am convinced that REACT-EU will clearly show our citizens that they are not alone. I believe that it is extremely important that the resources available under the Fund will support, among other things, those most affected by the crisis, namely tourism and culture, and small and medium-sized enterprises, or support health systems. I also believe that, thanks to high pre-financing, a 100% co-financing rate for expenditure and more flexible programming and implementation, REACT-EU will make it possible to effectively and quickly offset the negative economic impact of the pandemic.  There is also no doubt that tackling the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic is a long-term task. I therefore think it is right to suggest that, where appropriate, additional resources should also be available in 2023 and 2024, because we will also then be forced to protect jobs within the European Union.

name: Cristina MAESTRE MARTÍN DE ALMAGRO
text: – Madam President, this is certainly a very important plenary for many reasons: we will talk about the annual budget, the long-awaited agreement on the multiannual financial framework and the aid and measures package to deal with COVID, among many other also very important issues.  But if we have to look for a point, a link for the union of all these important issues that we are debating, that is the capacity that the European institutions are demonstrating to 'solidify' important agreements when citizens need it most. We are giving a very clear message to European citizens: Europe is here to help them get out of this difficult time.  Today we approve the REACT-EU instrument, an important mechanism that will help many people, many European citizens get out of this COVID crisis—19. This fund will reinforce the most important thing—the right to health—by helping health systems in the worst-spending countries. This fund will give a very big boost to the economies that have been so damaged; will give a boost to the company; it will help recover and maintain jobs for hundreds of thousands of European citizens and help sectors as damaged as culture or tourism in these pandemic times.  This is certainly a great tool that will help Member States deal with this crisis. Let us help them to be, of course, a genuine commitment to this crisis.  It is also about making it easier for public administrations to have that flexibility that we have always been asking for: flexibility that is not at odds with resource efficiency; without stiffness, but rigorously.  I would like to thank and congratulate on your work the European Commission, represented here by your Commissioner Elisa Ferreira, the rapporteurs, who have made every effort to reach the agreement, the Council and also the President of the Commission, in defence and as a symbol of what this fund entails: a clear and resounding commitment by the European institutions to cohesion policies.

name: Irène TOLLERET
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the COVID-19 pandemic has hit very hard. The economy of our regions is on its knees, our health systems are under strain, thousands of jobs are lost or are at risk.  Our territories were waiting for a European and solidarity response, capable of accompanying their action. Our Union was quick, it was able to respond quickly through the cohesion policy- I welcome its President - which has once again proved to be a modern and flexible tool. The additional resources - we are talking about EUR 47.5 billion - provided by REACT-EU will strengthen the resilience of these European regions. This will allow them to invest in their health systems, save jobs and support struggling SMEs.  The total flexibility left to Member States in the expenditure of these resources will enable them to target the territories and sectors most affected by this crisis. The level of co-financing, set at 100%, makes it possible not to increase the public budgets of the Member States, which are already in such demand.  Europe is here, ladies and gentlemen, and once again it proves that it is built in crises. Thanks to REACT-EU, our territories can look to the future with more hope. We are not leaving anyone on the side of the road and we are showing once again that it is together that we will emerge from this crisis.

name: Alessandro PANZA
text: Madam President, commissioner, chairman of the committee, we are finally commenting on a measure, a regulation that leaves behind a past of bureaucratic Byzantineism and absurd constraints for local authorities and citizens, introducing, for example, flexibility and 100 % cofinancing and the direct involvement of the regions, which are only a small part of the positive aspects of REACT-EU.  Today we are here to welcome a measure which, at last, looks to the future, a future made up of simpler, simpler, more useful rules and, above all, closer to the needs of the people of Europe, with the hope, of course, that they will also be maintained on all future measures of cohesion policy and next generation EU. A measure that, among the various concrete and positive aspects, thanks also to the contribution of the League and the ID Group, finally takes explicit account also of mountain areas, areas that are too often forgotten and not adequately considered in the European legislative process, despite the fact that they are widely present on the continental territory. For the mountains it is a small timid step, but more needs to be done to allow the tenacious and resilient population of mountain areas to be the protagonist in Europe.  Finally, allow me to point out that, on the part of my group, despite the so-called cordon sanitary cord applied to us at the beginning of this parliamentary term, there has been positive and correct cooperation, precisely because this type of measure was in favour of the citizens, peoples, territories and nations that make up this Europe. If we continue to work in this way, we are obviously ready to play our part, if we return to talk about constraints, blackmail and absurd taxation in us, you will always find a strenuous and fierce resistance.

name: Niklas NIENASS
text: – Madam President, it is just and right that the EU is there to help in these times of crisis. The goals for the recovery funds are to help swiftly and unbureaucratically and to overcome the economic crisis, while at the same time fostering European cooperation. In this regard, it was a good idea to use the framework of already existing programmes like the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), which we know work well in the regions. REACT-EU follows the logic of swift, easy, productive and European. However the Recovery and Resilience Facility does not. It is shameful to see that the vast majority of the recovery money, EUR 670 billion, is being spent with little to no European agenda behind it. I also have to say: that REACT-EU has no obligation for the usage of Interreg is a pity. How the fact that in the first draft of REACT-EU, Interreg wasn’t even mentioned, is shameful and unworthy of a European Commission. After images of closed borders and failed European solidarity at the peak of this crisis, after months of isolation and for thousands of families, also months of loss and mourning, we need the European coronavirus aid to be used to bring Europeans back together. We need our funds to be spent in a European way, a way that increases European exchange, cooperation and solidarity, and that benefits our citizens. Here’s how to do it. Instead of transferring EUR 670 billion to the Member States, use them to top up these tools that foster European cohesion – top up the ERDF, the Cohesion Fund, the Just Transition Fund and the ESF, and then use the EUR 50 billion that are now planned for REACT-EU to top up the programmes that support European exchange, European culture and European education: to support Interreg, Erasmus and Creative Europe. This is the way we should spend our European money. To enable Europeans to study, work, celebrate life, live and laugh together, until once again this crazy pandemic is finally over. REACT-EU is not bad. It is one of the better programmes of the Next Generation EU funds, and probably the best that we can get from a Council like this, but for me as a member of the next generation of Europeans, one good programme is not enough. The overall spending is not climate-just enough, it is not social enough, and it’s definitely not European enough.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are finalking the legislative process of the REACT-EU Regulation, i.e. Support for reconstruction for cohesion and the territories of Europe. This fund, which aims to complement cohesion policy programmes in the fight against the current economic crisis, is expected to be worth €47.5 billion. The allocation of resources will be determined by the Commission at a later stage through implementing acts, and I hope that, in accordance with the agreement of Parliament and the Council, it will ensure maximum flexibility and decision-making for the Member States.  At this point, I would like to emphasise that Poland, contrary to the popular opinion expressed by the media and some Union politicians, has never opposed the rule of law mechanism. However, in defence of European law and the interests not only of our own citizens, we do not accept any possibility of arbitrary interpretation and use of this mechanism. It can only be applied in the event of an unlawful disbursement of Union funds and must be based on objective and measurable criteria which do not allow its political instrumentalisation.  Returning to the REACT-EU fund, I must unfortunately finally note, to paraphrase the famous saying by the Polish columnist Stefan Kisielewski, that today the European Union, like socialism, is heroistly fighting the problems it has created itself.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, dear Elisa Ferreira, Commissioner, my dear colleagues, I would first like to warmly congratulate Constanze Krehl and Andrey Novakov, the co-staff, and the whole REGI Committee for the outstanding work done on this regulation. I also want to thank Commissioner Ferreira and the German Presidency. Our policy has, I believe, demonstrated its ability to be reactive in times of crisis, to be more flexible in helping as closely as possible. We also noted this gamble which many considered impossible: to adopt the 'cohesion' package on time and to conclude five open negotiations at the same time - with the added value given to the regulation by the European Parliament. With almost 370 billion euros for 2021-2027, plus stimulus funds, cohesion policy is central and regions can now move forward safely for 2021-2027 programming. I think we can now say that the recovery plan starts with the adoption of REACT-EU and we can also, I believe, be proud of the contribution of the cohesion policy, the solidarity policy that has helped to build Europe and which will also allow it to be rebuilt.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Madam President! Today we are looking at the REACT-EU programme, the first measure in the recovery plan package, which demonstrates that cohesion policy has been at the heart of the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic from the outset. The REACT-EU action is a further step to support Member States in the recovery from the pandemic by providing additional resources to bridge the gap between the first, emergency crisis response and the long-term recovery of the economy and society as a whole, which awaits us in the next MFF.  REACT-EU ensures fair and cohesive action, much-needed flexibility for Member States to decide on the share of funds and retroactive effect, as countries will be able to justify the expenditure incurred as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic since 1 February 2020, even if the measures have already been finalised and fully implemented.  I am convinced that, with a dedicated amount of EUR 47.5 billion, THE EU will continue and further expand emergency measures to respond to the crisis and to remedy the crisis. In doing so, it is particularly pleased that the programme does not provide for a predetermined breakdown by region, allowing Member States adequate flexibility and channelling resources to where they are most needed, allowing countries to justify expenditure incurred by 31 December 2023.  REACT-EU also foresees a business-to-day and rapid mobilisation of investments without additional bureaucratic conditions such as ex ante conditionality, thematic concentration requirements and the performance framework. I believe that the EU will contribute to a green, digital and resilient recovery of society following the COVID-19 crisis with additional resources, the existing cohesion policy programme. Thank you and greetings from Ljubljana.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, I am pleased that you are here after the productive meeting we had yesterday with members of the SEARICA intergroup. React-EU is one of the welcome responses to the health and economic consequences of a pandemic whose scope is still impossible to see. It is spooked that this pandemic could cause as many as 100 million new poor people in Europe. For this reason, I support the rapporteur's efforts to extend this programme after 2022, if necessary, for another two years in compliance with other instruments.  The social consequences of this crisis on society should be emphasised.  The Socialists and Democrats Club places special emphasis on them. I welcome the allocation of additional resources for the most vulnerable groups and children, the improvement of social inclusion and the eradication of poverty.  As you can assume after yesterday's conversation, we especially support the appreciation of the specificities of the islands and other territories referred to in Article 174. treaty on the functioning of the European Union. Due to the dependence on too often unsustainable tourism as the main source of income, the islands are further affected by the consequences of the pandemic. Having already proven through a pilot project that they can be at the forefront of the energy transition, islands can be at the forefront of sustainable digital development with adequate support and appreciation of their specificities. And the country I come from, Croatia, will have 800m euros available as a welcome aid. I agree with the Commission's recommendations that these funds should be channelled to the worst affected geographical areas in line with the economic recommendations of the European Semester. Only some of them are: improving healthcare, strengthening labour market and social protection measures, boosting corporate liquidity and investing in sustainable development. The effectiveness of all available funds will, of course, depend primarily on our willingness to make the most of the proposed reforms. In conclusion, this crisis is a huge challenge, but also a great opportunity for the sustainable development of a digital Europe and a more resilient economy, which is why we do not use recovery funds to preserve the status quo, but for new and better solutions.

name: Laurence FARRENG
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we can be particularly proud to vote for this REACT-EU plan, which shows both the European Union's capacity to respond to the crisis and the relevance of European funds to invest as closely as possible to the needs of Europeans.  Many MEPs, and I am one of them, have enabled REACT-EU to provide support to culture and tourism. It is now essential that the European fund management authorities take this opportunity and also make it known as widely as possible to all the leaders of local authorities, cities and regions. Tourism has stalled and many local economies depend on it. Culture is being hit hard and, again, we must act for theatres, museums, festivals and allow those who animate them to spend this period. As a time, we must save these sectors and those that do them.

name: Mathilde ANDROUËT
text: Madam President, I have no doubt that you will describe this unanimity in the face of the release of emergency funds for a European economy brought to its knees by the health crisis as 'historic'. Indeed, how could it be otherwise when each nation is apprehensive about the publication of the latest figures on unemployment, poverty, social plans, debt or business closures? In a new situation, a new device. After the European Union's failed meeting with the health war, the image of this cold institution had to be restored.  You say that you are allocating specific, immediate and extraordinary means to quickly reach the real economy. Yet, quick, you have not been. For those companies that have already shut down, there will be no retroactivity. On the other hand, if you gave up the environmental condition to allocate these emergency funds, you could not help but slip your old obsessions.  Thus, you deplore the fact that the single market, your holy relic, had to suffer a strengthening of borders during the health crisis. If only it had been true and if only some countries, including my own, France, had rushed to close their borders with the outbreaks of this virus to avoid sinking into disease, and therefore into containment and crisis!  Another obsession found here is the desire to welcome and preserve illegal immigrants. Even when the programmes aim to save The Europeans, we still have to think about warming up against our bosom those who come to destabilize us.  So don't be fooled by today's unanimity: we are not fooled by this gift of tens of billions. In some ways, your gift looks like the kiss of death. It means a lot to our European economies, but isn't it also the price you set for yourself to accelerate your dominance over our national economies and our lives? Let us just hope that this emergency fund, which is impossible for us to refuse given the seriousness of the economic and social crisis, is a real gift and not a pact with the worst.

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, I am pleased with the proposed amendments to the Commission's text because they draw attention to perhaps the worst-affected sector and this is naturally culture. I welcome the text because it pays special attention, I quote, to entrepreneurs and self-employed people, including freelancers, artists and other creative workers, who will find it much more difficult to benefit from the financing of cultural projects and funds.  There is one danger, however, that the culture will remain last in line again and receive only the scraps. We need a firmer commitment and enough money to go towards rebuilding the sector. There have been similar legislative formulations before, but to no avail. It is time to receive guarantees from the Commission and the Council, as well as from the Member States, for some percentage of the aid that will only go to culture. However, this affects the 10 million people who work in this sector, and let's ensure that once others distribute their bread, as they say, it will not just be the crumbs of the table for the people of art.

name: Stelios KYMPOUROPOULOS
text: Madam President, Commissioner Ferreira, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to take this step to congratulate everyone on the excellent work they have done in drafting the text, which is helping to make great progress today in cohesion and in the recovery of the European Union. REACT-EU is an initiative that will literally help the recovery and cohesion of the regions. The additional resources as 'new money', which will be made available through the funds, allow Member States to choose the allocation of funds regardless of the economic sector and thus offer a substantial and targeted breath to businesses and workers.  It is important that we have direct regional funding to launch investments to maintain and create jobs, strengthen healthcare systems at all levels, and provide working capital and support for investments in small and medium-sized enterprises.  Let us not forget that, in addition to the pandemic, we have also had a ten-year economic crisis, which has hit many Member States, especially Greece, and a generation of young people has now been lost to the productive fabric, as they have also been hit by high unemployment rates. We will try not to lose another generation of young people with dreams and creativity.  Solidarity and the rule of law are not negotiated products, but they are part of the DNA of Europe's very existence from the Renaissance and the Enlightenment to the present day. That is why all European recovery and multiannual budget lines are rightly linked to the rule of law. I am really pleased that the final text, as it stands, actually supports the economic and social fabric of our regions.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, REACT-EU is an innovative and fundamentally important instrument put in place by the European Union to respond to the crisis, firstly because it provides valuable additional resources, almost EUR 50 billion, to strengthen key programmes such as the European Social Fund, the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Regional Development Fund and the Aid fund for the most deprived, so as to help combat the most serious effects of the pandemic and the most vulnerable territories and population groups. Affected. For Italy, my country, it means EUR 11.3 billion, the largest share among the countries of the Union.  REACT-EU also introduces a series of measures to facilitate the use of European funds, as a bridge between the resources of the current programming and the budget for the next seven years. The possibility of increasing the advance of resources is therefore extremely important because it will provide liquidity to Member States and regions in difficulty, while the increased share of cofinancing will ensure a faster and more complete absorption of the funds available. It would be an unforgivable mistake to leave unused resources in the Union's coffers because of bureaucratic complexity or because of the limitations of structural fund programming, in the context of the extreme need in which we find ourselves. However, we cannot stop there – I want to say this – from this extraordinary and temporary instrument, a political initiative must continue, precisely by the European Parliament, in order to make permanent the major initiatives decided during this period: next generation EU, the common debt, a new European taxation and this innovative approach to the Structural Funds that we are talking about. We cannot miss this opportunity.

name: Monica SEMEDO
text: – Madam President, REACT—EU is the immediate response of the European Union to tackle the consequences of the Covid pandemic, which has hit our citizens and our economy hard. We have freed EUR 54 billion in record time in order to support SMEs through investments into jobs and growth. Almost a quarter of the fund is going to social measures, because we see how EU citizens struggle. Many have lost loved ones; many jobs are at risk; food banks have been used more than average, even in the wealthiest countries. And we don’t know how long this will take. REACT—EU will help citizens to have a more positive outlook and some reassurance, but governments must deploy this fund quickly and purposefully. So, dear colleagues, let’s vote in favour of the proposal to help our citizens, because today, together, we will build the foundation of our future in Europe.

name: Álvaro AMARO
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Ferreira, I clearly wanted to define in this framework a very important and very particular situation of REACT-EU. It is additional support, we know, but it has, in addition to simplified access, funding for investments in various areas, as is known, health, education, training, employment, SMEs and, without ever forgetting, cross-border territories and has, in this simplified procedure, 100% funding.  Only these two reasons would be enough for us to be fully satisfied. But there are others, equally important, and I wanted to draw attention, from my own experience I know well how much, in my country and, certainly in many others, it is in local administrations very close to the populations that these real needs feel. They are the ones who can act quickly, effectively and in a much more appropriate way.  I therefore hope that these investment possibilities will be implemented in this swift manner, particularly in the less developed regions in the outermost regions, so that this dual objective of the ecological and digital transition to which the Union has proposed can be achieved. Europe has indeed played its part and congratulations to Commissioner Elisa Ferreira. Now it is time for the Member States to act and I sincerely hope that we can take the significant step in each Member State and, in a way, in the most disadvantaged regions.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, there is no doubt that the EUR 47 billion REACT-EU Fund will be able to help the economies of the Member States of the European Union, which are currently being tested by a pandemic crisis, which has swept everything in its path and leaves behind both health and socio-economic ruins.  In order to substantially help this Fund, I consider it essential to channel this money directly into the real economy, to support small and medium-sized enterprises, which are at a marginal point and at risk of closure, and to support the sectors that really need it. And all sectors of the economy are in need, because small and medium-sized enterprises, farmers, the various productive sectors of the economy, even social groups, which are in danger of being sidelined once again, the unemployed, vulnerable groups, single-parent families, large families, all those who are actually in a much more critical situation than anyone else are.  That is why we are demanding that the European Union not only announce the EUR 750 billion for the Recovery Fund, but that this money be entered through flexible procedures, away from the well-known bureaucratic procedures of the European Union, away from those procedures that actually discourage citizens. Especially the southern countries, countries such as my home country Cyprus, were irreparably affected because they were based on the tourism sector and the tourism product, which was zeroed in. These countries and those businesses that have so far not received a single euro, these tourism businesses and these sectors must support the Recovery Fund, REACT-EU, before it is too late.  We are already being watched today by European citizens, small and medium-sized enterprises, social groups, the unemployed and they expect us to give them solutions. We're already late. It is the time of the European Union. And the European Union must, with a resounding 'present' but also with a force that gives perspective, vitality and an exit from today's social and economic crises, give the answers that we all expect and that we all expect from the European Union.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: - Dear Chairman, REACT-EU is one of the instruments to address the economic downturn caused by the unprecedented Covid-19 pandemic. The suspension and slowdown of economic activity has caused enormous economic and social damage, and cohesion policy is a key instrument in the fight against these consequences. REACT-EU is an additional step in helping Member States.  It will provide them with additional resources to preserve jobs, cooperate territorially and prepare a green, digital and resilient economic recovery. In this regard, I would like to point out that react-EU funds must primarily help less developed Member States, especially those most affected by the pandemic due to their structure of the economy. I think primarily of those countries that are largely dependent on tourism and the service sector that have suffered the most damage as a result of the pandemic. Of course, I would also mention border regions that have also suffered major consequences during this epidemic due to mobility restrictions.  In particular, I welcome the adoption of amendments by me and my EPP colleagues that will be able to use €47.5 billion to invest in health products and services, including cross-border health and care homes, for infrastructure dedicated to the provision of basic services, for people living in rural, border, less developed island, mountainous and sparsely populated regions, and in particular for stronger cooperation and coordination in the field of health through the construction and development of centres of excellence specialised in development of special procedures for new health needs. And finally, I welcome the european union's co-financing rate of up to 100 per cent, as it reflects that solidarity on which the European Union is founded and which guarantees that aid will arrive to those most in need.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the context of the current pandemic, which affects the whole planet, the population is facing a number of economic and social problems. The pandemic has particularly affected small and medium-sized enterprises throughout the European Union, which has caused many SMEs to go bankrupt and some to be on the verge of survival. At the beginning of this health crisis, the closure of national borders led to a real economic bottleneck, affecting the movement of workers and rising unemployment in the Member States. The European Union, however, reacted quickly, showed responsibility and solidarity, trying and achieving effective protection for all affected citizens, employees and businesses.  A number of programmes and financial aid have been created to limit the negative effects of the pandemic. The REACT-EU programme was designed to save European Union member countries whose economies and jobs have been more severely affected. This programme will seek to limit national differences in addressing the effects of the crisis so as not to create regional gaps. Unemployment across the European Union is expected to rise to 8.6% in 2021 as a result of the Coronavirus pandemic. The programme must therefore focus on avoiding the risk of having a lost generation and creating new jobs, and of course strengthening existing ones. Bold policies will be needed. REACT-EU has all the tools to provide Member States with a set of effective responses to the current crisis, including by simplifying procedures for spending European money.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all those that contributed to this very interesting debate. I would like to reply in these two minutes by underlining that in fact, the Commission and cohesion policy reacted and gave the answer already in April with the support of this Parliament and with the support of the Council, and so cohesion policy once again demonstrated that it was there to act and to support when support is needed. Flexibilities are already there in the Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative (CRII), and so this is a continuation of this project and this programme until 2023. I would also like to underline that in fact, there was disagreement with going fast, and we share this concern. We have got to remind ourselves that after the European Council’s conclusions last Friday and this week’s plenary debate, I hope that the remaining procedures for the approval of the NextGenerationEU will go very fast so that the money reaches the citizens, the regions. On some comments that were made on which sectors, which regions we are proposing, it was approved by this Parliament and by the Presidency to concentrate efforts on countries and regions more in need of help. And so, what we are talking about is regions now that suffer the most and are less capable of helping themselves. I would like to finalise by thanking all those that had very complimentary words towards the Commission. I think the Commission did what it was supposed to do, and I would like to thank the incredible work done by the chair Younous Omarjee, by the rapporteurs Andrey Novakov, Constanze Krehl, Agnes Jongerius, and in those names I’m complimenting and thanking all the teams that in a very cooperative way and in a very convergent way were able to bridge differences. In fact, they improved, together with the Presidency, the initial proposal from the Commission and I thank you for that. So let’s go on working together. There is a lot to be done. This is just, as you mentioned, the first step to transforming the immediate support into a more prolonged and a more stable, more green, more balanced and more digital, recovery of Europe.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Constanze KREHL
text: Writing. – React-EU is the first programme of the Cohesion Package to be adopted. Through the Corona Building Fund, React-EU will provide EUR 47.5 billion for the coming years to help Europe's regions respond to the crisis consequences: to preserve jobs or support the self-employed, to strengthen health systems, to small and medium-sized enterprises, not least in the highly affected sectors of tourism and culture. Particularly good: all these projects can be supported retroactively from 1 February 2020. This will allow the regions to support their actions to deal with the Corona crisis with EU funds almost retrospectively. Also important: especially in border regions, people felt the Corona restrictions very much when borders were closed again. I am therefore pleased that we have highlighted these border regions. Here, React-EU should help to restore lost confidence in the EU. I am also pleased that we have been able to achieve a stronger link with the Social Fund and the Youth Employment Initiative. In doing so, we are ensuring that React-EU will invest a lot in the social sector. The money from React-EU can be used quickly and unbureaucratically – so the programme lives up to its name: the EU is responding to the Corona crisis, as the people and the regions rightly expect.

name: Rovana PLUMB
text: in writing. – The S&D Group has always been at the forefront for a swift and meaningful EU reaction, showing that the European Parliament is ready to step in and properly address the pandemic and its consequences for the benefit of our citizens. Throughout negotiations, we have always focused on the social component of REACT-EU. Additional resources need to go especially to youth employment, education and skills, social inclusion and health. And in doing so, we must make sure that no disadvantaged group is left behind. Health, tourism and culture are also areas where special attention will be paid. We fought hard to keep a balance between regions – the ones most affected by the pandemic and the less developed ones – which are at the core of the cohesion policy. Therefore, it’s time to promote new jobs, competitiveness, sustainable and inclusive growth for driving the recovery process. To achieve this, funding must reach our regions immediately and it is necessary to develop the knowledge how best to use these funds. I am confident that REACT-EU will provide the additional funding for the most important sectors to contribute to green, digital, and resilient crisis-repair measures through a variety of EU instruments and funds.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Next point Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy: The latest developments in the Eastern Partnership countries (2020/2883(RSP).

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, before starting today’s debate, I would like to thank Parliament for its continued support in what has been one of my main personal commitments since I took office, the adoption by the Council of the European Union Global Human Rights Sanctions Regime.  I think this is a landmark achievement. It’s a first, strong step forward. It is evident that human rights are at the Union’s core and in our DNA, and it signals the European Union’s strong determination to stand united in their defence. We will surely have the opportunity to discuss it more in detail on a few occasions, but I would like to take this opportunity to thank you again for your support in getting this important initiative through and then I hope that the Member States will be able to use it because, once you have a tool, you have to take it out of the toolbox and use it. Now let us turn to the recent developments in the Eastern Partnership. The Eastern Partnership was established 11 years ago. Since then, it has consolidated as a useful and relevant framework for the benefit of both the European Union and our eastern neighbours. It has offered closer political associations and economic integration with the European Union. It has also been key in supporting sustainable reform processes, including the rule of law, although I have to say that progress has not been linear and it is very different from one country to another. It has had a tangible impact on people’s lives. I think we should be proud of advancements in mobility, growing trade with the European Union, and improvements in digital and energy cooperation. We have achieved a lot despite the challenges faced by our partners. The last year and especially these last months have been particularly difficult and have put all of us to the test. We will for a long time be facing the consequences of the pandemic, which has shifted our priorities. Several of our partners have experienced conflicts, fighting and repression, unrest and popular demand for democratic values and reform. You know what I am talking about. In this time of challenges, the need for cooperation becomes stronger and the partnership with the eastern countries enables us to address these common challenges and provide a platform for dialogue and exchange of best practices. The Eastern Partnership forges an area of shared democracy, prosperity and stability with our neighbours in the East. It must remain at the top of the European Union agenda. It’s in our interest.  Our partners have made demands. For them, the European Union remains the most trusted foreign institution in the region, as our opinion polls show. Strength and resilience is the main objective and core element of the future partnership policy as set out in the joint communication in March. We will work with our partners on five areas of resilience: economic, democratic, environmental, digital and societal.  I think it’s key to empower civil society and independent media to increase accountability, to expose corruption and to enhance critical thinking. There is no hidden agenda behind this approach. We are only guided by the values we believe in – free, open societies based on human rights and the fundamental rights of citizens. Our reflection in the future also encompasses how to make sure that the partnership remains strategic, ambitious, effective and flexible. The partnership is designed to offer flexibility to develop more advanced relations with those who wish to do so, but it also has to remain inclusive and not to leave anyone behind.  We need to stress the great potential of the current bilateral agreements, notably the association agreements and the deep and comprehensive free trade areas with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine.  In recent months, we have engaged in a comprehensive dialogue with partner countries, Member States, civil society and a wide range of stakeholders on the future shape of the Eastern Partnership. I think there is a strong consensus that the framework has delivered, and they can be proud of many achievements, but many challenges remain.  The implementation of practical and concrete activities will be the result of this debate and I will conclude after listening to all your observations and  remarks. I think it is a very important debate. Our Eastern Partnership is one of the most important things we have to deal with because our stability, security and even economic prosperity depend closely on how these countries are performing.  So thank you for this opportunity. I am looking forward to listening to your remarks.

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the European Union has a huge transformative power to influence in a positive way developments towards democracy, stability and prosperity in its neighbourhood. This is the EU enlargement and integration promise. That is what we in the Baltic States faced 20 years ago, and we are grateful. Now it is time for the Western Balkans. The Eastern Partnership countries deserve the same, maybe a little bit later. It’s a pity that from the EU side we are still not able to promise a more clear vision of Eastern Partnership integration, and that creates unnecessary frustrations and a loss of hopes and dreams in those countries. But what we can do is to show where, in which place, the Eastern Partnership countries are on their road towards integration. Let’s start to produce regular evaluation and benchmarking reports; let’s compare not only the Eastern Partnership countries among themselves, let’s compare Eastern Partnership and Western Balkan countries on their path towards integration. Comparison will bring a sense of progress and perspective and also dynamism of competition. That is what is very much needed for the Eastern Partnership region.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, High Representative, it’s a really good moment to discuss this topic today, with the next Eastern Partnership summit planned to take place in spring next year. As the objective of this summit is to agree on new common objectives, I wish to particularly emphasise two aspects of utmost importance: violations of fundamental freedoms and human rights as well as conflict settlement. Here we primarily speak about unacceptable events in Belarus connected to the latest presidential elections. I’m very happy that tomorrow this House will present the Sakharov Prize to the democratic opposition of Belarus. It’s important to maintain the Eastern Partnership as the framework to increase bilateral and multilateral cooperation and create positive spillover effects among the countries. At the same time, I believe we need a more determined approach towards violations of the joint commitments and the principles and values of this partnership. Regarding the latest context in Nagorno Karabakh, we have to play a more active role in the post-conflict environment. The European Union should not be excluded for settlements of conflicts in its neighbourhood. In the context of the ongoing discussions of so-called strategic autonomy, what we need is more strategic responsibility. The European Union must take responsibility for the promise of security and prosperity in the common neighbourhood which constitutes the basis of the Eastern Partnership too.

name: Urmas PAET
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the last few months in the EU’s eastern neighbourhood has seen some of the most serious political and military crises. Belarus is in turmoil for the fifth month now. There is an intensifying crackdown on peaceful demonstrations, arrests and torture. In this situation, the EU must halt all cooperation with the government and redirect assistance to the opposition and civil society until new and legitimate elections take place in Belarus. Another sudden explosion of a fully-fledged military conflict in the Nagorno-Karabakh region took the EU by surprise. Fortunately, a ceasefire has been brokered, but the EU’s role was very limited. Whereas Moldova, Ukraine and Georgia appear to be more stable, it is noteworthy that they went through a complex electoral season, and while the process appears to have been reasonably well managed in Ukraine and Moldova, the aftermath of the parliamentary elections in Georgia is, of course, of serious concern. The political parties in Georgia should resume dialogue with the aim of reaching an agreement, so that all members of parliament would work in the parliament and adopt electoral and judicial reforms in the interest of Georgian citizens and EU-Georgia relations. The aim of the Eastern Partnership is to work towards achieving political association and economic integration to promote well-being. We need to rethink our approach to conflict resolution, enhancing civil protection, promotion of international law principles and countering hybrid threats. In light of this year’s developments, the Eastern Partnership needs to be re-examined to ensure its efficiency in the future.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, Mr Borrell, if I were superstitious, I would end up believing that the Eastern Partnership is bad luck. Founded in 2020, following events in Georgia whose wounds are still unhealed, the Eastern Partnership goes from disappointment to disappointment. From the implosion of Ukraine in 2014 to the painful clash between Armenia and Azerbaijan in recent weeks, the least that can be said is that the Eastern Partnership, for the moment, has not achieved peace.  It is even certainty for the countries that are members of it that they are increasingly interfering with the European Union in their affairs. In Moldova, we see that, in the end, subsidy agreements depend at times on the outcome of the elections. In Belarus, the European Union has decided to take things to the next level and, to hear some of our colleagues, an internet poll is now enough to choose who won the presidential elections.  But I don't think it really matters. When we are satisfied with having a foreign policy that applies sanctions, I would like to ask you, Mr High Representative: what was the result of these sanctions? Russia has been under sanctions since 2014. Now it is Belarus. Seriously, does any of us think it's going to change their minds? The answer is no. We have never seen sanctions bend a country.  Is it not time for another dialogue? For I believe that, within the European Union, all our nations are equal, but some make financial and human efforts to maintain an independent foreign and military policy. Others, obviously, have decided to follow NATO's instructions. As such, hearing eminent figures of the German CDU reject the very idea of strategic autonomy from NATO gives a real picture of reality.  That is why we cannot be satisfied with this Eastern Partnership, which, in fact, is indeed an instrument for distributing aid in these countries, but which unfortunately, for the past ten years, has not produced any real concrete results.

name: Markéta GREGOROVÁ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the year 2020 has been turbulent for our eastern partners, and the Eastern Partnership has become more unstable than ever. We have had Belarus cracking down on peacefully-protesting citizens, increasing polarisation in Moldova, a democratic backslide in Georgia, Ukraine’s constitutional crisis, and the revived war in Nagorno Karabakh – Armenia and Azerbaijan blaming each other for the ceasefires and attacking civilians. The status quo kept for years brought the violence again, which is never a way for peace. There is a need for serious debate about the future. Nevertheless, regarding the issues in the Eastern Partnership, I am more disappointed in the EU’s approach and so-called common foreign and security policy. We have 27 foreign and security policies, and it shows in our incapability of doing more than these hearings and occasional sanctions. We must have a more substantial, better—united foreign and security policy that will stand behind human rights. Without it, we might just start to call ourselves the European Economy Community again.

name: Witold Jan WASZCZYKOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab A year of geopolitical Commission is passing, unfortunately, without success. We are not in the Libyan conflict, we are not in the Syrian conflict. In the Persian Gulf, progress has been made as a result of the actions of Israel and the United States, but not the participation of the European Union.  So have we been more active with the Eastern Partnership partners? Nor does it. We did not exist in the Armenian-Azerbaijani conflict. There, Russia and Turkey took on the issue of restoring peace. There have been positive developments in Moldova, but also not under the flag of the European Union. In Ukraine, they are increasingly counting on NATO support, not the European Union. Belarus is fighting for democracy under its national banner, but not under the banners of the European Union. The European Union is therefore not becoming a magnet for attraction.  So will the Eastern Partnership continue to be an eternal waiting room, or will it evolve? Will we offer sectoral cooperation? Will we finally dare to raise the issue of membership? So will we multiply the conditions for cooperation that even our members sometimes do not meet?

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the way in which she has It is difficult to take stock at the end of the pandemic year. The transformations of societies are not complete, and the domestic and foreign policy challenges are enormous. The ceasefire between Armenia and Azerbaijan remains fragile. In Georgia, resolving ethnopolitical conflicts through Russia's interests and the EU's inconsistent policy seems more than difficult. In Belarus, despite large and courageous demonstrations by the people, there is still no easing of the situation. The European Neighbourhood Policy is undoubtedly complex, but it is clear that our support for the democratic, social and economic development of these countries must not present them with confrontational developments. Rather, this partnership must allow them dialogue and cooperation both with the EU and with the Russian Federation. Encouraging here are the clear statements and plans of the newly elected President of the Republic of Moldova. Maia Sandu has presented a comprehensive political and social programme with a consistent focus on the rule of law, the fight against corruption and democratisation. Let us help it by set an example in all 27 Member States.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the history of the Eastern Partnership and especially for the peoples of the South Caucasus, it is not inappropriate to recall the enormous suffering caused by political violence, dear High Representative. Our programmes have contributed to the well-being and growth of this society with the main aim of stopping this spiral. Current events show us, however, that this progress is unfortunately reversible and that the only way to defend it and bring prosperity to society is, of course, a peaceful way. Recent developments in Nagorno-Karabakh, the violent repression of Lukashenka in Belarus and the EU's operational difficulty in the face of their deployment are a clear sign that the EU needs to rethink the instruments of the Eastern Partnership Programme. In Nagorno-Karabakh, the conflict has once again been frozen by a truce useful to the hegemon powers of the Caucasus – Russia and Turkey – in order to consolidate the new influence, but it has further scars and wounds between Baku and Erevan. Resolving this dispute, resolving the democratic transition in Belarus is an important effort, it will require a Europe that can best play its role as mediator and champion of dialogue and multilateralism. Our will must be unanimous, not the functioning of our instruments.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: – Madam President, dear colleagues, I never believed it could happen that, due to my parliamentary activities because I try to protect the rights of the Hungarian minority living in Ukraine, I have been included on a so-called death list of the Myrotvorets website as an enemy of Ukraine. However, it happened, and the problem is even more serious, as it is not just me who is attacked because of raising a voice for the protection of the Hungarian community, but the community itself faces constant political pressure, attacks and intimidation. I often stress that there is a huge problem with the respect for fundamental minority rights in Ukraine, especially how the Hungarian community is treated. In November there were several cases of hate speech against the Hungarians; then, armed commando units of the Security Service of Ukraine delivered a coordinated attack against the Office of the Cultural Alliance of Hungarians and the home of its leader and a charity. The harsh actions were based on fabricated accusations to restrict the operation of these organisations and to intimidate the Hungarian minority. Honourable High Representative, I would like to ask you to take concrete steps and call on Ukraine to close down the Myrotvorets website and to ensure the protection of the Hungarians living in Ukraine and persons who stand up for human and minority rights.

name: Marina KALJURAND
text: – Madam President, I should like to say to the High Representative that it’s very symbolic that we are discussing the Eastern Partnership today, on the eve of awarding the 2020 Sakharov Prize to the democratic opposition of Belarus.  2020 was a difficult year. Our eastern partners faced serious and unforeseeable challenges. Therefore, today more than ever, they expect – and rightly so – political commitment and resolute actions supporting their democratic processes. Eastern Partnership policy has not failed, but it needs reinforcement.  As the Chair of the Delegation for Relations with South Caucasus, I have had regular contact with my partners and colleagues, but I also know how important it is to talk to people, civil society and human rights activists. Today, I discussed the human rights situation in Nagorno—Karabakh and, more widely, in Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia, with the women’s rights organisation Kvinna Till Kvinna (‘Woman to Woman’). As this is most probably my last intervention this year, I would like to conclude with what they said to us parliamentarians: ‘do not forget ordinary people, especially minorities, when taking political decisions’.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Borrell very much for the human rights sanction mechanism. Finally, I should say.  The stability of our neighbourhood is key for our security, so we need a strong Eastern Partnership. We all agree on that. But how do we get there, that’s the fundamental question. What the situation in Nagorno Karabakh and Belarus have in common is the inability of the EU to have a meaningful influence. It’s not just that we are too slow or too divided. No, we just don’t have any political clout. Geopolitical ambitions, yes, but power, no.  And so we continue our financial support, yet at the same time we leave the fate of the region in the hands of Putin. Putin’s troops are in Nagorno Karabakh, his military advisers and media experts in Belarus. And where are we? The EU needs to take a more proactive, direct and leading role. But most importantly, if we want our eastern neighbourhood policy to succeed, we need, Mr Borrell, to complement it with a new, more effective EU-Russia strategy. Time to make work of it.

name: Bernhard ZIMNIOK
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report The Eastern Partnership has been in existence for more than ten years. More than EUR 1.3 billion has so far been invested in stabilising state institutions to bring them closer to the EU standard. Apart from a few small successes, however, the balance sheet is rather sobering. Take the example of Ukraine: as early as November 2019, I drew attention here in plenary to the system, which is still rife with corruption and Soviet structures. Ukraine, for example, has signed the Hague Convention on child abduction, but has never implemented it. Children abducted by a parent to Ukraine are still being held there, the perpetrators are covered by the authorities and court decisions are ignored. A conversation I asked for and also promised with the Ambassador of Ukraine on this subject never materialised. The EU must finally make its support conditional. In this case, this means: no implementation of the CKU – no subsidies or visa-free travel!

name: Viola VON CRAMON-TAUBADEL
text: – Madam President, this year has been extremely intense everywhere, particularly in the Eastern Partnership region. Besides fighting the pandemic, the Eastern Partnership countries also had to deal with many other challenges. Moldova managed to elect a pro-European President. Ukraine conducted successful local elections only to backslide on fighting corruption and other crucial reforms on rule of law. Georgia, unfortunately, trapped itself in a dangerous political crisis. Therefore, we urge all political parties to resume the dialogue in order to uphold the national interest.  However, nowhere has the year been as violent as in Belarus, Armenia and Azerbaijan. The EU continues supporting the people of Belarus and their democratic government in fighting against terror until freedom and justice will prevail.  Dear fellow Europeans and our neighbours in Belarus, we stand with you until the very victory. The Sakharov Prize to the democratic opposition is one of the most visible signs of solidarity from this House in order to honour your striving for freedom. In Azerbaijan and Armenia, the EU should realise its vital role for bringing peace, engage actively in reconstruction of the region, and make sure that the reconciliation leads to prosperity for both countries.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: – Madam President, Azeri soldiers beheaded two Armenian civilians while they were alive: Genadi Petrosyan and Yuri Asryan. They tortured Armenian civilians and prisoners of war; desecrated corpses, churches and tombstones. While Turkish and Azeri troops marched victoriously through Baku, Turkey’s aspiring Sultan, President Erdogan, revered the souls that committed the Armenian genocide – the Islamic Army of the Caucasus. Armenia’s capital and several provinces were declared Azeri historical land by Azerbaijan’s dictator, President Aliyev. Azerbaijan, ladies and gentlemen, is an EU Eastern Partnership country, which means we shower them with EU funds. That needs to stop. Instead we need sanctions against Azerbaijan and Turkey for their neo-Ottoman war of aggression.

name: Dorien ROOKMAKER
text: – Madam President, the Eastern Partnership aims at bringing peace at our eastern borders but to countries which have neither the ability nor the will to adopt western values, and the EU does not have the power to impose values or political views. If you take on responsibilities without having the authority and power to act, you are heading for failure. The actions of the European Union in the Eastern Partnership countries, especially the injection of funds, may in fact lead to instability, because it provokes people to fight among each other over funds. Ten years of partnership has not led to stability at all and that’s terrible. Money can be a solution but it often is a cause of problems. The 72 million people who live in the Eastern Partnership countries will receive EUR 1 billion to soften the coronavirus crisis. This is almost EUR 14 per person. Will this really help, or will it create new problems? Let’s stop this nonsense and start dealing with our neighbours in a mature and respectful manner. Stop sending money for nothing, which only destabilises the countries and enhances corruption.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, High Representative, five of the six states in the Eastern Partnership have more or less frozen conflicts and troops of the Russian Federation on their own territory. The inefficiency of international forms of negotiation has given separatists time to strengthen their illegal statehood, and the Russian Federation time to strengthen its military presence at the borders of the European Union and NATO. Looking at the map of the region, we find that the Russian Federation has created through frozen conflicts an arc of offensive military resources around the Black Sea. We are planning strategic autonomy, but we tolerate Russia's aggression on our borders. The Eastern Partnership will not bear the expected fruit unless we do three things: 1. through diplomatic action, to acquire the legitimate right to be a party to all formats for negotiating frozen conflicts; 2. military consolidation of the eastern flank by deploying European Union troops at the eastern border and 3. a strong partnership with NATO to regain military balance in the Black Sea. These things will ensure stability for the countries of the Eastern Partnership.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, we need a coherent approach towards Eastern Partnership countries that violate joint commitments. We all know that these things are not going well. Let me mention only the situation in Nagorno-Karabakh, about which we have to very concerned. The ceasefire brokered by the Russians in November sent a positive signal, but lasting peace, including agreement on the status of the region, still needs to be negotiated. Both sides in the conflict recently accused each other of ceasefire violations, but there are also many human rights violations. For example, you need only take the mistreatment of the Armenian troops captured during the conflict. We have to call for the immediate release of all the detainees. I have to say that I’m afraid that it’s not enough for the European Union only to follow the situation and to support the Minsk Group. The EU must take the responsibility and contribute more actively to long—term conflict settlement in the Eastern Neighbourhood. The role of Turkey and its support of one of the sides in the conflict creates a serious threat that may ultimately be counterproductive to long-term peace in the region.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, frankly speaking, I miss the EU’s geopolitical ambition, strong determination and full engagement in the Eastern Partnership. Renewed military conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh, its devastating outcomes and the ceasefire agreement confirms the fact of a reduced EU geopolitical presence in the South Caucasus. Neither the European Union nor its Member States were a part in reaching the political solution. The mere fact that the conflict involved two participants of the EU’s Eastern Partnership Initiative demonstrates the shortcomings of our foreign and security policy. We lacked the timely political initiative, necessary tools and strategic vision. Election of the pro-European President Maia Sandu in Moldova is a long-awaited event that returns hopes about implementation of most needed reforms. Her promise to fight against corruption and free the state from oligarchic rule needs to be reinforced with EU support. Moldova received a historic opportunity and it would be too disastrous not to seize it.  Awakening of the civil society in Belarus, its desire to democratise the state and start the reform process places even higher expectations on the EU’s Eastern Partnership policy. Let’s be vigorous and strong in supporting Belarusian democratic opposition.

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Madam President, the European Union hoped in 2009 that this Eastern Partnership, which includes Azerbaijan in particular, would enable the establishment of common values of democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights. This circle of friends, as the former President of the Commission Romano Prodi wished, was to be born thanks to the miraculous virtues of free trade. Today, Azerbaijan and its president occupy by force a territory that history has wanted Armenian, and every day that passes brings its share of massacres, looting committed by Azeri troops and militiamen. The conquering and belligerent Turkish President Erdogan can unashamedly say that Azerbaijan's historic struggle against Armenia is not over.  It is time, Madam, to suspend as soon as possible all the benefits granted to Azerbaijan as part of our foreign policy, starting with the visa facilitation agreement. If Europe is so concerned about its gas interests, which is why it refuses to raise its voice, it therefore courageously defends its Member States in the Eastern Mediterranean in the face of Turkey's repeated aggression.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, recent developments in Eastern Partnership countries call for a strategic European policy towards the region. We can see that the political scenes remain highly volatile. We must take into account the drafting of new objectives post 2020. The initiative that offered full cooperation to the Eastern Partnership countries has advantages. However, we must put our common security and the security of our citizens in these countries higher on our agenda. Breaking a ceasefire in the brokered peace in Nagorno-Karabakh is one of these security concerns. I call on the European Union to closely monitor the implementation of the peace agreement between Armenia and Azerbaijan. Humanitarian assistance should reach those in need and citizens should be able to return peacefully to their homes. We also have to ensure the protection and preservation of cultural and religious heritage sites in Nagorno-Karabakh. Since the ceasefire, both Armenia and Azerbaijan have accused each other of breaching the agreement. We must look for a means, in close cooperation with the co—chairs of the Minsk Group, to find a role for the European Union to broker a permanent ceasefire in this troubled area.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, we have always been committed to our neighbours in the East, but one thing must be very clear: our commitment is to the people, and wherever a dictator actively steals elections, throws peaceful demonstrators in jail and even tortures his own citizens, whether this is in Belarus or Azerbaijan, our relations should be with the people alone. Tomorrow we are awarding the Sakharov Prize to the female-led Democratic opposition of Belarus, and it is with them that our relations must be. Strong words are not enough. The Belarusians have been protesting for four months now, and Lukashenko is still there with the support of Moscow. More than 32 000 people have been detained. There are more than 4 500 serious allegations of torture and several people who have been killed or disappeared. We can’t simply look away and allow this to continue. The people of Belarus rightfully expect firm action. We have to seriously step up the sanctions to include all state companies and oligarchs, who are the lifeline of an illegitimate dictator, to hurt those who repress and torture peaceful demonstrators and finance Lukashenko, and at the same time, of course, step up all technical, financial and political support to the Belarusian people. We will not rest until all political prisoners are freed, perpetrators brought to justice, and free and fair elections are held. It is the right of the people of Belarus and the whole Eastern Partnership to decide on their own future and direction, and we will always defend that right.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I am talking about the Eastern Partnership as a Member from a country that, more than 10 years ago, proposed this programme to the entire European Union. As the previous previous ers have said, the picture of the situation in the partner countries is mixed. We have war, frozen conflicts, repression, corruption, but we also have the struggle for freedom, the development of trade and the triumphs of democracy. The temperature of the Eastern Partnership debate in this House shows that it has become a key element of our neighbourhood and foreign policy.  Mr High Representative, I know how difficult it is to influence events in other countries, but I want to tell you that all these voices are voices of support and concern, and that the population first of Ukraine, then of Belarus and now of Moldova, is a great victory for the Eastern Partnership. Please continue your efforts, and I just hope that the Member States will loyally support a common policy.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you all very much for your contributions; I appreciated them, in particular the last one, that of Mr Sikorski, who has made a summary of the picture. Certainly, problems are not lacking. We have wars, we have dictatorships, we have stolen elections, we have situations of deep instability, we have corruptions that do not end or do not end—because they are the ones who have to do it—they have not just eradicated. I am not saying that the situation is particularly positive— and you know it — but it would surely be worse without this Association. Listening to some of you, I thought I had the impression that, for some, if you're not able to put troops on the ground, then your action is worthless. Well, I'm sorry to tell you, just in case you don't know: the European Union is not going to put troops on the ground. We're not going to be like Turkey; as you said, there has been support or military intervention. Are you suggesting I do the same? When you call for stronger, more determined, more energetic action, what do you mean? No, we're not going to intervene militarily. You better know and don't ask the apple tree for pears. We can do what we can do and we're doing it. We're not a military alliance.  We work from the fields of cooperation, diplomacy, support for civil society with our financial resources. We may be able and should take action using the instruments we have in the commercial and economic fields. But let me remind you that we invest a lot of money in this Association. I'm not going to give you a recital here of all the figures. Some of you have quoted them. Ukraine, for example, is the country that receives the most aid from the European Union. With COVID-19 we have accelerated and increased our financial support.  Yes, I know there has been a war between Azerbaijan and Armenia. And what have we done to stop it? Well, the tasks that give diplomacy and financial resources. We don't have any others. We have no others; please put your feet on the ground.  Tomorrow and the day after tomorrow we will have the agreements of the meetings of the Association Councils with Armenia and Azerbaijan. And of course we will raise the problems that you, with good judgment and reason, have raised here, of the abuses that have been committed in this war. And we will continue to commit ourselves to support with the means available to us for peaceful conflict resolution, to continue to combat bad governance practices, respect for human rights, freedom, progress and everything in our objectives.  Do not believe that we can solve the problems of these countries in ten years, which are the ones that the Eastern Partnership is of age. But we can't underestimate what we've done either. We can't be that negative either. The situation would be much worse if the European Union had not been an active and committed partner and funder of political and economic transformations in these countries.  Our support for Ukraine has been critical. And our approach to what has happened in Belarus is fundamental to supporting Democrats in Belarus.  Yes, I would like to collect complaints regarding the situation of the Hungarian minority in Ukraine, of course. Disclosing personal data on this website Myrotvorets is completely unacceptable and we have already requested that this content be removed and we are in contact with our counterparts in this field. Of course, we have been talking to the Ukrainian authorities and Hungary to resolve their disagreements quickly, constructively and with respect for minorities. We know and intervene as we can to defend the situation of minorities and, in particular, the situation of the Hungarian minority. Ladies and gentlemen, your criticisms are very stimulating and I assure you that I would like to have magic wands to solve the problems you pose. I don't have them. What I have are the Union's financial and diplomatic resources. We use them with all our energy and capacity. And I hope with your support; rather, surely counting on your support.  We have to keep insisting. This is not an easy task. The situation in these countries, after the decomposition of the Soviet Union, could hardly be imagined to be resolved in ten years. We must continue to provide them with committed support, but we cannot pretend to act as others do. We reproach them for doing it, but we're not going to imitate them. We can't, we can't.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – The situation in Belarus continues to be dramatic. Despite the efforts of the European Union and other political factors involved, President Aleksander Lukashenko continues the crackdown on the protesters and there is concern among the population that, in desperation, the Belarusian dictator will allow Russia to be actively involved.  The situation remains extremely tense in Nagorno-Karabakh, where the Azerbaijani regime is accused of not respecting the truce and humanitarian efforts are hampered. The EU will therefore have to reconsider its approach in the region, so as not to allow governments involved in open conflicts to violate the common principles and values of this partnership. We also need to keep our promise and therefore the EU needs to be more actively involved in finding long-term solutions to peace, stability and safety.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – In Ukraine today, systemic intimidation of Hungarians in Transcarpathia is taking place: in recent days, armed commandos of Ukrainian national security have invaded Hungarian organizations in Carpathia, including the institutions of the Hungarian Cultural Association of Transcarpathia (KMKSZ), which is ethnically represented by Hungarians, and the home of the president of the association, László Brenzovics. Over the weekend, our MEP colleague Andrea Bocskor was added to the mirotvorec list of the extremist right-wing grouping 'enemies of Ukraine', putting her life in danger. The series of violations is very long, and these are just the latest episodes of a long-running anti-Hungarian-minority policy aimed at intimidating Hungarians and their leaders in Transcarpathia, in addition to making the activities of Hungarian organizations in Ukraine impossible. This level of intimidation of national minorities anywhere in the world is unacceptable, but it is much more serious if it takes place in a NATO and European Partnership country wishing to approach the European Union. Human rights are part of minority rights, as the European Union is calling for everywhere in the world, and should also be held to account in Ukraine, not turn a blind eye to serious infringements – for geopolitical reasons.
