Political pressure and intimidation against Hungarians in Ukraine is an unacceptable method, which, especially in this part of Europe, evokes bad memories and creates fear, and therefore requires a strong resolution and the prospect of sanctions.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Eastern Foreign Policy of the European Union under the Neighbourhood Policy, the Eastern Partnership, aims to deepen political ties and economic integration with Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine.  Today, its formula, which was created between 2008 and 2009, needs to be updated. Recent developments in the region – especially in Belarus and the South Caucasus – pose new challenges. At the same time, they demonstrate the need to maintain the strategic importance of the European Neighbourhood Policy, especially in the context of aggressive Russian policy in the region. It is worth recalling that when the Eastern Partnership programme was created, Russia received a proposal for cooperation, which it did not benefit from. However, not only Russia, but also a number of other forces, would like the EU not to deal with eastern topics. Historically, he can be criticised in part because he has not had much success, perhaps because he did not have enough money. The positives are association agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. In this context, it is worth mentioning a new regional initiative, the so-called Lublin Triangle, for deeper cooperation between Ukraine, Poland and Lithuania. It is an idea for a format for political cooperation between EU countries and non-EU countries, but belonging to the Eastern Partnership. We would like it to be a quadrilateral that includes Belarus, because we cannot afford to give up cooperation with Minsk.

name: Janina OCHOJSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Eastern Partnership Programme, which involves closer political cooperation and greater economic integration with the 6 partner countries of Eastern Europe and Transcaucasia, has been in place, among other things, thanks to the efforts of the Polish Government since 2009. During this time, some partner countries have started to implement the internal and systemic reform process.  Ukraine clearly took a pro-European direction, and due to the failure of then President Yanukovych to sign an association agreement with the EU, numerous protests began that led to the creation of Euromaidan. A few months later, Russian aggression led first to the annexation of Crimea, and then by regularly supporting the separatists, to the outbreak of war in the Donbass. Since August this year, thousands of Belarusians have been taking part in peaceful demonstrations, despite the many forms of repression they are subjected to, due to the falsification of the results of the presidential elections in Belarus, who want to change their country's direction to a democratic one. On 27 September, an armed conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan erupted again in Nagorno-Karabakh, which had been frozen for several years.  These are just some of the problems that partner countries face. I believe that further EU involvement can be more effective and effective, and that actions aimed at cooperation and dialogue can have better results. Efforts to support these countries in various areas should continue, especially now in the context of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Next item statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy: Worsening of the situation in Mozambique [2020/2910(RSP)]

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable members, the crisis in the northern part of Mozambique is already causing more than half a million displaced persons and more than two thousand dead, and we , the European Union – continue to seek to help through the humanitarian axis, development and peace-building, defending human rights at the heart of our response.  As if that weren't enough, Cape Delgado, one of Mozambique's poorest provinces, with a tremendously fragile social structure, was devastated by Cyclone Kenneth in 2019. This only aggravated a situation that is now complicated by the extent of terrorism coming to them from the north, from Somalia.  We have specialized teams working on the situation in Mozambique; we have ongoing contacts with the Government and international institutions—the United Nations, the African Union, and the United States. We have allocated one hundred million through a resilience programme signed with the Government to respond to the socio-economic consequences of COVID-19, and, of course, we are ready to consider providing more resources. But this year, we have already contributed 37 million in humanitarian aid, priority to Cabo Delgado. We are strengthening cooperation with all countries in the region, combating the impact of human trafficking, which will unfortunately increase with this situation, and helping to implement the Maputo Peace Agreement between the Government of Mozambique and the Renamo. But the outlook is not positive, ladies and gentlemen: the situation in Mozambique deteriorates in the protection and heat of natural disasters and a country with very serious difficulties of government.  In reality, it is the entire facade of the Horn of Africa towards the Indian Ocean that is being the scene of an extension of conflict and the spread of terrorist forces. We're very concerned about the situation.  There does not appear to be any improvements in the Somali area to the south; recent tensions between Somalia and Kenya are not going to help either. But, within Mozambique, we need to take surely stronger measures.  I have asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Portugal , a country which will assume the Presidency shortly - to move to the region as my personal envoy, as I cannot go for agenda reasons. And I have asked you, as a colleague of the Council, to pay particular attention during your Presidency to what is happening in that country , which Portugal is well aware of.  That's what I can tell you; I can't bring you many positive elements. Just be a sure that we mobilize all the resources we have to act in Mozambique.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. " Mr High Representative, your statement here is proof of what we already knew. The European Union's external action service is not up to the humanitarian crisis in Mozambique. You do not have time to go to Mozambique, You are not able to see what resources have been given to the Region of Cabo Delgado, continue to talk about hurricanes, continue to talk about the peace process, this is what I heard the External Action Service bring here on July 6, knew nothing about Cabo Delgado.  The Cabo Delgado crisis is an autonomous crisis, totally different, with other characteristics, where women are being raped, where young people are being recruited for radical Islamist terrorism, where people are driven out of villages, where there are more than half a million refugees in the most coastal towns and cities where the crisis of sanity is brutal. I haven't heard of health care here. No logistics teams? Aren't there teams of doctors from the European Union who are going to Cabo Delgado at this time? With malaria? Cholera? A COVID? Is there no accommodation to take to this region? Mr High Representative, the European Union is failing and the responsibility is yours in the first place. I am sure that the Portuguese Presidency will play its part, but the European Union cannot vote Mozambique for ostracism as it has been doing since you held this position and I am aware that this crisis has existed for more than 3 years.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Mr High Representative, I thank you for having been present at this debate and that, with your intervention, you have made a commitment that the European Union will be part of the political and humanitarian solution to the conflict in Cabo Delgado. I also welcome the appointment of the Foreign Minister Portuguese as special envoy.  The indifference of the international community to the situation has generated a deafening, chilling, incomprehensible silence. The European Parliament has positioned itself at the front line of denouncing the situation and the demand for action from both the international community of institutions and the Mozambican Government. These warnings have helped to wake up the international community and strengthen the Mozambican Government's commitment to a solution. The UN and the European Union have strengthened their aid and cooperation programmes. Any intervention on the ground by the United Nations has now been considered. The Community of Southern African States has also scheduled a summit. Portugal, which will assume the European Presidency from 1 January, has decided to support the training of Mozambican military personnel, as well as the logistics of its armed forces, giving an example of action that should be emphasized. As relations between the European Union and Africa are deepening in a promising way, I welcome the European Union's new attitude to the conflict in Cabo Delgado. It's about time, Mr. High Representative. We must now turn this attitude into more action.

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, first of all, Mr Borrell said things don’t look good in Mozambique and in Cabo Delgado especially, and the situation is worsening, and I thank Mr Rangel for describing the situation and I would like to add that since the urgency resolution we discussed here in the plenary, several hundred people have been killed. On 9 November, 50 people were beheaded – just to remind you of the situation at the moment in Mozambique. You said that you are using all means that are at your disposal to help in that country, but as colleagues already said, at this moment, you cannot even reach the most vulnerable and I would like to ask you: you said that you want to explore the possibility of more resources. That’s good. But how do you want to reach those in need of help? Today even doctors cannot go there. What do you want to do to help those people?

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, High Representative Mr Borrell, I would like to thank mr Borrell for his work on this In my view, the situation in Mozambique can be very aptly demonstrated by the example of Andre Hanekom, a South African businessman who worked in Mozambique and died in police custody after having previously been arrested and detained by the Mozambican army. Mr Hanekom was accused of supporting the Islamist rebels in Cabo Delgado. These insurgents have been guilty of heinous crimes, including the beheading of villagers who stood in the way of their machinations. There is no doubt that these rebels really do exist, and they pose a serious threat to the state of Mozambique and the region beyond. And – Mr Borrell, you have just mentioned it – the terrorist influence from Somalia is being added.  However, as Mr Hanekom tragically learned, parts of the police and army in Mozambique are using these insurgents as a pretext to suppress all opinions in Cabo Delgado that deviate from the official line. These dissents include opposition to the development of offshore gas fields – one of the largest deposits in Africa – and to the forced purchase of land from the local population directly related to the development of gas fields. Add to that the exploitation of mining resources to extract precious stones, rampant corruption, and the presence of private militias – including the temporary emergence of Eric Black – all the ingredients for a humanitarian catastrophe are united.  Mr Hanekom did not want to sell his property. Influential groups wanted to force the sale. Mr Hanekom had partners who also pursued mining interests in Cabo Delgado. The Islamist uprisings are the result of the exploitation of Mozambique's natural resources and the marginalisation of the local population. This is the result of corruption in Africa, which usually always follows these things on the foot.

name: Pierrette HERZBERGER-FOFANA
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Mozambique is alarming. More than 450,000 people have been forced to flee and abandon their homes. These internally displaced persons suffer from permanent insecurity, lack of access to basic care and, of course, the trauma that results from this conflict, often seen as a targeted measure to depopulate economically attractive areas of land. I would like to highlight the particularly precarious situation of women, girls and children during this conflict, a situation on which we must absolutely focus. Unicef's latest appeal on the situation in Mozambique, which was published yesterday, mentions that violations of children's rights continue, with reports of killings, abductions, abuse and ill-treatment of girls and women. Cases of gender-based violence continue to increase. Overcoming and finding multi-level solutions to address or mitigate this conflict without interfering should be the norm and be consistent with our own objectives.

name: Assita KANKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Islamic militants linked to ISIS in Mozambique’s gas-rich northern province Cabo Delgado are becoming bolder. The extrajudicial executions, burning and looting and destruction of schools and hospitals is also extending to Tanzania. Since 2017, this Islamic terrorism has killed more than 2 200 people in this country. There are almost half a million internally-displaced people depending on international aid for food and basic needs.  This humanitarian catastrophe must come to an end. The civilian population must be protected – urgently – and human rights violations must be investigated and punished. Gas resources should be used for the development of the region and to create the much-needed employment. The EU must contribute to humanitarian aid and the de-escalation of this conflict. We should also seriously consider why the EU so often underestimates this type of geopolitical threat – the proliferation of jihadist violence is deliberately disrupting African societies and becoming a push factor for migration.  If the EU is serious about its geopolitical role then regional crises with a potential global impact, such as this, must be at the top of our EU-Africa agenda.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, Mr High Representative, the Republic of Mozambique has been confronting terrorist mercenary groups who are responsible for very serious acts of terrorism against the Mozambican population, particularly in Cabo Delgado province. Strongly condemning the actions of these terrorist groups, we also denounce the interests behind this new destabilisation operation against Mozambique and its people and aimed at the appropriation of resources that are essential to the economic and social development of the Mozambican state.  We therefore reject any instrumentalization of the situation in Cabo Delgado to pave the way for interventionism and neocolonial postures that disrespect the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Mozambique. The Republic of Mozambique has the inalienable right to defend its sovereignty and integrity by mobilising the necessary means, including in the framework of international cooperation, to protect its people, territory and resources.  Any support for Mozambique must respect its sovereignty and institutions. From here we express our solidarity with Mozambique, its people and its struggle.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: Madam President, Mr High Representative, I take your words to tell you that I am not here to ask you for a magic solution or a magic wand. I come to ask you simply for a reply to the request for aid sent to the European Union by the Mozambican authorities and, to that effect, I ask the European Union to complement the Portuguese response in supporting the training of the Mozambican military forces and in supporting their equipment and to provide a strong and active response to the humanitarian aid that is needed on the ground at the moment. We must not forget that there are more than half a million displaced people. People who do not have any kind of shelter, who are without access to water, who are without access to medicines and who are without access to food. An urgent response to this need must be addressed. But we can't just get by the emergency responses. It is up to us to go to the root of the problems, inequalities, poverty and lack of expectations in the future, even though this country has the greatest gas reserves, which has been fertile ground for jihadist radicalization.  European multinationals should abandon the logic of pure extractivism and take on their environmental responsibilities and contribute to the sustainable development of the countries where it operates.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Madam President, the abuses of the Islamist group al-Shabab in Cabo Delgado are part of a wave of terror that, from Africa to the Middle East, vehemently represses Christian communities. Everywhere, the consequences are the same: the closure of schools, which mortgages the future of the younger generations, and the uncertain fate of thousands of internally displaced people. As I keep saying, there are more than 300,000 of them in this part of Mozambique. Also at stake is Africa's economic rebound. In a world plagued by the health crisis, in Cabo Delgado, it is not only the titanic project of liquefied natural gas exploitation, essential to the whole region, and in particular to the department of Mayotte, which is compromised, but also traditional activities such as fishing or growing cashew nuts. However, it would be premature to mention any European intervention without first playing with regional integration. From the Government of Mozambique to the Southern African Development Community to the African Union, it is the responsibility of all the leaders of that continent to demonstrate in fact its capacity to respond.

name: Francisco GUERREIRO
text: – Madam President, dear Representative, first of all I would like to recall the important speech of the Bishop of Pemba, Bishop Luiz Fernando Lisboa, who presented by videoconference at the meeting of the AFET committee on 3 December the humanitarian urgency situation experienced in Mozambique, where terrorist attacks have left thousands dead and displaced.  We must put aside, for now, the political debates and long-term strategies because Mozambique is facing an emergency situation, also taking into account aggravating factors, such as the situation of COVID and the next rainy season in the region. So, Mr Borrell, I specifically ask you what more resources you were talking about in your intervention to help Cabo Delgado and the Mozambican authorities? Finally, I call on the European Commission, Portugal and the other Member States to intervene urgently now to help Mozambique restore security in the region and ensure the arrival and distribution of humanitarian aid. We need a rapid, concrete European response for the good of Mozambicans and to restore credibility to the European Union's global capacity for action.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are going to highlight what we are doing.  We have given priority to humanitarian aid to Mozambique.  The Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (ECHO) has allocated more than 14 million humanitarian aid in Mozambique this year. Five million have been dedicated specifically to the population affected by the conflict in the area. For us Cabo Delgado is an area of priority action, but think that demand for aid has grown exponentially in recent months.  In May, the United Nations anticipated that it would need EUR 35 million and are now asking for EUR 250 million. Surely they need them, but our budget is not expandable like a balloon in which it blows. We don't have 250 million euros available; if we had them... You also asked why we are not more active, as always, and why we do not send aid that the Government of Mozambique has requested.  Well, things aren't that clear. We are waiting for the Government of Mozambique to give us the green light to send a mission of security experts, who have been appointed since November and ready to leave for Mozambique as soon as they authorize us. There have been discussions with the Government, which doubts whether it prefers our experts or prefers bilateral relations with some countries of the European Union.  We have done our homework: we have exchanged letters and petitions with the Government of Mozambique and our experts are willing to move there, they are appointed! We just need to be authorized.   But look, let's not close our eyes to reality. You know her very well and have participated in this debate because you know and care about her. But Mozambique is a country that is mired in a deep financial crisis, with a debt level exceeding 110% of its gross domestic product; which has only been maintained thanks to the massive help of international donors; which has had serious corruption problems and government-wide business takeover problems. The International Monetary Fund has stopped its financial aid programme and the international community has diminished its Community support.  Nor can it be said that everything that happens in Mozambique, as some say, is a simple extension of the movements of terrorism called Islamist. Well, it's partly true; armed violence in northern Mozambique has been, from the outset, driven by rising poverty and inequality and detachment from a state that cannot bring basic goods to the population. But there are governance problems, there are traffic problems; there are problems...  Think of Mozambique as a country that has one hundred cubic trillion cubic natural gas – proven reserves – is the third largest natural gas reserve in Africa, after Nigeria and Algeria. You can imagine that this poses a sense of alienation for citizens, of saying "we are a rich country and we live in poverty", and their expectations are frustrated by a lack of development and misgovernment, or serious problems of government.  We are there to help to the extent of our capabilities, but Mozambique's needs go much further from the operational capabilities that our budget gives us.  I say to you with this the same thing I told you before regarding your demands for muscle interventions in Armenia and Azerbaijan: we have what we have, and what we have, we use it. And if suddenly the needs are multiplied by ten, my budget is not multiplied by ten.  We are ready to send missions, but we need the government to accept them.  Yes, I don't have time to go everywhere. I don't have time to go to Mozambique because either I couldn't travel or, when I travel, I have to attend to other needs. And I do not think it is a bad idea for the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Portugal to assume, on my behalf, the presence in Mozambique — Portugal is the country that will hold the Presidency — just as I have asked the Minister of Finland to go to Ethiopia, and I will continue to ask my colleagues in the Foreign Affairs Council to help me in the international representation of Europe, because I cannot be everywhere. But they can help me—and a lot—and thus help create a more common foreign policy, more appropriate for all countries, because they participate in it.  And I hope, I am sure, that the presence of Minister Augustus, my friend Augustus, in Mozambique will help us to know reality better and to further promote cooperation with the Government and to further guide our resources, which are always scarce for the many needs that have been expressed in 2020, with COVID-19 and without COVID-19. In Mozambique is not a COVID-19 problem, but COVID-19 has aggravated it. It is a chronic problem of lack of good governance, development, poverty and inequality, and armed conflict. And all this can only be resolved through concerted action with the international community, of which the European Union participates to the extent of our capabilities.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The following point is a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy: The 25th anniversary of the Barcelona Process and the Southern Neighbourhood [2020/2918(RSP)].

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, 25 years ago, I was there. The Barcelona Declaration set the goal to create an area of peace and shared prosperity around the Mediterranean. The Barcelona Process is 25 years old. What have we achieved and what are the remaining challenges and our priorities for the future? Well, I don’t want to be gloomy today, but I have to say that the situation in our southern neighbourhood has in some aspects worsened. We haven’t achieved some of our objectives, and the challenges have been growing faster than our collective response to them. Let’s face reality. The challenges have been growing faster than our capacity to respond to them.  In defining our response, we are not starting from scratch. We have a vast array of political dialogues and grassroots work undertaken over the last 25 years with the Parliamentary Assembly of the Mediterranean, which you are now chairing. It was created during my mandate as President of this House and is an extremely valuable institutional framework, but we have to seize the new opportunities, the need to build more resilience and to fight the pandemic, and to increase trade and boost development. We had a ministerial meeting with our southern neighbours in Barcelona last November and this discussion gave us some ideas that I would like to convey to you. First, we need to have an inclusive approach as we develop greater economic autonomy. Some prefer to say sovereignty. I don’t mind what it is, but it needs to be more engaging on climate change and digitalisation. We use these two words so much that we are going to lose them. Second, we need an investment plan, building on the success of the External Investment Plan, but the needs are so big that we cannot expect to fulfil all of them with public money. We need private engagement to create jobs, especially for youth.  We should answer the calls of these countries. It’s time to act. We need to speak with one voice. Often we don’t do that and we pay the price of our divisions. I want to stress the need to focus our help on their youth. They need a peaceful and prosperous future. The demographic trends show them becoming younger and younger at the same time that we are becoming older and older, and this is going to create a gap that will push migration. The only way of facing that is to boost development at the same pace. But we don’t have adequate funding. We must admit that we don’t have enough resources from the national budgets. We absolutely need to develop private investment.  Finally, most of the regions cannot be addressed only bilaterally. They have to increase their regional and subregional cooperation. Only 5% of the trade among the countries of North Africa is trade among themselves. They don’t trade among themselves. At the same time, the gap in revenue per head is increasing. I think it’s now ten times higher in the north than in the south. If you compare both trends – the trends on revenue per head and the trend on demography – it is clear that we are going to create a big incentive for migration that, I repeat, can only be faced by increasing massively investment in the region. Then there is more bad news. The price of oil has been decreasing, and for some countries which depend a lot on oil exports this has created a big structural deficit on their public accounts. If it is just a matter of the conjuncture – a couple of years – they can resist, but if it becomes a structural issue and the price of oil remains low for a long period of time then the economic situation will be unsustainable. This is one of the consequences of the big shift that climate change policies will create on the wealth of nations. The stock of oil is a wealth that depends on its price, and its price depends on demand, and demand depends on the climate policy that we are going to follow. So we have to be ready to help diversify the economies of some of these countries and so they are not strongly dependent on oil exports, as is the case for some of them.  In any case, we have to be more committed to our partnership with the Mediterranean. It has to be stronger than ever because it is needed more than ever and, 25 years after the Barcelona Declaration, in Barcelona in November, all the states from the northern and the southern Mediterranean represented there reaffirmed this commitment. I am sure it will have the help and the support of the European Parliament.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Mr High Representative — Mr Borrell - today I have to say that today I agree with you, which I am sure you will appreciate. I totally agree. And I believe that this European Union, I believe that these institutions need to be much more aware and pay attention to the phenomena that are happening in our southern neighbourhood. Just as Mr Borrell, I and many of our Mediterranean colleagues pay attention to the pressing problems that are happening in Belarus, Moldova, Ukraine, I ask my colleagues and, above all, the President of the European Parliament , which is also Mediterranean - to pay more attention to Morocco's problems, to the problems of Libya , Tunisia. Finally, countries and situations that are currently making the European response, the fight against terrorism, immigration, the economy very complicated at the global level as well. These are all issues on which we have to work from this European Union.  And do not doubt, Mr Borrell, that the European People's Party and I will support you in all that this matter can be extended.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Mr High Representative, yes, the 25th anniversary of the Barcelona declaration creates a momentum for an in—depth reflection on European Union strategic objectives and engagement in the region. This anniversary also comes at a time of great disruption for the region, compounded by the unprecedented global health crisis with severe economic and social impacts. The COVID—19 pandemic is a stark reminder of the need for tangible and coordinated cooperation across both shores of the Mediterranean. In this context, it’s crucial to relaunch and strengthen strategic relationships with the Southern Neighbourhood countries. We are looking forward to the joint communication on the renewed partnership for the Southern Neighbourhood. It’s crucial to reinforce common bridges and elaborate solutions to transform traditional and new challenges into opportunities for both sides of the Mediterranean. Lastly, we have to create strong synergies with the NDICI instrument and to ensure that this instrument will be able to provide adequate support for shared priorities and creation of area of prosperity.

name: José Ramón BAUZÁ DÍAZ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, Mr Borrell, when the Barcelona Process began in 1995, the European Union set very ambitious objectives: firstly, the promotion of human rights, democracy and the rule of law; secondly, the fight against terrorism, organized crime and drug trafficking and, finally, economic and social development, in particular the fight against youth unemployment.  Twenty-five years later and hundreds of millions of euros later, Europe is still far from achieving these goals and faces new challenges that it cannot respond to, as is the case with the geopolitical struggle that other powers do wage on our southern flank.  But how will Europe achieve its objectives, if it is not able to defend its most basic interests?  Mr Borrell, to this day, one of the most important partners in the European Union continues to challenge with impunity the sovereignty and territorial integrity of a Member State. And I don't mean Turkey; I am referring to Morocco, which, in recent years, has overthrew sovereignty over Spanish waters in the Canary Islands and has narrowed the fence over Ceuta and Melilla.  The first condition of all foreign policy is geography. Europe cannot therefore afford to ignore the southern shore of the Mediterranean. We need to continue working on a Euro-Mediterranean policy that solves common problems. But how are we going to advance good governance, human rights in the region, when the foundations of respect for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of a Member State, such as Spain, fail in our relationship?  That is why, Mr Borrell, I ask you: what are you going to do to ensure that Moroccan respect for Spanish sovereignty is a priority for the European Union and an inexcusable condition of our relations?

name: Anna BONFRISCO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you, High Representative for your introductory statement, today we are celebrating another historic stage of Europe for the Mediterranean, made up of light and shadow, Mr Borrell.  As you think of Barcelona, the seat of the Union for the Mediterranean, I am thinking of the Treaties of Rome of 1957, which were considered the birth certificate of the European family, and I am therefore thinking of the red thread that unites Rome and Barcelona as capitals of Europe and the Mediterranean.  Together, therefore, we want to plan for a more sustainable and just future, along the paths of respect for the environment, development, culture and modernity, and we must be able to do this by working on strengthening economic governance and attracting important private investment, but there are also shadows, Mr Borrell.  We call for joint action against trafficking in human beings to be developed synchronously against organised crime, terrorism and irregular immigration, both from the areas of origin and transit, because the continuation of these trends will always prevent the region from making progress and will force European citizens to pay too high a price. And before that comes the human dignity that we find at the beginning and end of every individual's life.  And yet many countries in this area are not so inclined to respect human dignity in the name of state reason. This is the most important appeal we can make today as we celebrate Barcelona, postponing a future in which together we will be protagonists of respect, freedom and human dignity.

name: Salima YENBOU
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, we have a very poor record of our policy towards our neighbours to the south. Lack of ambition, political will and institutional creativity - in short, a minimum service for the Euromed area. A little help, a lot of lenient speeches, and above all an accommodation with a generalized authoritarian drift and a blatant diplomatic absence. Of course, the European Union cannot be held responsible for the tragic failure of democratic impulses, but it should have done its part to talk to and support the people. Mr High Representative, dare to dream with me of a Euromed policy that lives up to the current aspirations of our neighbours and the challenges of tomorrow. I dream for both sides of a grand plan that would put social, culture, environment and values at its heart, that would target young people and peoples rather than worn and delegitimized elites, that would make our Mediterranean a sea of exchange and hope rather than a graveyard of migrants and their dreams. Finally, let us put our diplomats at the service of a decisive contribution by the Union to the shamefully prolonged conflicts in Palestine and Western Sahara.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, Mr Borrell, thank you very much; actually, you're right in this case. Almost everything is worse right now than in 1995. Twenty-five years ago democracy had enormous prestige, had just passed 1989, Europe had been reunified, communist regimes had fallen, and we really believed that democracy was also going to move to other areas.  Today we know this has not been the case. We have seen that weakness, and in large part the message of weakness that Europe has given, has been one of the factors that has led to this destabilization that has taken place in large regions of the Mediterranean, and which affects us so much.  Not just the population explosion, not just this massive illegal immigration that is taking place that can destabilize us and that use other powers against us, as is the case with Turkey.  We have seen a deterioration in relations with many countries. We have seen Iran, which is a threat, peeking into the Mediterranean through Syria. I mean, we're much worse off than in 1995.

name: Manu PINEDA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Mr Borrell, the Barcelona Process is twenty-five years old and we must look at how the situation in the Mediterranean has changed. To be sure, for multinationals, for those who benefit from infringement of rights, exploitation and slavery, it has been a success, but I wonder what progress has been made in terms of human rights, peace and stability, which was the objective.  You acknowledged, in your initial intervention, that progress has not been what was expected. I want to focus on three examples—there could be many more, but I don't have time.  Israel, a privileged partner of the European Union, receives, thanks to the Barcelona Process, more than 170 million euros per year that help perpetuate the occupation of Palestine, funding, for example, military research. This year the record for new illegal settlements has been broken and its response has been to try to revive the Association Council – a curious way of punishing those who violate international law on a daily basis.  Libya had the highest rate of human development in Africa, according to the United Nations, until NATO, with our help, destroyed the country to keep its resources. Today the war remains active and, with the excuse of migration control, Community policy is based on funding armed militias that create migrant concentration camps and slave markets. Finally, Morocco, another of our preferred partners, continues to consolidate through the facts the occupation of Western Sahara and the expoliation of its natural resources.  The European Union legitimizes these policies and benefits from them with trade agreements.  The Barcelona Process has been a big deal for many multinationals and for some governments. It is in our hands, Mr Borrell, to give real priority to human rights and make them the central axis of our foreign policy, and not to leave them in a nice paragraph.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: Mr President, Senyor Borrell, the Barcelona Declaration is the result of a clear vision and commitment to the future of the entire Euro-Mediterranean region.  Twenty-five years later, as you said, expectations are far from being met. We are lagging behind on some critical issues and, with a few exceptions, the regression is dramatic. The Mediterranean has become a great mass grave where the hopes of thousands of human beings are lost, not the reference to peace, stability and shared prosperity that we had conceived and promised.  This failure is also our responsibility, perhaps because today Europe does not have the moral authority it had 25 years ago, but also because of its paradoxes. Barcelona, the capital of Catalonia, which gives its name to the declaration, has been the scene of the most ferocious repression that a European Union state has inflicted on millions of citizens who simply wanted to vote for the past three years. And when the European Union is silent on these abuses, its voice cannot have the strength it should have in the face of the threat to freedom in the region.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, Mr Borrell, the Barcelona Process was an ambitious initiative, the objectives of which have unfortunately not yet been achieved.  But much has changed since 1995. The States concerned are more numerous and more heterogeneous and the situation in the Mediterranean is more complex by a number of factors: economic crises, the rise of Islamist terrorism, the birth of the Union by the Mediterranean below the expectations created, the so-called Arab Spring, the serious situation in Syria and Libya, the refugee crisis and irregular migration , in short, Turkey's defiant nationalism.  And while, in Brexit Europe, anachronistic populism and radical nationalisms increase, as we have just heard. But the European Union must give priority to the Mediterranean and its many challenges. It is essential to strengthen the dialogue with our southern neighbours and to relaunch the idea of a Euro-Mediterranean free trade area, which was the great economic objective of the Barcelona Process for the economic and social modernization of the south bank.  I hope that the forthcoming joint communication - I think by this spring - from the Commission and the European External Action Service will be truly ambitious and takes into account that stability and prosperity in the Mediterranean are really essential for Europe.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Barcelona Process is an opportunity to reflect on the results achieved, on the great difficulties encountered and on the current state of the process that wanted to make the Mediterranean a common area of peace, stability and prosperity, through means of dialogue, cooperation and social and cultural encounter.  Unfortunately, today, twenty-five years later, we have to say that instead of looking at that area – the Mediterranean – and imagining it as a place on which to build bridges and development, we have seen it as a source of problems often to be hidden like dust under the carpet and the results are unfortunately before everyone's eyes. We must not be satisfied, which is why I believe it is necessary to start from the ambitious expectations of twenty-five years ago and to restore to the Mediterranean the centrality it deserves. That is where the challenges of peace, security, the fight against terrorism, respect for rights, environmental protection and positive and truly supportive management of immigration are at play.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: Mr President, dear Joseph Borrell, 25 years ago the Barcelona process set high ambitions for the Euro-Mediterranean partnership. Twenty-five years later, his birthday is held in relative discretion. However, the efforts have been made, projects have been carried out. But the current situation calls for both modesty and greater determination.  To modesty, because our common sea is crossed by crises. The enthusiasm of the Arab Spring has often waned, human rights are too frequently violated, the place of women insufficiently recognized. The Syrian tragedy, the Libyan crisis, the tensions in Lebanon and the eastern Mediterranean are taking place just a few steps from Europe. We need to do more and do better.  The crises in the southern Mediterranean all have consequences in Europe. We have a deep interest in more democracy, more stability, more exchanges between our civil societies. The European Council has just raised this. So, Mr High Representative, I ask you: let us rediscover the spirit of Barcelona, which I have no doubt is dear to your heart. Whether we are from the north or the south of the Mediterranean, we not only share a history, we have a destiny in common.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, 25 years into the Barcelona Process, our assessment cannot be positive. The Mediterranean is too much a space of divergence rather than integration, of huge socio-economic disparities instead of shared progress, it’s a deadly place where migrants drown, much to our shame, and it’s one of the places that will be hardest hit by climate change. As the challenges are too great not to address them, it’s time to revive the spirit of Barcelona and move the Mediterranean agenda forward, an agenda that should focus on specific projects that bring about economic progress and reform, but also on issues of democracy, human rights and the fight against corruption. As the Arab Spring showed, but also the ongoing protest, many people in the southern neighbourhood hope for both economic and political inclusion. Our focus on stability and security tends to forget those very legitimate aspirations, and in the end, we all know that there won’t be any real stability on the shores of the Mediterranean without social progress and political openness.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, there is no other way but cooperation in the Mediterranean where the challenges are most acute, from climate change to migration flows, pandemic issues and security issues. As chairman of the Political Committee for the Mediterranean, I confirm that we need resources to work constructively in energy-focused cooperation in the Mediterranean and with common rules on international law and respect for the sovereignty of states.  However, I have to be honest. Turkey's policy of appeasement against neo-Ottoman expansionism is not met with verbal condemnation. It requires leaders in the European Union who put the interests of the European Union and its principles above the state interests of their countries. Failure in this area is obvious, not because there are no tools, but because there is no such leadership. This will be recorded as a black page in history and the outlook for all of us is huge.

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: Mr President, Mr High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, this is a stark statement on this anniversary. The so-called "pragmatic" approach of the European Union is deplorable. With 60,000 prisoners of conscience and a poverty rate that has jumped by nearly 30% since 2015, the Egyptian example is painful. There is an urgent need for human rights to once again become the foundation of our cooperation, enabling the development of sectoral programmes à la carte. It should also be remembered that the effectiveness of a commitment lies only in its ability to punish violations. The coherence of external policies is not embodied anywhere. Today, despite the supposed fight against immigration, terrorism, investment and arms sales are thriving, regardless of all considerations. Europe must contribute to a prosperous and peaceful Mediterranean future. Let's no longer turn a blind eye, let's end our criminal migration policies, support a redistributive and inclusive green economy!

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, High Representative, now that twenty-five years of the Barcelona Process are coming is a good time to remember that in the sea, the Mediterranean Sea, our hopes and our tragedies have always been intertwined. But it was twenty-five years ago that we decided to place the Mediterranean agenda at the heart of the Union, intensifying our cultural, human and socio-economic cooperation with the vocation of building an area of security, prosperity and peace.  The truth is that, after these twenty-five years, the objectives are also far away and we have added new ones: new conflicts in Libya and Syria, rising inequality, the migration and refugee crisis and climate change — I would like to remind you that the Mediterranean will be the second most affected area in the world after the Arctic — all of them challenges that we want to address from respect for the 2030 Agenda , as a guide and map to address them.  But today I would like above all to vindicate the Union for the Mediterranean, the institution that was born twelve years ago and which also welcomes Barcelona, which finds in this process — and I finish — its international vocation and its willingness to be a city to intertwine cultures. Strengthening this institution is the best we can do for the Barcelona Process.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to make use of the words of Nathalie Loiseau to sum up this debate. We need to be modest and to be ready to engage more. Modest, because certainly the results are not good enough. And I’m not going to repeat the long list of problems that we have, but at the same time we cannot not put value on what we have been doing, because we have been doing things, and we have to build – continuous building – on the things that we have been doing in the past years and at the same time recognise that, yes, okay, the situation is not as good as we could have imagined 25 years ago, but let me put value on some examples. I’ve been talking about the European investment plan. We put 4.5 billion from the European Union budget and we succeeded in raising 44 billion of investment by 2020. That’s a good result. You will say that’s not enough. No, that’s not enough, for sure, but with 4 billion, we succeeded in raising 44 billion. And now we have been allocating, by June this year, 5.1 billion of European Union funds, and we have already generated ten times more in investments, which means 50 billion in public and private investment for development. We have created universities, like the Mediterranean University in Fez, to educate a new generation of young people with a Euro-Mediterranean vision. We have in training more than 100 000 young people and supported the development of over 1 000 small and medium firms. That’s not enough. No, that’s not enough: we have to continue. Yes, you have to continue. But I think that we cannot solve by ourselves: it is up to the people of these countries to solve. We can support, we can help, we can accompany, but there are problems that have to be solved by the people according to their interests and their will. Sans aucun doute, la Méditerranée est la première de nos préoccupations – et il faut encore plus en faire la première de nos préoccupations. Il n’est pas possible que le revenu par tête continue de diverger entre le nord et le sud. Il n’est pas possible qu’on soit toujours devant une région qui n’est pas du tout intégrée, avec des barrières qui empêchent un développement régional. Oui, tous ces problèmes sont là. Mais ce que je peux vous assurer, c’est que la volonté ne manque pas et que le Parlement, la Commission et le Conseil doivent unir leurs forces pour faire de la Méditerranée une mer de développement conjoint, de démocratie et de prospérité économique. C’est notre principal devoir. Si nous n’avons pas de succès dans cette politique-là, alors où aura-t-on du succès?  Dans quelle partie du monde devons-nous nous sentir plus engagés que dans notre voisinage le plus immédiat, pour éviter un fossé culturel, un fossé économique, un fossé générationnel, démographique? Je peux vous assurer que, comme je vous le disais, la volonté est là. Parfois, les ressources manquent, mais il faut augmenter notre engagement. Comme disait Nathalie Loiseau, il faut aussi beaucoup de modestie, parce que les résultats sont maigres, et beaucoup de volonté de s’engager, parce que les besoins sont grands.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on – the oral question to the Council on the Council Recommendation on Vocational Education and Training for Sustainable Competitiveness, Social Justice and Resilience by Lucia 'uri' Nicholsonov', Maria Walsh, Marianne Vind, Ilana Cicurel, Elena Lizzi, Kim Van Sparrentak and Anna Zalewska on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000068/2020 - B9-0027/20) (2020/2767 (RSP)) and – the oral answer to the Commission on the Council Recommendation on Continuing Education and Training, social justice and resilience of Lucia Suri Nicholsonov, Maria Walsh, Marianne Vind, Ilana Cicurel, Elena Lizzi, Kim Van Sparrentak and Anna Zalewska on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000069/2020 – B9-0028/20) (2020/2767(RSP)). I would like to point out to Members– as you are used to – at the beginning of an item on the agenda that there are no spontaneous requests for speeches in all the debates in this part-session and, unfortunately, no blue cards can be accepted by me. In addition, it is possible to switch from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Lucia ĎURIŠ NICHOLSONOVÁ
text: author. – Mr President, I have a few questions for the Council and also for the Commission, for Commissioner Schmit and for Mr Roth. First, the COVID-19 crisis has accelerated the need to improve digital training solutions and ensure equal access to digital skills, tools and technologies for learners, teachers and trainers. Through what measures and with which financial and non—financial means, will the Member States promote digital upgrading and distance learning in vocational education and training (VET), while ensuring accessibility and acquisition of the necessary skills for all? How does the Commission intend to support the Member States in this, and how can this be coordinated and monitored together with the Member States? How will the Member States ensure equal access to the internet and to digital schools and all the digital tools in all schools? The Council recommendation provided for the number of quantitative objectives to be achieved by 2025. What measures will the Member States take to meet the objectives and how can the quality framework for apprenticeship and the Erasmus programme help to achieve them? How will the Commission support the Member States in achieving these objectives? How will the Commission monitor progress in achieving these aims and how will it relay this information to both Parliament and the Council? How will the Member States and the Commission improve the tracking of VET graduates?  There is a lack of coherence and discrepancy between the VET sector and the general education system, with VET often being considered as the less preferred option, despite the constant demand for more vocational professionals. What are the Member States and the Commission doing to boost the attractiveness of VET, and to ensure coherence and synergy between the two? What are the Member States doing at national level to improve the communication on VET, and what is the Commission planning at EU level to improve the communication on VET? What measures are the Member States taking to bring VET dropouts back into the system? What measures will the Member States and the Commission take to ensure that VET programmes are of high quality, are inclusive and offer equal opportunities to all, in particular to vulnerable groups and people living in rural or remote areas? What actions will the Member States and the Commission take to make quality and inclusive VET a right for all learners, as enshrined in the European pillar of social rights? How will the Member States and the Commission ensure that apprenticeships are of high quality and are diversified and tailor-made? What the Member States do to ensure a fair remuneration for apprenticeships and access to social protection? Does the Commission intend to review the European framework for quality and effective apprenticeship?

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this for the Council, on an issue of outstanding importance. Let me say this as a representative of a country where dual education – a close partnership between state/state schools on the one hand, businesses and the economy on the other – is the key to the lowest youth unemployment in the whole of the European Union and also the key to well-paid, decent, demanding, but also fulfilling work. I am grateful to all those who contribute to the fact that, despite our national competence, we also follow the principle of 'learn from each other, learn from each other' in order to strengthen vocational training.  What I also notice in many conversations is that there is still a very strong focus on academic education. Nothing against academic education. But it is important that young people, whether they want to pursue a career after school or then pursue an academic career, have the chance to meet social acceptance, that, above all, vocational qualifications are open to all – people with disabilities, but also people who have no chance of access in the light of their background or the financial circumstances of the families from which they come – and that there is no discrimination and no discrimination. And I would like to emphasise this in the recommendation that vocational training programmes must be inclusive and accessible to disadvantaged groups. The Council adopted the important recommendations on vocational training for sustainable competitiveness, social justice and resilience only a few weeks ago. There is also a special obligation for us as the European Union to act, because, according to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, everyone has the right to education and access to vocational training and further training. There is still a great deal of room for improvement here, and I also have the impression that the so-called European Skills Agenda and this recommendation have really given impetus to this debate – in the interests of young people, no matter where they live in the European Union and what their background is.  We believe that flexible and resilient vet systems can compensate for disruptions and turn threats into opportunities. In our statement, we said that while vocational education and training enables citizens to adapt to change, it should also enable them to shape change. It has just been expressed in the introductory words: the dramatic change in digitalisation is also creating fear. Many are worried and wonder: is this training, this qualification, still worth it? Or: Do I have the opportunity to master this qualification at all? That is why it is important that we make workers, young people, actors who are not just waiting for something to be put before them. I was particularly impressed by what we have launched as a joint declaration. Let me mention one last point, because it is one of the great success stories of a united Europe, namely the mobility of young people. Through Erasmus+, we have created the conditions for hundreds of thousands, even millions, of young people to have a chance to learn, work and live in another European country. But it is primarily a program for the academic elites. It is true that 1.5 million VET learners and staff have benefited from the Erasmus+ mobility programme for two decades now. But that is still too little for us, we need to go more broadly. We must also encourage young people who want to pursue vocational training and qualifications that it is worth getting to know Europe. This is also a good instrument against prejudice, stereotypes and resentment. That is why, in the Recommendation on Vocational Training at EU level, we have set ourselves a target that 8% of VET learners should benefit from learning mobility abroad by 2025. I am very pleased that this debate is also helping to bring the opportunities of vocational training to the fore. I would like to thank all those who are helping to strengthen and strengthen the role of the European Union in this important test. Here, close cooperation between regions, Member States, but also the European Union, is more imperative and more necessary than ever.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for putting vocational education and training in the spotlight, and thank you for the support you are expressing in your resolution on the new Council recommendation on that. Let me also thank the German Presidency for their continued support during the negotiations on this recommendation, and particularly also for the adoption of the Osnabrück Declaration, which really identifies vocational education and training (VET) as an enabler, and I quote, ‘an enabler of recovery and just transitions to a digital and green economy’. Already before the pandemic our workers, young and older alike, needed massive up- and re-skilling opportunities to tackle skills mismatches. The pandemic and the accelerated shift towards a digital and green future demand this even more, because workers need to acquire digital skills and those skills needed for the green transition. We can only achieve this if education and training systems keep up the pace and meet the needs of our economy of the 21st century. The VET recommendation puts this vision into action, and the Commission provides concrete measures and instruments to support Member States in modernising their VET systems, which the 27 Member States wish to do. Enhancing the digital shift in VET is at the core of our policy, because most professions are directly affected by digital transformations. Digital has become the engine of modernisation, flexibility and the attractiveness of the VET systems, and it contributes to their inclusiveness by opening up new digital learning opportunities for all. The Commission has developed EU-level tools for schools to reflect their own progress and the pathway towards digitalisation. We have established quality standards. We are enhancing and promoting exchanges of good practices between Member States in all these areas. Vocational education and training also mean apprenticeships; they are a particularly appropriate answer to tackling the rising youth unemployment and they facilitate precisely the transition between education and the labour markets. The Commission will reinforce support to good quality, diversified and tailor-made apprenticeships thanks to the new initiatives such as the renewed European Alliance for Apprenticeships and the recently launched pact for skills, which precisely brings together companies, Member States, governments, regional authorities, providers of skills and social partners. I am particularly grateful for increased European funding for all these policies. The increase in the Erasmus+ budget will significantly increase the number of learners and teachers and trainers benefiting from VET mobility – and mobility was pointed out just now. What is the rule for university students should also become the norm for VET learners and this is also an aspect: how to restore the value of VET to the same level as other educational forms.  Moreover, Erasmus will also invest in VET excellence, because lifting quality and making education systems more inclusive are fundamental dimensions of the Erasmus+ programme, and the platforms of centres of vocational excellence financed through this programme. Modernising VET systems can in particular be financed through the European Social Fund Plus, and through REACT and the Recovery and Resilience Facility. The Commission’s strategic guidance for the Recovery and Resilience Facility laid out in the annual sustainable growth strategy proposes upskilling and re-skilling as one of the flagship initiatives of the Facility. Unprecedented funds are available thanks to the good outcome of the MFF negotiations, and I urge Member States now to use them to invest in people. It’s a matter of Europe’s competitiveness and social cohesion alike.  Vocational education and training is also based on the cooperation of schools, learners, parents, employers, social partners, government authorities, regional innovation agencies, researchers and many more players.  We all know that, in principle, education is a national competence, but we need this European cooperation, and by the way, professional education was already in the Treaty of Rome. It was also initially an objective of the European Community, because it was understood that we need a good professional education to have a well-functioning common market.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, there is no doubt that vocational education and training is a key element of the education system and also of European lifelong learning. It is a fundamental piece for inclusion, for the development of active and cohesive societies, it strengthens democratic and also active citizenship. And, of course, it is essential to achieve the objectives of employment, competitiveness and the objectives of the social pillar of the European Union.  But, indeed, after the pandemic it faces challenges. One of the challenges is the digital challenge, the ecological challenge and also the demographic challenge. We will have to work in a coordinated way so that no vulnerable sector is left out of these challenges and we can all have access to that technology. The pandemic has also been a very hard blow to all, but especially to young people, and especially to vulnerable sectors. Distance learning has increased school drop-out, especially for the collective of the most vulnerable, such as people with disabilities.  The European Union must make youth employment one of its top priorities. I therefore request a coordinated European strategy to make vocational training accessible, visible, attractive and effective, and to cease to be the Cinderella of education.

name: Marianne VIND
text: for the S&D Group. Mr President! When the winds of change blow, some are building hedgerows, while others build wind turbines, and the winds are blowing in Europe right now. Digitisation and the green transition place high demands on our ever-changing labour market. Digitalisation does not only create challenges. It is also an opportunity to create a sustainable green future. However, in order to build this green digital future, we need to focus much more on the wise hands and ensure a European workforce with strong professional skills and high-tech knowledge. That is why we must invest in our vocational training. Europe's vocational training must be an attractive choice for all, ensuring a high-quality education for all. We must ensure a much more common level of quality across Europe, thus fully including the pupils from the vocational schools in Erasmus Plus. Many more skilled workers are needed, and so we must also engage talented young women. And it even offers bonuses, because a better working environment occurs when both sexes are represented in the workplace. Anyone who wants an apprenticeship should be able to get an apprenticeship. Someone who is both with pay and dresses a good one for many years in the labour market. Now is the time to have the vision for a greener Europe. Because only with a strong skilled workforce can we build tomorrow's future. This is the time to build on the foundations of tomorrow's society. We therefore welcome the Council's approach. It clearly calls on all the Member States to take this important step and invest further in our vocational training. Let's get started. This is important.

name: Ilana CICUREL
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner Schmit, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to tell you about Kevin, an electricity student in the Paris region, whom I had the chance to meet between the two waves of COVID. He had just returned from professional mobility in Romania and when I asked him what he had gained from it, he replied with sparks in his eyes: "Never be discouraged."  Kevin has come back strong from this spirit of conquest, which we want every young European to have. And what gave him this strength was the trust that was placed in him, perhaps for the first time, through Erasmus. We want thousands of Kevins, millions of Kevins who travel europe, coming from our villages, our towns, our cities.  And yet, as you know, Erasmus mobility benefits too little for learners in the career path. Among our proposals, we encourage the development of a true status of apprentices in Europe. It is clear that we must go further if we are to make Europe an educational power, a real space for education for all our young people. There's an emergency. As with the university, we must start a Bologna process for the professional path.  Never before has training been placed so high on the European agenda. Making the career path a true path of excellence and the future must be one of the priorities of our Legislature. Today I want to send a strong message to all of our youth: Europe is here for you and you are here for Europe, because, armed with this spirit of conquest, you will be our pride.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. The fact that we are discussing vocational education today is important and crucial. It is crucial that the economy rises from the crisis. All issues here are strategic. From the fact that the vocational school is dual, that is, that the employer is in school and the school and the pupils at the employer, that the school is taught not only professional competences, but also soft competences, so that the young person can adapt to the changing digital reality all the time and throughout his life.  Revolution 4.0 is a fact. I am therefore pleased that the Commissioner is talking about digitalism here. Yes, she is very important here. Digitality for students, digitality for teachers and digitality for simulating all kinds of devices to make this learning practical. Of course, an industry language, an industry language, is important, which will ensure that mobility becomes a reality and there are no barriers.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: gue/NGL Group. Mr President! We need skilled craftsmen to energy-reseze our houses in the fight against climate change. We need a skilled caregiver to help our elderly and our sick. After a long period of shutdown here during the corona pandemic, I think we've all learned to appreciate a well-trained hairdresser or barber. Skilled skilled workers are essential to make our society work, and we need more young people to take up vocational training. All too often, unfortunately, young people run their heads against a wall during their professional training. The cuts to vocational training, the lack of traineeships are a huge problem. We must strengthen vocational training. This requires member states to invest in vocational training. This requires employers to be required to set up traineeships and this requires close cooperation with the social partners. Ladies and gentlemen, let us get started.

name: Daniela RONDINELLI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, dear Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I find it disconcerting to persist in wanting to tell our young people how beautiful and attractive an education and training system that is not really, compared to their future in work and in society, because it is a system sacrificed in recent years also because of austerity. This Council proposal risks remaining a dream book if we do not address some crucial issues: replacing 'recommendations' with legally binding acts; to create a European mechanism for the recognition of competences, going beyond bilateral agreements to ensure greater employment opportunities; digitize the entire system of vocational training, which not only means giving a tablet to each student, but accompanying him in digitized teaching; recognize lifelong vocational training as a right, to face the digital and environmental transition with upskilling and reskilling.  Finally, and most importantly, to restore working and social dignity to young people starting from professional studies, starting with a genuine European reform of apprenticeship systems, all too often these young people are poorly paid and lacking the minimum protections.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Vocational training must be seen as an essential tool to promote integration and social inclusion. Language learning is an excellent tool to strengthen this, as mobility suffers significant obstacles due to a lack of knowledge of languages. At the same time, knowledge of several languages is of great added value in the labour market. I would like to draw your attention to the link between inclusion and language learning. It is an excellent fact that, for the first time in Europe, a state-recognised language examination of Hungarian sign language can be taken from 1 July 2021 in my own country, Hungary, under a change in the law currently adopted. In addition, the concept of desicable sign language interpreter has been regulated at the legal level, thus enabling the birth of a new profession. I encourage you to push for this very important step in your own Member States. It is particularly important for young people, as vocational training will continue to play a greater role in the Youth Guarantee, and the Youth Guarantee is also a very good and effective tool for facilitating unemployment and the entry of young people who are exposed to social exclusion into the labour market.

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Lifelong learning and vocational training is not only an ambitious challenge, but also a necessary one. It is crucial for achieving social and economic objectives. 60 million adults in the European Union are low-skilled, 128 million have low levels of education. Therefore, it is very important to increase the participation of adults in lifelong learning. This increases their employability, for an adequate presence on the labour market.  Digital skills are becoming more important, but they are ageing faster than we are. We need to update them, keep up with them, and that's not easy. We should answer the following questions. Why does lifelong learning affect only a few? How do we support them financially? What is the territorial availability of forms of education? What is the attractiveness of these forms? How to increase the competences of learners so that they can better find themselves in the labour market?

name: Stelios KYMPOUROPOULOS
text: Mr President, Mr Roth, Mr Schmit, according to Cedefop's estimates, jobs requiring medium-level qualifications will continue to account for the largest share of all jobs in the new era of the Green Deal and digital transformation. In this light, the draft resolution on vocational education and training very reasonably makes it imperative to upgrade and modernise it qualitatively so that it can meet the new challenges.  We need better coordination with traditional vocational education systems, better interconnection with the respective systems of the other countries of the European Union, greater emphasis on the necessary horizontal skills, but also active participation of the social partners in the formulation of programmes. Clear personal objectives in terms of the percentage of graduates employed are also necessary, together with systematic monitoring of their results.  In conclusion, I would like to stress the need to make vocational education and training more attractive to young people. In Greece, for example, only 29% of young people aged 16 to 18 are enrolled in higher secondary vocational education programmes compared to 49% of the European Union average. To this end, the use of innovative practices, as well as the best use of apprenticeship, mobility and exchange programmes such as Erasmus Pro, are particularly important.

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, education and training – these are the central issues of how our society can and must develop further. However, training and training are not just needed for Erasmus+. Erasmus+ is important, no question, and it is right – and it is good. But we also need low-threshold offers – low-threshold offers, where we can also take young people who simply do not bring this know-how with them for Erasmus+. Otherwise, we depend on millions of young people, and we create social hardships in old age, because these people are no longer able to join in our society. We already have the problem that there is simply no cross-border adoption of various training criteria. Here, too, improvements must be made. We have the problem that continuing training is partly required in occupations, but cannot be provided – either because they are too expensive or because the intellectual know-how is also a bit lacking. In other words, low-threshold offers are urgently needed, and we need to compensate for the concentration of work by means of further training – because work is becoming increasingly complex, ever more complex, and increasingly difficult.

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Mr President, colleagues, vocational education and training are the key to overcoming the effects of the economic crisis linked to the Kovid-19 pandemic. They are the key to overcoming the backlog of the European economy from its main competitors.  There is no doubt that investment in vocational training is the way to strengthen small business, the middle class, innovative businesses, but we need to realize something else. Small businesses, the self-employed, the middle class have to go through the crisis. Their assistance must be granted so that they can benefit from these investments in vocational training and education in the near future. But here, three European countries, among them Bulgaria, do not provide any assistance for small and medium-sized enterprises, for the self-employed, for their middle class under the SURE programme, the main tool for experiencing the severe winter, which is just beginning.  We in the European Parliament, the Council, the European institutions as a whole need to give very clear guarantees that aid against The Covid-19 reaches those who need it most, those who suffer the most from the crisis, and across Europe these are the middle class, the self-employed, the family business.

name: Miriam LEXMANN
text: – Mr President, unfortunately, training is often seen as a kind of secondary option for young people who choose it on the basis of not the best school results. And yet that may not be the case. Training can become a sought-after option for employment when properly grasped, such as dual education. This is why it is necessary to increase its attractiveness, to introduce innovative methods of learning and to improve the equipment of schools. It is also very important to gradually shape society's perception of the benefits of training. Secondly, it is crucial to find ways in which training can adapt quickly and flexibly to changes in the labour market, whether these are sudden ones, such as during the current pandemic, or based on technological or social developments. Furthermore, I believe that such preparation should really be for everyone.
