However, we must not only declare on this the removal of barriers to education, but also think about better accessibility of digital tools, strengthening digital skills, debariising the environment and improving the overall public perception of the possibilities of professional application of vulnerable persons, whether persons with disabilities or persons from disadvantaged backgrounds. Finally, I will mention one aspect that I lack in the recommendations, which concerns the acquisition of skills outside official educational structures. For example, many people acquire invaluable skills during the care of a loved one, but they are not formally recognised. Therefore, the new vocational training system should also flexibly respond to such situations and also link non-formal acquired skills to their formal recognition.

name: Antonius MANDERS
text: Mr President, it is good that we are talking about vocational education this evening and that we are getting back the doctor-and-craftsman we know from the past.  For too long, vocational education has had a bad image because - and I am one of them - parents wanted their children to study, be academically educated and get an office job, and then no more young people were educated with a real profession, at least a real profession with hands and spirit, to strengthen our economy. The image of craftsmen was that they always had to work hard in weather and wind and actually got underpaid. I believe that this has given us fewer and fewer professionals and that our economy will be in trouble because the economy in Western Europe cannot progress without migrant workers.  I believe that we should launch a campaign to make vocational training attractive to young people again. And that we also have to pay them better, which makes the image better. I propose to reintroduce the master-and-journeyman system - which used to be the guilds - which teaches young old and old from young, and which actually gives us a society we want.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. First of all, I would like to thank all the stakeholders for their ideas and their contribution to effectively promoting vocational training. I also welcome the adoption by your Parliament of a resolution promoting this form of training.  We all agree that, especially after this crisis, vocational training will become even more important. It will have to be open to new technologies, such as digital technology, such as digitalization. It must keep pace with the evolution of our economy, as the evolution of our economy will see the emergence of new professions, but also the need for new skills. And I believe that, precisely, what the Commission intends to promote is the flexibility inherent in vocational training. I think that is one of the important points.  The second point I would like to make is the extension of this form of training, the extension to many professions. There is no longer - there should be no more - this opposition between academic training and vocational training. We need open systems where we can move from one to the other. I think that is a very important aspect in valuing vocational training.  You also pointed out the attractiveness of vocational training, and salaries are indeed one of the elements of that attractiveness. Hence, moreover, the interest of having an framework for minimum wages, because if young people feel that they cannot earn a living by taking a vocational training course, the attractiveness will not be assured.  Yes, the youth guarantee must be an instrument to guide, to direct young people towards vocational training, and that is its objective. I believe that in Europe we face many young people who do not have a degree, who have no training and who are likely to be the losers of future economic development, the so-called NEETs. I believe that vocational training can be an absolutely valuable way to give these young people a new opportunity.  And finally, on Erasmus and the figure of 8% that has been raised concerning young people in vocational training who should have the chance to have professional mobility: 8% is not enough. I believe that there are still too many barriers that prevent young people in vocational training from accessing this professional mobility. I am committed here to work on the removal of these barriers to reach more than 8% and so that every young person in vocational training has the same rights, exactly the same rights, as those who go to university and can take advantage of this mobility.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The debate has shown me that the institutions are also pulling together on this central issue. I would also like to reassure you – also in view of the central competences of education policy, which are in the hands of the Member States or the regions – that we take the recommendations very, very seriously and that we are also aware of the European dimension of vocational training. We have tried to shed light on this with a number of very specific examples, and I would also like to thank you for that. So what do I take with me from this debate? Firstly, vocational training needs more appreciation. The central importance of the craft sector, which is an irreplaceable pillar in the field of vocational training, has just been mentioned in a very, very many Member States, regardless of the structure of dual training. I take a second message with me: inclusivity and equity of opportunity. Dual education must really be open to all, and it must also help to ensure that people have a second, a third chance and that those who have failed or who have considerable difficulties can go their own way as free members of our European societies. Yes, and I would also like to acknowledge that the European Union is already making a significant contribution, for example through the European Social Fund, to improving training and qualification, especially for the disadvantaged. So it is always a question of adequate financial, organisational support. Another message I take away from today's debate is that we also see new developments as an opportunity and that we are also taking away people's fears of change. Of course, digitalisation, but also environmental issues, play a very central role at the moment. Of course, the Members who have pointed out that it is not enough simply to give a young person, an apprentice, a laptop or even an iPad. That will not be enough. And the very last thing I would like to promote again is the principle of "learning from each other and with each other" – completely unbiased. There are excellent examples in the European Union which show that it is possible and that what we have now agreed in the recommendation can also be implemented everywhere. Best practice is an excellent tool.  Once again, thank you very much for this debate, which has once again underlined the importance of vocational training, the qualification of young people, here in the European Union.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: A motion for a resolution has been tabled in accordance with Rule 136(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place on Wednesday, 16 December 2020, and the final vote will take place on Thursday 17 December 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. – We know that the impact of the pandemic on vocational education and training (VET) has been massive. Within VET, digital learning is even more difficult than in classical education. At the same time, vocational education and training are crucial for maintaining classic European industries, which have long suffered from a shortage of skilled labour. The VET deserves our full support and this oral question with the EMPL resolution is therefore very appropriate. Last Friday, a trialogue agreement on the Erasmus programme was concluded after 2021. This is excellent news for young people in the EU, students, vocational education and training pupils, teachers and staff in the field. The mobility of pupils and staff in vocational education and training will continue to be massively encouraged in the EU. Up to a fifth of the budget of the Erasmus programme, which will total EUR 26 billion, can be devoted to this. It will also be possible to systematically promote cooperation between centres for a top level of vocational education and training under the Erasmus programme. The feedback I receive from our national agency shows that European money invested in VET is one of the most effectively invested funds in terms of concrete impacts. We must maintain this and continue to support it.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the end of Norbert Lins' abattoir exemption for slaughterhouses established in Regulation (EU) 2017/185 on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (O-000076/2020 – B9-0030/20) (2020/2886(RSP)). Once again, I would like to draw the attention of all Members to the provisions – no spontaneous speeches, no blue cards, interconnections from the liaison offices – which, unfortunately, need to be handled in the light of Corona.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to present to the Commission the list of questions presented by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development on the end of the derogation for slaughterhouses under Regulation (EU) 2017/185. Let me first point out that there are certain slaughterhouses in the EU that are allowed to slaughter and process animals without complying with certain hygiene requirements. However, this only applies to a limited quantity of animals in the poultry and hare meat sectors in order to market local and fresh meat to the final consumer or to retailers who deliver directly to the final consumer. In order to meet the high demand of consumers for these local products and to ensure better remuneration for local producers, short marketing cycles have been developed. I would like to point out that these practices go hand in hand with the Commission's farm-to-fork strategy. This strategy calls, among other things, on the Member States to switch to more sustainable production and consumption. In addition, short processing and production chains are called for in response to growing social demand and the favouring of local production. I would also like to refer to this as the current complex legal framework that applies, among other things, to these slaughterhouses. The Hygiene Ordinance lays down the specific hygiene requirements for food stuff of animal origin. By way of derogation from these rules, the Commission provided that an exception should apply to the direct supply of small quantities of poultry and hare meat slaughtered on the farm to the final consumer or to local retailers supplying the final consumer directly. However, this derogation will no longer be possible from 1 January 2021, since the scheme will no longer apply from that date, so that the undertakings concerned will no longer be able to carry out this activity. This is a serious problem for certain Member States, in particular the Czech Republic, Finland, France, Hungary and Poland – but not exclusively. These countries have already asked the Commission to extend the derogation. Unfortunately, however, the Commission confirmed the end date of the derogation. She stressed that the only way to continue this practice would be to change the hygiene rules, which would require a proper legislative procedure. There is an urgent need to clarify which procedure will be introduced from 1 January 2021 in order to allow producers to continue their work.  That is why the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development is addressing the following four questions to the Commission. Firstly, how does the Commission intend to allow slaughterhouses operating under this derogation to process their products when the derogation no longer applies from 1 January 2021? Secondly, when does the Commission intend to take action on the matter and what approach does it consider appropriate? Thirdly, what new legal framework will the Commission create to ensure a smooth transition for producers? Fourthly and finally, given the urgency of the question, when does the Commission intend to present an amendment to Regulation (EC) No 853/2004, which will allow producers to continue to supply local markets directly with processed poultry meat and hare meat? We thank you in advance for answering the questions.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the EU’s 2004 rules on the hygienic production of food aim to ensure a high level of food safety for consumers while remaining proportionate for producers. They provide the framework for all food produced for the EU market. When they were adopted, the co—legislators took account of small producers, notably, including the possibility to adapt hygiene rules for small local establishments and excluding certain on-farm practices from the scope of EU food hygiene requirements. In particular, the rules expressly exclude fresh meat from poultry and lagomorphs produced and slaughtered on—farm for direct supply to the final consumer or local retail establishments, as you just described.  Let me clarify. This will not change on 1 January 2021. Farmers can continue to produce and sell this type of fresh meat without having to comply with EU hygiene rules, due to their comparatively low risk. However, the situation is different for meat preparations like raw sausages and meat products like pates manufactured from this fresh meat. While small producers could temporarily benefit from a similar derogation to that for fresh meat, it was subject to a transition period of nearly 16 years, which ends this year. This was foreseen to allow sufficient time for producers to adapt smoothly to the EU’s hygiene rules. Last year, the European Parliament and the Council repealed the Commission’s empowerment to lay down transitional measures, meaning a new transitional arrangement is no longer legally possible. This means that, from 2021 onwards, meat preparations and meat products from poultry and lagomorphs slaughtered on—farm must respect the EU’s food hygiene legislation.  Contacts with Member States show that only a very limited number are concerned about the impact of ending the transitional measure for meat preparations and meat products. Member States may of course use the possibilities provided for in the legislation to adapt national rules to EU requirements.

name: Anne SANDER
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, the question on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture is a subject of concern to many slaughterhouses which, until now, have benefited from a waiver allowing them to market products directly as an extension of livestock. In these times of economic crisis, it is essential to defend this model of activity synonymous with jobs and economic wealth. The perpetuation of this derogation therefore represents first of all a real challenge for some of our rural areas, which are likely to be severely penalised, even though they are already going through a more than difficult situation. But beyond these economic considerations, these modes of production also find a particular resonance in the era of the Green Pact and the "farm-to-table" strategy, which call on us to encourage local circuits, also responding to a growing societal demand. That is why we are waiting for a response from the Commission that is going in the right direction, because this agricultural world badly needs it.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Mr President, the COFID-19 crisis has highlighted the importance of the short chain and the small producer - two vital elements in the new common agricultural policy. That is why many of us found it incomprehensible that the Commission's position not to extend the derogation granted to poultry and rabbit farmers, so that they could sell their farm-slaughtered animals in markets and local shops. I noted what the Commissioner said a few minutes ago, but although seven Member States - including Romania - have called for it, a procedure for revising the regulation has not even been started. There is a clear contradiction between the promised support of the small producer and the decisions actually taken, especially since we are talking about a producer badly hit this year by the COVID-19 measures that have caused him losses that he could not afford. I therefore call on the Commission for an urgent procedure to remedy this injustice.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to remind the Commission that we are working towards a coherent policy for the food chain. As part of the Green Deal, the Commission has for the first time presented a holistic approach to a fair, healthy and environmentally friendly food system in the Farm-to-Fork strategy. With the expiry of the transitional measures under Regulation (EU) 2017/185, the Commission is contradicting this approach. In doing so, it is harming many small businesses, which are already making important contributions to achieving these objectives through their practices. In addition, the Commission plans that a maximum of six animals may be slaughtered in the case of slaughter on the farm with a mobile slaughter box and that this may only be done in the presence of a veterinarian. Why should more restrictive rules apply here than conventional slaughter in the slaughterhouse? Consistency and proportionality of measures under the Hygiene Regulation with the objectives of the Farm-to-Fork strategy are mandatory. Regional direct marketers, who have invested a lot of money and are also slaughtering stress-free, are forced to stop here by arbitrariness. Tell me a case where these slaughters have put consumers at risk to health. I therefore call for an immediate extension of the transitional regulation. In the long term, we need a fair and practical regulatory framework.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the For many farms, direct marketing is the last chance to keep their farm running. For many of our consumers, the personal relationship with the farms from which they buy their food takes on a new meaning. In the Green Deal, we try to minimize transport routes. In the farm-to-fork strategy, we try to strengthen regional value chains and regional food supply. I cannot understand why this derogation should now expire, why these very farms that are doing just that – marketing regionally, short transport routes, no animal transports, no animal suffering – and what our consumers want should now be put in trouble. This is not a coherent policy with what we are doing here. Please, Commission, turn this exception into regulated legislation and make this exception a permanent exception, because, as we know, the problems are at home in slaughterhouses, in the large slaughterhouses, but not with small farmers. These problems generally do not exist there. Allow our farmers to continue to live.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I often get asked where animals are best slaughtered. Abroad? Certainly not. Last week, Eyes on Animals released gruesome images of Dutch calves being cut off in slaughterhouses in Libya and Lebanon while they are still alive.  What about Europe? Also in our own slaughterhouses we see how pigs suffer severely from CO2 anesthetic, how chickens are slaughtered unsedated by weak intoxication and how animals are mistreated. On the farm, then? That makes sense. In any case, it would save the animals long transports to the slaughterhouses. But only with mandatory CCTV, in the regular slaughterhouses and on the farm, so that we can all continuously monitor and monitor the welfare of the animals. Mr President, animal-friendly slaughter is an illusion. The only real animal-friendly slaughter is no slaughter. That is why I will continue to work towards a transition to plant-based nutrition. I hope that the European Commission will embrace this. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I thank you for your interventions and your comments. The Commission supports proportionate rules that guarantee the safety of food placed on the EU market. This protects consumers and enables producers on every scale to build a reputation based on quality and safety. This is all the more important given the rise in support for local producers, and this has been underlined during the recent COVID—19 lockdown.  As I have already mentioned, production of small quantities of fresh meat from poultry and lagomorphs for local sale is not at risk. For meat products and meat preparations, however, after almost 16 years the time has come for local producers also to comply with EU food hygiene rules. This does not mean that they have to stop their activities.  I’m convinced that with the flexibility introduced by the co—legislators in the 2004 regulations, the remaining requests for adoption can be addressed. The Commission will certainly look at that.
